Description: Banking in New-York and investments. President of Chatham National Bank. Director in Phoenix Insurance Company, New-York, Connecticut and Eastern Railroad, Consolidated Refrigerating Company, D. G. Yuengling, jr., Brewing Company, etc., etc.

Name: WILLIAM DURYEA
Description: Starch manufacturing. Director in the National Starch Manufacturing Company.

Name: PERRY BELMONT
Description: Inherited from August Belmont. Made in banking in New-York City.

Name: SWITIS CONDEE
Description: Manufacturing woollen knit goods.

Name: THOMPSON KINGSFORD
Description: Made in the Oswego starch factory and a planing mill, box factory and store.

Name: THOMAS S. MOTT
Description: Made in the grain commission business, vessels, gas and water works, etc. President of the First National Bank.

Name: GEORGE B. SLOAN
Description: Made in the grain commission business chiefly, a little in Oswego Shade Cloth Factory. President of the Second National Bank. Director in the American Surety Company.

Name: THEODORE IRWIN
Description: In the grain commission business; a little in Oswego Shade Cloth Factory with Mr. Sloan.

Name: DAVID WILBER
Description: Large dealers in hops. Also in farming, banking and land investments.

Name: ABIJAH WESTON
Description: Has made several millions in the purchase of low-priced pine lands on the upper peninsula of Michigan and in the production of lumber. He is a large operator, and is the heaviest holder of stock in the Chicago Lumbering Company and the Weston Lumbering Company, which have large sawmills at Manistique, Mich. He is a large owner also in Weston, Dean & Aldrich, Gouverneur, N. Y.; Bronsons & Weston, Ottawa, Ont., and various other lumbering and manufacturing concerns.

Name: JOHN B. DUTCHER
Description: Made chiefly in railroads. He is a director in many of the Vanderbilt railroads, and owns a large dairy farm near Pawling.

Name: CYRUS FROST
Description: Brick manufacturing and investments. President of the Westchester County Bank.

Name: WILLIAM J. TINGUE (of Tingue, House & Co., New-York)
Description: Woollen manufacturing.

Name: JOHN A. MERRITT
Description: Speculation, in cattle chiefly.

Name: SILAS H. WITHERBEE
Description: Began in the transportation business on Lake Champlain, then went into iron mines and iron manufacturing.

Name: G. R. SHERMAN
Description: Iron mines and iron manufacturing.

Name: HENRY H. FARNUM
Description: Made in developing the local real estate, gas and water works, banks, etc., of the city.

Name: MRS. ARCHIBALD ROGERS (born Coleman)
Description: From iron mines in Pennsylvania. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: JOHN F. WINSLOW
Description: Manufacturing Bessemer steel, etc. He began life in New-Jersey, making pig iron. A few years later he engaged in iron manufacturing in Albany with Erastus Corning, and they made enormous quantities of railroad and other iron. With John A. Griswold he then supplied the financial aid for building the Monitor and six turreted ironclads; and, later, with Griswold, bought the Bessemer steel patents and manufactured steel on a large scale.

Name: JOHN O. WHITEHOUSE
Description: Made in manufacturing boots and shoes.

Name: MATTHEW VASSAR (founder of Vassar College)
Description: Made in brewing.

Name: JOHN GUY VASSAR
Description: Made in brewing, with his uncle, Matthew Vassar.

Name: JOHN P. ADRIANCE (of Adriance, Platt & Co.)
Description: Manufacturing the Buckeye reaper and mower, etc.

Name: JOSEPH TUCKERMAN TOWER
Description: From his brother, Albert E. Tower, who was president of the Poughkeepsie Iron Works. Treasurer of the Port Henry Iron Ore Company, etc. Made in mineral lands, etc.

Name: A. E. TOWER
Description: From his father of the same name. Made in mines, manufacturing, etc.

Name: CHARLES M. McGILL
Description: Made in royalties on brass fasteners for documents and law papers.

Name: ALFRED DE WITT
Description: Partly inherited from his brother, a lawyer. Most of his fortune made by himself in California in early days by merchandising, speculations in real estate, lumber, etc., followed by purchases of real estate at Elizabeth, N. J., and investments in securities.

Name: CHAUNCEY KILMER
Description: Paper manufacturing.

Name: COLONEL DANIEL DAVID CAMPBELL
Description: Inherited. Made in fine stock-raising and lands.

Name: MRS. SAMUEL D. COYKENDALL
Description: From her father, Thomas Cornell. Made in steamboating.

Name: HIRAM W. SIBLEY
Description: Inherited more than a million from his father, Hiram Sibley, who made a great fortune in the Western Union Telegraph Company when it was formed; was also in the wholesale seed business. President of the Bank of Monroe.

Name: MRS. HIRAM SIBLEY
Description: Inherited from her late husband. Made as above described.

Name: H. H. WARNER
Description: Made in the manufacture of proprietary medicines.

Name: HENRY BARTHOLOMAY
Description: Founder and principal owner of the Bartholomay Brewing Company, until it was sold to an English syndicate.

Name: WILLIAM S. KIMBALL
Description: Manufacturing cigarettes and investments. President of the Union Bank.

Name: JUNIUS JUDSON
Description: Manufacture of the Judson steam governors in the firm of Junius Judson & Son.

Name: MRS. EARL B. PUTNAM
Description: From her father, Charlemagne Tower. Made in law practice, the purchase of coal and mineral lands, and railroad building, railroads, etc.

Name: JAMES C. HART
Description: Manufacturing cigarettes.

Name: C. B. WOODWORTH
Description: Street railway franchise in Rochester.

Name: GEORGE ELLWANGER (of Ellwanger & Barry)
Description: Made in the nursery business.

Name: DON ALONZO WATSON
Description: The richest man in Rochester. Made several millions in handling Western Union Telegraph Company stock.

Name: MRS. JAMES S. WATSON
Description: Inherited over a million from her father, Hiram Sibley.

Name: GEORGE C. BUELL
Description: Made in wholesale groceries.

Name: D. W. POWERS
Description: Chiefly in real estate, Powers Hotel, and banking. President of Powers’ Bank.

Name: CHARLES J. BURKE
Description: Drygoods merchandising.

Name: GEORGE EASTMAN
Description: Made in the manufacture of photographic outfits.

Name: PATRICK BARRY
Description: Nursery business.

Name: WILSON SOULE
Description: Inherited from his father. Made in the manufacture of “Hop Bitters,” and in Western railroads and canals.

Name: MORTIMER F. REYNOLDS
Description: Made in advance in value of real estate inherited from his father.

Name: EDMUND OCUMPAUGH
Description: Made in the sale of gentlemen’s furnishing goods, and real estate.

Name: A. G. YATES
Description: Wholesale and retail dealing in coal.

Name: MICHAEL FILON (president of the East Side Savings Bank)
Description: Banking and real estate.

Name: SIMON L. BREWSTER (president of Traders’ National Bank)
Description: Made in banking and loans.

Name: HENRY A. STRONG
Description: Manufacturing whips in the Strong & Woodbury Whip Company, originally; now a large owner in the Eastman Dry Plate and Film Company.

Name: JAMES J. WINANTS
Description: Contracting.

Name: JOSEPH PARK (of Park & Tilford, New-York City)
Description: Wholesale and retail groceries, chiefly, added to by investments in banks, insurance companies, real estate, etc. Director in the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, Sixth National Bank, etc.

Name: E. B. WESLEY
Description: Made in stocks.

Name: WILLIAM W. DURANT
Description: From Dr. Thomas C. Durant. Made first in shipping, but chiefly in railroads in the West and Northern New-York. Director in the Adirondacks Railway.

Name: BENJAMIN BRANDRETH
Description: Manufacturing medicines and porous plasters.

Name: HENRY J. BAKER
Description: Merchandising drugs in Baltimore and manufacturing castor oil in Jersey City, and saltpetre in Brooklyn and several other places. He had complete control of those two trades for many years. The Baker Castor Oil Company still continues in business.

Name: CHARLES G. ELLIS
Description: Made in the Schenectady Locomotive Works. President of the company.

Name: EDWARD ELLIS
Description: Made in the Schenectady Locomotive Works. Is treasurer of the company.

Name: D. EDGAR CROUSE
Description: Richest man in the city. Partly inherited from his father, John Crouse, and his brother, John J. Made in wholesale grocery business, followed by investments in express and other companies.

Name: JAMES J. BELDEN
Description: Made in State and Government contracts in firm of Denison, Belden & Co. Now in banking. President of the Robert Gere Bank.

Name: JACOB CROUSE
Description: Wholesale groceries and real estate.

Name: ALEXANDER H. DAVIS
Description: Partly inherited. Made in railroads, landed property and coal.

Name: A. C. BELDEN
Description: Public contract work with James J. Belden.

Name: ROBERT N. GERE
Description: Ironworks, saltworks and banking.

Name: GEORGE N. KENNEDY
Description: Law practice and fortunate real estate investments, and partly through his wife. He is president of the Merchants’ National Bank.

Name: GEORGE BARNES (of the Whitman & Barnes Co.)
Description: Made in manufacturing and investments.

Name: HORACE K. WHITE
Description: Stock speculation and real estate.

Name: BAINBRIDGE S. CLARK
Description: Made in carpet manufacturing, with Elias S. Higgins.

Name: FREDERICK S. FOSTER
Description: Made in California.

Name: MRS. KATE ANDERSON
Description: From the estate of her husband, John Anderson, the tobacco manufacturer.

Name: FREDERICK W. GUITEAU
Description: Grain commission business and railroads.

Name: WILLIAM P. HAZLETON
Description: Made in piano manufacturing.

Name: ROBERT E. HOPKINS
Description: Made in oil pipe-lines and kindred enterprises.

Name: EUGENE JONES (Jones & Co., New-York)
Description: Flour milling.

Name: GEORGE B. NEWTON
Description: Mining and shipping coal.

Name: MRS. ELIZABETH S. PATON
Description: From her husband, Francis Paton. Made in linen importing.

Name: REV. EDWARD C. BULL
Description: Fortune partly inherited, but added to by various investments. He is a retired Episcopal clergyman.

Name: JOHN SINCLAIR
Description: Made in provisions.

Name: D. O. BRADLEY
Description: Banking and investments in real estate. President of the Tarrytown National Bank.

Name: MRS. CORA LIVINGSTON BARTON
Description: Inherited from the Livingston family. Made in real estate. She was the daughter of Edward Livingston and widow of Thomas P. Barton.

Name: JOHN J. JOSLIN
Description: Manufacturing hemp, flax and wool; lands in the West and real estate here.

Name: EDWARD MURPHY, JR (of Kennedy & Murphy)
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: WILLIAM KENNEDY (of Kennedy & Murphy)
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: GEORGE M. TIBBITS
Description: Made in part in the tallow chandlery business, but chiefly in farms and real estate in various localities in Northern New-York.

Name: JUSTUS MILLER (of Miller, Hall & Hartwell)
Description: Manufacturing shirts and collars; real estate and stocks.

Name: JOSEPH M. WARREN
Description: Made in manufacturing stoves and hardware.

Name: WILLIAM F. BURDEN
Description: Inherited from his father, William F. Burden, sr. Iron and mines, foundries and machine shops.

Name: GEORGE H. CRAMER
Description: Banking, stock in the mowing machine factory of Walter A. Wood, and investments in railroads, etc. President of the United National Bank.

Name: WILLIAM POWERS
Description: Made in manufacturing paints and oils, oil refining, manufacturing oil cloths, and private banking at Lansingburg, N. Y.

Name: WILLIAM H. FREAR
Description: Merchandising, drygoods.

Name: I. TOWNSEND BURDEN
Description: Inherited. Made in the invention and manufacture of patented articles, including the first cultivator ever used in the United States, a machine for making wrought iron spikes. Director in International Boiler Company and Knickerbocker Trust Company.

Name: JAMES A. BURDEN
Description: Inherited. Made in inventions and making of patented articles, cultivators, machine for making horseshoes, hook-head iron spikes, etc.; also in iron mines. Director in the Chateaugay Ore and Iron Company.

Name: JOHN L. THOMPSON
Description: Merchandising drugs.

Name: N. G. LUDLOW
Description: Manufacturing valves.

Name: NATHAN B. WARREN
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate, banking, etc.

Name: STEPHEN WARREN
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate, banking, etc.

Name: JOHN THORN
Description: Made in the manufacture of soap and candles, and railroad investments.

Name: LEWIS H. LAWRENCE
Description: Lumber dealing and railroads.

Name: THEO. S. FAXTON
Description: Stage and telegraph lines.

Name: MRS. JAMES WATSON WILLIAMS
Description: Inherited. Made in Pennsylvania coal lands and stock investments.

Name: JOSHUA MATHER
Description: Merchandising first; then banking, the purchase of real estate and street railroads, electric light, etc. President of A. D. Mather & Co.’s Bank.

Name: MRS. DR. HENRY GOLDTHWAITE (Cornelia C. Munson)
Description: Inherited. Made in Pennsylvania coal lands and investments in stocks.

Name: GAIL BORDEN
Description: Made a large fortune in manufacture of condensed milk (patented) at Wassaic, Wallkill, and Brewster’s, N. Y., and Elgin, Ill.

Name: JAMES R. WHITING
Description: Made in the manufacture of “Hop Extract.”

Name: GEORGE I. MAGEE
Description: Pennsylvania coal mines, etc.

Name: E. H. MACK
Description: Merchandising and investments.

Name: GEORGE T. ADEE
Description: He left several millions, made in mercantile business in New-York City, banking, and large purchases of real estate.

Name: JOHN C. JACKSON
Description: Merchandising iron and coal.

Name: ABIJAH CURTISS
Description: Street railroads in New-York City and investments.

Name: FRED. K. AGATE
Description: Inherited from his father, Joseph Agate. Made in merchandising and investments in real estate.

Name: EDWARD J. KING
Description: Fur business and real estate in New-York City.

Name: HENRY E. ROBINSON
Description: Made in business in California.

Name: JAMES B. COLGATE
Description: Banking and bullion dealing in New-York City.

Name: MRS. JOHN TREVOR
Description: From her husband. Made in banking, railroads and stocks.

Name: MARY T. TREVOR
Description: From her father, John B. Trevor. Made in banking, railroads and stocks.

Name: EMILY H. TREVOR
Description: From her father, John B. Trevor. Made in banking, railroads and stocks.

Name: WARREN SMITH
Description: From his father, Alexander Smith, of Alex. Smith & Sons’ Carpet Co., and the Smith Moquette Loom Co. Made in manufacturing carpets and looms.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM F. COCHRAN
Description: From her father, Alexander Smith. Made in manufacturing carpets and looms.

Name: FRANK COXE
Description: Mines in Pennsylvania; real estate, banking and hotel at Asheville, and interest in many other enterprises.

Name: LAWRENCE HOLT
Description: Made in raw cotton and cotton manufacturing.

Name: JAMES HOLT
Description: Made in raw cotton and cotton manufacturing.

Name: WILLIAM E. HOLT
Description: Made in raw cotton and cotton manufacturing.

Name: Mrs. WESTMORELAND
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate in Virginia.

Name: GEORGE W. WATTS
Description: Made in manufacturing tobacco. President of the Fidelity Bank.

Name: JULIAN S. CARR
Description: Manufacturing tobacco; and president of First National Bank.

Name: WASHINGTON DUKE
Description: Manufacturing tobacco.

Name: JAMES B. DUKE
Description: Manufacturing tobacco. President of the American Tobacco Company.

Name: BENJAMIN M. DUKE
Description: Manufacturing tobacco. Director in the American Tobacco Company.

Name: B. L. DUKE
Description: Manufacturing tobacco.

Name: PAUL C. CAMERON
Description: Largely inherited through several generations. Increased by himself. Made in plantations, banking and railroads. Was president of the North Carolina Railroad, and director in several railroads and banks.

Name: K. M. MURCHISON
Description: Made in cotton and naval stores, and in real estate, including the Orton House.

Name: WILLIAM BUSH
Description: Made in manufacturing morocco, and banking. Was president of the Equitable Guarantee and Trust Company.

Name: Colonel CHARLES A. MORTON
Description: Banking and investments. He is president of the Exchange Bank.

Name: O. C. BARBER (president of the Diamond Match Company)
Description: Manufacturing matches.

Name: LOUIS MILLER (superintendent of Aultman, Miller & Co.)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements.

Name: A. L. CONGER (of the Whitman & Barnes Manufacturing Company)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements.

Name: FERDINAND SCHUMACHER (of the Ferdinand Schumacher Milling Company)
Description: Manufacturing oatmeal and flour milling. Has investments in the East Tennessee Land Company, etc.

Name: JOHN F. SIEBERLING
Description: Mowing machine manufacturing.

Name: GEORGE W. CROUSE (president of Aultman, Miller & Co.)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements. President of the City National Bank.

Name: THOMAS W. CORNELL
Description: Banking and gas companies in Akron and Brooklyn, N. Y.; president of First National Bank of Akron and Akron Gas Company.

Name: CORNELIUS AULTMAN
Description: Manufacturing reapers and agricultural implements.

Name: MRS. CATHERINE L. ANDERSON
Description: By inheritance from Nicholas Longworth, who founded a great fortune by purchases of real estate.

Name: W. P. ANDERSON
Description: Made in real estate and cotton oil; inheritance from Nicholas Longworth largely.

Name: R. B. BOWLES
Description: By inheritance from his father, who made his money largely in the Kentucky Central Railroad; and from his mother, a sister of Elliott H. and George H. Pendleton, whose money was made in real estate.

Name: JULIUS BALKE
Description: Made in the manufacture of billiard tables in the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company.

Name: LEOPOLD BURCKHARDT
Description: Oil producing, etc.

Name: CHRISTIAN BASS
Description: Made in brewing, and in real estate.

Name: A. D. BULLOCK
Description: Made in manufacturing cotton, wool and hair bristles.

Name: POWELL CROSBY
Description: Made in real estate investments.

Name: ALEXANDER M. DONALD
Description: Made a large fortune in petroleum producing, refining, etc.

Name: THOMAS J. EMERY
Description: While engaged in manufacturing candles, etc., his wealth has been made almost wholly in real estate, with some other investments.

Name: J. J. EMERY
Description: Made almost wholly in real estate. Is engaged in manufacturing candles to some extent.

Name: MISS KEZIAH EMERY
Description: Made almost entirely in real estate.

Name: ALBERT ERKENBRECHER
Description: Made in manufacturing starch. Director in the National Starch Manufacturing Company.

Name: JACOB ELSAS
Description: Tanning and leather, and real estate.

Name: FRED ECKSTEIN
Description: Manufacturing white lead.

Name: SETH EVANS
Description: Packing meats and real estate.

Name: SAMUEL FOSDICK
Description: Merchandising first; then cotton manufacturing; then railroad investments, etc.

Name: CHARLES FLEISCHMANN
Description: Whiskey distilling and yeast.

Name: JULIUS FREIBERG
Description: Made in wholesale liquors.

Name: JAMES W. GAFF
Description: Made over two millions in the Mill Creek Distilling Company, the Perlin-Gaff Manufacturing Company, Third National Bank, and other enterprises.

Name: WILLIAM GLENN
Description: Merchandising, and railroad and other investments.

Name: JAMES N. GAMBLE (of the Proctor & Gamble Co.)
Description: Manufacturing soap and candles; and investments.

Name: WILLIAM S. GROESBECK
Description: Groceries, steamboats and real estate.

Name: MRS. LAURETTA BODMAN GIBSON
Description: From her brother, Ferdinand Bodman, a tobacco merchant, money lender and real estate owner.

Name: L. B. HARRISON
Description: Made a large fortune in banking and investments. He is president of the First National Bank.

Name: W. H. HARRISON
Description: Made in real estate investments.

Name: A. H. HINKLE
Description: Made in publishing copyrighted school books. Director in the American Book Company.

Name: JOHN HAUCK
Description: Brewing and banking. Is president of the German National Bank.

Name: M. E. INGALLS
Description: Made a large fortune in railroads.

Name: J. N. KINNEY
Description: Packing meats and real estate.

Name: CHARLES H. KILGOUR
Description: Street railroads and banking.

Name: S. KUHN (of S. Kuhn & Sons)
Description: Private banking.

Name: HERMAN LACKMAN
Description: Made in the sale of liquors at wholesale.

Name: MRS. NICHOLAS LONGWORTH
Description: By inheritance from Nicholas Longworth, who laid the basis of a great fortune by early investments in real estate.

Name: HENRY LEWIS
Description: Manufacturing hair goods and real estate.

Name: CHRISTIAN MOERLEIN (of the C. Moerlein Brewing Co.)
Description: Brewing and bottling.

Name: ROBERT MITCHELL (of the Robert Mitchell Furniture Co.)
Description: Made in the manufacture of furniture.

Name: STERN MAYER
Description: Wholesale clothing and cloths.

Name: GOTTILIEB MUHLHAUSER
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: HENRY MARTIN
Description: Drygoods merchandising.

Name: J. R. McLEAN
Description: Made in publishing “The Cincinnati Daily Enquirer”; and Washington real estate.

Name: HENRY MACK (of Mack, Stadler & Co.)
Description: Wholesale cloth and clothing.

Name: J. J. MOONEY
Description: Made in tanning and leather; real estate, coffin-making, etc.

Name: MRS. MARY J. PERIN (widow of Oliver Perin)
Description: Inherited a large fortune, accumulated in the Mill Creek Distilling Co., the Perlin-Gaff Manufacturing Co., the Third National Bank, etc.

Name: ELLIOT H. PENDLETON
Description: By inheritance. Made in real estate and banking.

Name: HENRY PROBASCO
Description: Made in the hardware business. He was a partner of Tyler Davidson, whose sister he married.

Name: HARLEY T. PROCTOR (of the Proctor & Gamble Co.)
Description: Manufacturing soap and candles.

Name: WILLIAM N. PROCTOR (of the Proctor & Gamble Co.)
Description: Manufacturing soap and candles.

Name: JOSEPH RAWSON
Description: Packing meats.

Name: MRS. BELLAMY STORER
Description: By inhertiance from Nicholas Longworth, who laid the foundation of a great fortune by early purchases of real estate.

Name: REUBEN R. SPRINGER
Description: Merchandising first, then railroads, real estate, and miscellaneous investments.

Name: WILLIAM SUMNER
Description: Manufacturing sewing machines.

Name: JOHN L. STETTINIUS
Description: By inheritance from Nicholas Longworth, who laid the basis of a large fortune, by early purchases of real estate.

Name: W. W. SCARBOROUGH
Description: Banking and real estate.

Name: LEWIS SEASONGOOD
Description: Wholesale cloth and clothing.

Name: DAVID SINTON
Description: Made many millions in iron manufacturing.

Name: STEWART SHILLITO
Description: Made in drygoods, and by inheritance.

Name: EDWARD SARGENT
Description: Publishing copyrighted school books.

Name: GEORGE K. SCHOENBERGER
Description: Made over four millions in iron manufacturing.

Name: LOUIS STIX
Description: Wholesale drygoods.

Name: BRIGGS SWIFT
Description: Pork-packing, his fortune having been augmented by fortunate investments in real estate.

Name: J. C. TULLIS
Description: Largely in the manufacture of the rebounding ball; in part by speculation in horses during the war, and real estate investments.

Name: LEWIS VAN ANTWERP
Description: Educational publications, copyrighted.

Name: MICHAEL WERK
Description: Wholesale wines and soap.

Name: JAMES WALSH
Description: Distilling and redistilling, and wholesale liquors.

Name: M. MORRIS WHITE
Description: Banking. He is president of the Fourth National Bank.

Name: O. J. WILSON
Description: Copyrighted school books publishing.

Name: A. S. WINSLOW
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: DANIEL WOLF
Description: Wholesale clothing and real estate.

Name: DR. N. B. WOLFE
Description: Manufacturing proprietary medicines.

Name: E. ZIMMERMAN
Description: Made in lumber dealing.

Name: SAMUEL ANDREWS
Description: Made a large fortune in oil refining, producing and transportation, in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: CHARLES F. BRUSH
Description: Manufacture of electric light machinery invented and patented by himself.

Name: STEVENSON BURKE
Description: Law practice, railroads, real estate and investments in mining and manufacturing companies. President of the Cleveland and Mahoning Valley Railway; Toledo and Ohio Central Railway; Toledo, Columbus and Cincinnati Railway; Kanawha and Michigan Railway, and Central Ontario Railway. Interested largely in nickel mines.

Name: E. I. BALDWIN (of E. I. Baldwin, Hatch & Co.)
Description: Made in a large drygoods business and investments in real estate.

Name: MRS. W. J. BOARDMAN
Description: From her father, James E. Sheffield, of New-Haven, Conn. Made in merchandising in the South and railroads, etc., in the North.

Name: M. A. BRADLEY
Description: Vessel property on the lakes.

Name: T. S. BECKWITH
Description: Engaged in merchandising; heavily interested in banking business; and a large owner of gas stock during the many years when it paid great dividends.

Name: MRS. C. S. HASKELL
Description: From her father, Dr. Wick. Made in iron manufacturing at Leetonia, Ohio.

Name: MRS. MARY S. BRADFORD
Description: From her father, who bought real estate in the early days of the city, which has now become valuable.

Name: DUDLEY BALDWIN
Description: One of the very early settlers of Cleveland. For many years the only vender of seeds and agricultural implements in that region. The bulk of his fortune has been acquired in real estate. Has other investments. Vice-President of the Wick Banking and Trust Co.

Name: WILLIAM CHISHOLM (of Wm. Chisholm & Sons, etc.)
Description: Rolling mills and other manufacturing; ore mining; and vessels.

Name: SELAH CHAMBERLAIN
Description: Contracting and railroad building, and investments in railroads, canals, real estate, and iron mines.

Name: AHIRA A. COBB
Description: Vessels on the Lakes; merchandising; and real estate. He was a large owner of real estate.

Name: LEONARD CASE
Description: Inherits from his father, Leonard Case, senior, who accumulated a large fortune in real estate, principally, in which he was a large dealer and owner. The son left the bulk of his estate to the Case Library and the Case School of Applied Science.

Name: JAMES F. CLARK
Description: Merchandising hardware, loans, and banking, but chiefly in building, organizing railroads. Some in coal mines.

Name: JAMES CORRIGAN
Description: He has interests in propellers on the lakes and in iron mines; but the great bulk of his fortune comes from refining oil and stock of the Standard Oil Company, in which he is a large owner.

Name: WARREN H. CORNING
Description: Distilling. A member of the Whiskey Trust.

Name: T. D. CROCKER
Description: Petroleum oil, banking, and fortunate investments.

Name: DAN P. EELLS
Description: President and Vice-President of the Commercial National Bank for nearly thirty years. Made chiefly in banking, but acquired some property in railroading and express companies and various kinds of manufacturing. Director in the United States Express Company.

Name: JULIUS E. FRENCH
Description: Distilling. A member of the Whiskey Trust; and manufacturing tar roofing for railroad cars, and car wheels.

Name: W. J. GORDON
Description: Wholesale groceries and liquors, added to by investments in iron and copper mines in Lake Superior region.

Name: S. V. HARKNESS
Description: Made in oil producing, refining and transportation in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: JOHN HUNTINGTON
Description: Made in oil producing, refining and transportation in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: L. E. HOLDEN
Description: Silver mines in Utah and other mine investments.

Name: MARCUS A. HANNA (of M. A. Hanna & Co.)
Description: Made in handling coal and iron ore, and investments in banks, street railroads, the Union Pacific Railroad, etc. President of the Union National Bank.

Name: CHARLES HICKOX
Description: Originally in flour milling. Later, a large buyer of real estate and railroad builder, and owner in iron mines.

Name: E. B. HALE
Description: Banking and western real estate.

Name: R. K. HAWLEY
Description: Made in lumber dealing.

Name: JAMES M. HOYT
Description: Real estate, purchased in early days.

Name: JAMES HARMON
Description: Iron manufacturing.

Name: H. B. HURLBUT
Description: Banking and railroad stocks.

Name: MELVILLE H. HANNA
Description: Iron manufacturing and iron ship building. He is the head of the Globe Iron Company, and the Globe Iron Ship Building Company.

Name: THOMAS L. JOHNSON
Description: Interested in iron mills at Johnstown, Pa., and a builder and owner of street railroads.

Name: PHILANDER L. JOHNSON
Description: Lake shipping and real estate.

Name: ZENAS KING
Description: Founder and President of the King Iron Bridge and Manufacturing Company.

Name: LEVI KERR
Description: Partly by inheritance. Made by himself in the oil business, steamers to the West Indies and various other enterprises.

Name: C. G. KING
Description: Made in the lumber trade, real estate and banking.

Name: T. P. LAWSON
Description: Made in manufacturing nuts and bolts.

Name: W. H. LAWRENCE
Description: Made in Brush Electric Co. stock; manufacture of cordage; and real estate.

Name: ISAAC LEISY
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: SAMUEL MATHER (of Pickands, Mather & Co.)
Description: Iron ore investments and vessel property on the lakes.

Name: MRS. SAMUEL MATHER
Description: From her father, Amasa Stone. Made in bridge building, railroads and investments. Amasa Stone was a man of remarkable ability and enterprise. He began life by building railroad bridges, and was for a while Superintendent of the New Haven, Hartford and Springfield Railroad. He then went into railroad building in the West. For several years managing director of the Lake Shore Railroad. He was once a director in the Western Union Telegraph Co., and in the Standard Oil Company. He had an interest in several banks, and founded rolling mills, woollen factories and other business enterprises. He died worth about $4,000,000.

Name: CHARLES A. OTIS
Description: Manufacturing iron and steel. He is president of the Otis Steel Company.

Name: J. B. PERKINS
Description: Advance in value of real estate, inherited through several generations.

Name: HENRY B. PAYNE
Description: Chiefly in real estate, but also in law practice, banking, railroads, etc.

Name: GEORGE W. PACK (of Pack, Woods & Co.)
Description: Sawmills and lumber.

Name: COLONEL OLIVER H. PAYNE
Description: Made in oil producing, refining and transportation, in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: JAMES PICKANDS
Description: Large investments in iron ore mines, especially in the celebrated Gogebic range.

Name: A. J. POPE
Description: Iron manufacturing. President and founder of the Malleable Iron Company.

Name: R. R. ROOT
Description: Wholesale drygoods.

Name: W. J. RAINEY
Description: Coal mines and coke.

Name: ROBERT R. RHODES
Description: Made in iron, coal and vessels on the lakes. President of the People’s Savings and Loan Association.

Name: GEORGE W. STOCKLY
Description: Manufacture of the Brush electric light machinery, patented.

Name: W. P. SOUTHWORTH
Description: Made in the sale of groceries and investments. Was president of the National City Bank.

Name: LEONARD SCHLATHER (of the Leonard Schlather Brewing Co.)
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: SILAS S. STONE
Description: Rise in value of real estate which he bought in early days and developed.

Name: DR. W. S. STREATOR
Description: Real estate and railroads.

Name: W. C. SCOFIELD
Description: Petroleum oil and rolling mills.

Name: CHARLES J. SHEFFIELD
Description: From his father, James E. Sheffield, of New-Haven, Conn. Merchandising in the South and railroads, etc., in the North.

Name: JOHN TOD
Description: Coal and iron mines.

Name: JOHN L. WOODS (of Pack, Woods & Co.)
Description: Saw mills and lumber and investments. President of the Euclid Avenue National Bank.

Name: CHARLES W. WASON
Description: Street railroads, real estate and, to some extent, iron manufacturing.

Name: THOMAS WILSON
Description: Vessels on the lakes, of which species of property he is one of the largest owners.

Name: J. H. WADE, JR.
Description: From his grandfather, Jeptha H. Wade, who made a fortune of several millions in telegraph lines, railroads and banking.

Name: WILLIAM J. WHITE
Description: Made mainly in the manufacture of chewing gum.

Name: MRS. ELIZA A. WITT
Description: From her husband, Stillman Witt, who left a large fortune, made in railroad building.

Name: HENRY WICK
Description: Banking. One of the veteran bankers of the city. President of the Wick Banking and Trust Co.

Name: S. WILLIAMSON
Description: Real estate, banking and law.

Name: MOSES C. YOUNGLOVE
Description: First in book publishing. Then in manufacturing agricultural implements. Also an original owner of profitable gas company stock.

Name: BENJAMIN S. BROWN
Description: Manufacturing and investments.

Name: WILLIAM G. DESHLER
Description: Banking and investments. He is president of the National Exchange Bank.

Name: WILLIAM MONEYPENNY
Description: Formerly in distilling. He put his profits into other lines of business enterprise. Now in banking and various investments. President of the First National Bank.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM DENNISON (widow of the late Governor Dennison)
Description: Inherited nearly $1,000,000 of real estate alone.

Name: FRANCIS C. SESSIONS
Description: Banking and real estate. Was President of the Commercial National Bank.

Name: EDWARD T. MITCHELL
Description: An early buyer of real estate, which is now valuable, much of which he has improved. He is said to be the largest tax-payer in the county.

Name: WILLIAM B. HAYDEN
Description: Mainly inherited from Peter Hayden, his father, and made by him in the manufacture of saddlery hardware, in Columbus, Ohio, Auburn, N. Y., and elsewhere. Added to both by father and son, in banking and investments.

Name: CHARLES HAYDEN
Description: Inherited from Peter Hayden, the saddlery hardware manufacturer, and added to by himself.

Name: HENRY T. CHITTENDEN
Description: Partly in business, but very largely in real estate, including a hotel, a theatre and a memorial hall.

Name: ROBERT E. NEIL
Description: Inherited, and added to by himself in judicious investments.

Name: LOUIS HOSTER
Description: Made in the L. Hoster Brewing Company and in real estate.

Name: P. W. HUNTINGTON
Description: Made in his private banking house and in judicious investments.

Name: JONAS M’CUNE
Description: In various business enterprises.

Name: EUGENE BARNEY
Description: Car manufacturing.

Name: JOHN HARRIS
Description: Miscellaneous investments.

Name: W. P. CALLIHAN
Description: Machinist business.

Name: JOHN K. McINTIRE
Description: Wholesale groceries in Dayton, for forty years president of the Third National Bank.

Name: JOHN W. STODDARD
Description: Made in manufacturing agricultural implements, protected by a patent.

Name: DAVID HARPSTER
Description: The largest individual worker of farm lands and wool grower in Ohio.

Name: BENJAMIN C. FAUROT
Description: Dealing in mules and horses during the War, etc. President of Lima National Bank.

Name: CALVIN S. BRICE
Description: See New-York city, where he is rated.

Name: DR. WILLIAM BUSHNELL
Description: Started in the practice of medicine. Bought thousands of acres of prairie land near Des Moines, Iowa, which has increased in value, and has invested in railroads, etc.

Name: E. P. STURGES
Description: Made in a general country store, and purchases of real estate, and private banking.

Name: JOHN SHERMAN
Description: Real estate here, and in St. Paul and Washington, D. C., street railways, bank stocks, railroads and other investments.

Name: DANIEL McCALLAY
Description: Banking and tobacco manufacturing. President of First National Bank.

Name: N. S. RUSSELL (of Russell & Co.)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements.

Name: WATSON HUBBARD
Description: Sawmills and lumber in Michigan, and real estate.

Name: RUSH R. SLOANE
Description: Railroads and investments.

Name: ROLLIN B. HUBBARD
Description: Sawmills, lumber, real estate and banking. President of the Second National Bank.

Name: JACOB KUEBLER
Description: Brewing and real estate in the firm of J. Kuebler & Co.

Name: AUGUST KUEBLER
Description: Brewing and real estate in the firm of J. Kuebler & Co.

Name: J. O. MARS
Description: Made in banking and railroads.

Name: JAMES WOOLWORTH
Description: Manufacturing handles during the War, and real estate since.

Name: F. T. BARNEY
Description: Made in manufacture and sale of hardware.

Name: LAWRENCE CABLE
Description: Merchandising, real estate and banking. President of the Third National Bank.

Name: JOHN W. BOOKWALTER
Description: Controlling owner in James Leffel & Co. Manufacturing patented water-wheels. Also in the Bookwalter Steel and Iron Company of New-Jersey, of which he is President.

Name: General ASA S. BUSHNELL (of Wardner, Bushnell & Glessner Co.)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements.

Name: B. H. WARDNER (of Wardner, Bushnell & Co.)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements. President of the First National Bank.

Name: J. H. THOMAS (of Wardner, Bushnell & Co.)
Description: Manufacturing agricultural implements.

Name: DAVID L. SNYDER
Description: Flour milling and investments.

Name: PHINEAS P. MAST
Description: Principally in manufacturing agricultural implements, but also in publishing, banking, etc. In the firms of P. P. Mast & Co., manufacturers, and Mast, Crowell & Kirkpatrick, publishers. Also president of the Springfield National Bank.

Name: Mrs. VALENTINE H. KETCHAM
Description: From her late husband, long the president of the First National Bank and a great owner of real estate.

Name: DENNIS COUGHLIN
Description: Brewing, real estate and banking. President of the Buckeye Brewing Company.

Name: WILLIAM PETERS
Description: He has made several millions in pine lands in Michigan, sawmills here, salt, real estate, and investment of his accumulations.

Name: CHARLES L. REYNOLDS (of Reynolds Bros.)
Description: With his brother he does the largest business in actual handling of grain in the world. They are grain and commission merchants.

Name: SHELDON C. REYNOLDS
Description: Made in grain and commission business and rebates from the Wabash road.

Name: GEORGE H. KETCHAM
Description: Inherited $750,000 from V. H. Ketcham, his father, and has added to it by investments in real estate, banking, stock farm, etc.

Name: CALVIN BRONSON
Description: Tobacco manufacturing in Toledo and Centreville and real estate in Chicago.

Name: GEORGE W. DAVIS
Description: Real estate and banking. President of Second National Bank.

Name: JOHN B. KETCHAM, 2d
Description: Inherited $750,000 from V. H. Ketcham. Real estate and banking. President of Ketcham’s National Bank.

Name: MRS. MARY E. NEARING
Description: Inherited from V. H. Ketcham. Made in real estate, banking, etc.

Name: JOHN T. NEWTON
Description: Real estate and banking.

Name: HORACE S. WALBRIDGE
Description: Started in the grain trade originally, but made his fortune principally in real estate. Has various interests.

Name: SAMUEL M. YOUNG
Description: Principal owner in the Toledo Gas Company. Made in gas works and real estate.

Name: H. B. PERKINS
Description: Iron manufacturing and rolling mills.

Name: EDWARD QUINBY
Description: Partly inherited. Real estate and loans.

Name: CHAUNCEY H. ANDREWS (of C. H. & W. C. Andrews)
Description: In the iron business, coal and railroads. President of Commercial National Bank.

Name: CHARLES D. ARMS
Description: Silver mines in Colorado.

Name: WILLIAM T. CARRINGTON
Description: Produce and railroads.

Name: GEORGE FLAVEL
Description: Real estate, steamboats and banking. President of the First National Bank.

Name: HENRY D. GREEN
Description: Gasworks, waterworks, real estate and kindred enterprises.

Name: L. FLEISCHNER (of Fleischner, Mayer & Co.)
Description: Dry-goods, millinery and fancy goods, and real estate.

Name: C. H. LEWIS
Description: Wharf property, storage business and merchandising.

Name: W. S. LADD (of Ladd & Tilton, bankers)
Description: Banking and purchases of real estate.

Name: HENRY FAILING
Description: Merchandising, banking and real estate. President of the First National Bank.

Name: H. W. CORBETT (of Corbett, Failing & Co.)
Description: Hardware merchandising, real estate and banking. President of the Security Savings and Trust Company.

Name: FRANK DEKUM
Description: Made in merchandising, banking and investments. President of the Portland Savings Bank.

Name: JACOB KAMM
Description: Made in merchandising and steamboating.

Name: W. K. SMITH
Description: Made in merchandising, steamboating and banking.

Name: AMOS KING
Description: Real estate investments.

Name: DONALD McLEAY
Description: Real estate and banking and merchandising. President of the United States National Bank.

Name: H. S. PITTOCK
Description: Real estate and newspaper publishing.

Name: RICHARD WILLIAMS
Description: Real estate and law practice.

Name: LEWIS LOVE
Description: Purchases of now-valuable real estate.

Name: VAN B. DE LASHMUTT
Description: Real estate, mining and banking. President of the Oregon National Bank and the Albina National Bank.

Name: DAVID P. THOMPSON
Description: Contracting, real estate and banking. President of the Commercial National Bank.

Name: A. BUSH
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: COLONEL JAMES ANDREWS.
Description: Engineer and general contractor on the Eads jetties and other public works.

Name: ALEXANDER M. BYERS.
Description: Manufacturing iron pipe, in Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and in banking. President of the Iron City National Bank in Pittsburg.

Name: JOSEPH S. BROWN.
Description: Manufacturing iron and steel. National Bank in Pittsburg.

Name: FELIX R. BRUNOT.
Description: Inherited from his father, and made in manufacturing white and red lead.

Name: JOHN W. CHALFANT.
Description: Manufacturing iron, steel and pipe. President of the People’s National Bank, in Pittsburg.

Name: JOHN DUNLAP.
Description: Importing tin, metals and japanned goods.

Name: MRS. HERBERT DU PUY.
Description: Inherited from her father, David Hostetter. Made in manufacturing proprietary medicines and bitters, and in railroad investments.

Name: MRS. ELIZABETH DARLINGTON.
Description: Inherited from Jacob N. McCullough, vice-president of the Pennsylvania Company, who made nine millions in railroads and stock operations. His start was made in merchandising, groceries and banking.

Name: HARRY DARLINGTON, JR.
Description: Inherited from Jacob N. McCullough, vice-president of the Pennsylvania Company, who made nine millions in railroads and stock operations. His start was made in merchandising groceries and banking.

Name: REBECCA DARLINGTON.
Description: Inherited from Jacob N. McCullough, vice-president of the Pennsylvania Company, who made nine millions in railroads and stock operations. His start was made in merchandising, groceries and banking.

Name: DAVID GREGG.
Description: Made in the sale of drygoods and investments in real estate.

Name: A. GUCKENHEIMER.
Description: Distilling.

Name: ABRAHAM GARRISON.
Description: Foundry and machine business and investments. President of Diamond National Bank and Safe Deposit Company of Pittsburg.

Name: MRS. J. COSH GRAHAM (born Annette McKee).
Description: Inherited from her father, Thomas McKee. Made in real estate.

Name: JOSEPH HORNE.
Description: Made in drygoods merchandising.

Name: MRS. DAVID HOSTETTER.
Description: From David Hostetter. Made in proprietary medicines and bitters, real estate and railroad stocks.

Name: D. HERBERT HOSTETTER.
Description: From David Hostetter. Made in proprietary medicines and bitters, real estate and railroad stocks. He is President of the Hostetter Company.

Name: THEODORE HOSTETTER.
Description: From David Hostetter. Made in proprietary medicines and bitters, real estate and railroad stocks.

Name: ROBERT HAYS.
Description: Made in steamboating on the rivers and canal transportation.

Name: THOMAS C. JENKINS.
Description: Made in wholesale groceries and flour.

Name: BENJAMIN F. JONES (of Laughlin & Co.).
Description: Made in iron and steel manufacturing.

Name: J. KAUFMAN.
Description: Made in the sale of clothing.

Name: WILLIAM J. KOUNTZE.
Description: Made in transportation by steamboats and rail.

Name: JACOB KLEE.
Description: Manufacture and sale of clothing.

Name: JAMES LAUGHLIN, JR. (of Jones and Laughlin).
Description: Manufacture of iron and steel.

Name: WILLIAM MULLINS.
Description: Made in railroad interests.

Name: JAMES MCCUTCHEON.
Description: Chiefly in iron manufacturing. President of the First National Bank.

Name: P. H. MILLER.
Description: In the building of locomotives and steam engines.

Name: H. SELLER McKEE (of McKee & Brothers).
Description: Manufacturing flint glass and traction roads. He is president of the First National Bank of Birmingham.

Name: MRS. JACOB N. McCULLOUGH.
Description: From her husband, who was vice-president of the Pennsylvania Company. Made in railroads and stock operations. Originally in merchandising, groceries, and banking.

Name: JOHN PORTERFIELD.
Description: Merchandising and groceries.

Name: HENRY PHIPPS, JR.
Description: Made in iron and steel manufacturing and bridge building.

Name: MRS. JAMES PARK, JR.
Description: Cotton, copper and steel manufacturing. Inherited.

Name: DAVID E. PARK.
Description: Chiefly inherited. Cotton, copper and steel manufacturing.

Name: CHARLES PARK.
Description: Chiefly inherited. Cotton, copper and steel manufacturing.

Name: WILLIAM G. PARK.
Description: Chiefly inherited. Cotton, copper and steel manufacturing.

Name: JAMES PARK.
Description: Chiefly inherited. Cotton, copper and steel manufacturing.

Name: A. E. W. PAINTER.
Description: Made in iron manufacturing and investments. President of the Safe Deposit and Trust Company of Pittsburg.

Name: JACOB PAINTER.
Description: Made in iron manufacturing.

Name: JOSHUA RHODES.
Description: Iron pipe manufacturing.

Name: WILLIAM H. SINGER (of Singer, Nimick & Co.).
Description: Steel manufacturing.

Name: MRS. DAVID A. STEWART.
Description: From her husband, who was connected with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the Pittsburg Locomotive Works, and the Carnegie interests.

Name: JOHN WALKER.
Description: Manufacturing soap, candles, etc.; cotton oil refining, and steel making.

Name: JOSEPH WALTON.
Description: Coal merchant; fortune made largely during the war. He is president of the Farmers’ Deposit Bank, Pittsburg.

Name: JAMES MILLIKEN.
Description: Dealing in stocks, especially in that of the Western Union Telegraph Company. Has large holdings in that Company, and in the United States and National Express Companies, etc.

Name: WILLIAM F. REYNOLDS.
Description: Merchandising, real estate and banking. He engaged a long time ago in iron manufacturing and lost money therein, resolving never to invest another dollar in manufacturing. He has also had flour milling interests, but made no money therein. His wealth comes entirely from non-protected industries.

Name: MORDECAI W. JACKSON.
Description: Partly in car-building. President of the First National Bank.

Name: J. T. JONES.
Description: Has made nearly a million, if not quite, in oil producing.

Name: L. EMORY, JR.
Description: Oil producing mainly, but has many other interests.

Name: JAMES AMM.
Description: Oil producing.

Name: JAMES W. BOSLER.
Description: Mainly in Indian contracts and the Palo Blanco cattle ranch, which was afterward sold to Stephen W. Dorsey.

Name: SAMUEL A. CROZER.
Description: Has made a large fortune in cotton manufacturing at Upland, Penn.

Name: ROBERT WETHERILL.
Description: Of R. Wetherill & Co.. Manufacture of steam engines and boilers.

Name: J. W. MOORE.
Description: Made in coke manufacture.

Name: ROBERT H. COLEMAN.
Description: Has a sixth interest in the famous Cornwall iron ore hills, in which, the State Geologist reports, there are more than 30,000,000 tons of iron ore, above water level, and a larger amount below. The ore is worth about $2 a ton.

Name: ANNIE COLEMAN.
Description: A sixth interest in the Cornwall iron ore hills.

Name: MRS. ALDER.
Description: A sixteenth interest in the Cornwall iron ore banks.

Name: JOHN PATTON.
Description: Lumbering, banking and increase in value of coal and timber lands.

Name: THOMAS BEAVER.
Description: Coal and iron and merchandising.

Name: W. J. RAINEY.
Description: Coal mines, coke and banking.

Name: JOHN E. DUBOIS.
Description: Sawmills, lumber, tanning and leather, and other interests.

Name: JOHN N. HUTCHINSON.
Description: Made in railroads.

Name: HON. WILLIAM A. GALBRAITH.
Description: Mostly in Chicago real estate. President of Erie Dime Savings and Loan Company.

Name: GEORGE SELDEN.
Description: Chief proprietor of the largest boiler and engine shop in the world.

Name: WILLIAM L. SCOTT, the richest man in the city.
Description: Made in railroads, coal mines and real estate in the city and elsewhere. His fortune was more than ten millions.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM L. SCOTT.
Description: By inheritance from John F. Tracy, increased by investments in the Rock Island Railroad.

Name: H. F. WATSON.
Description: Made in the manufacture of building and roofing paper.

Name: CHARLES M. REED.
Description: Erie City real estate, inherited from C. M. Reed, his father.

Name: MRS. GENERAL REED.
Description: Erie City real estate, inherited from C. M. Reed.

Name: JAMES CASEY.
Description: Partly from his brother John, who was his partner, and made by both in railroad contracting and building.

Name: JOSEPH M. FOX.
Description: Inheritance of oil lands. Fortune made in oil producing and private banking. President of the Foxburg Bank.

Name: HANNAH FOX.
Description: Inheritance of oil lands.

Name: S. P. McCALMONT.
Description: Law practice, coal interests, etc.

Name: J. DONALD CAMERON.
Description: Partly inherited from Simon Cameron. Added to by investments in real estate and in iron manufacturing. He is president of the National Bank of Middletown.

Name: C. L. BAILEY.
Description: Iron manufacturing.

Name: HENRY McCORMICK.
Description: By inheritance from James McCormick, the richest man in this section of the State, who made a fortune in law practice and real estate speculation. Added to by the son in iron manufacturing.

Name: JAMES McCORMICK.
Description: By inheritance from James McCormick, the richest man in this section of the State, who made a fortune in law practice and real estate speculation. Added to by the son in iron manufacturing.

Name: JACOB C. BOMBERGER
Description: Banking.

Name: GEO. H. MARKLE.
Description: Made about $3,000,000 in coal mining and railroads, which he left to five sons and daughters.

Name: CAPT. FRANK PARDEE.
Description: From his father, Ario Pardee, who made a very large fortune, exceeding $10,000,000, in hard and soft coal mines, iron mines and lumber.

Name: DANIEL EDWARDS.
Description: Mines, store and other investments.

Name: WILLIAM CAMERON.
Description: Land, banking, manufacturing and investments.

Name: CHARLES B. GRUBB.
Description: Inherited from Clement B. Grubb, who left $7,000,000. Made in iron furnaces and part ownership in the famous Cornwall iron ore hills. (See Cornwall.)

Name: BERNARD J. McGRANN.
Description: Made in railroad contracts private banking, etc.

Name: JAMES YOUNG.
Description: Merchandising, lumber, coal, tobacco, etc., and investments.

Name: MR. KUHN (of Kuhn Bros.).
Description: Banker and controller of the American Water Works and Guarantee Company. They control thirty or forty plants.

Name: GENERAL WILLIAM LILLY.
Description: Coal mining.

Name: EDWARD B. LEISENRING.
Description: Coal mining.

Name: MRS. CHARLES H. CUMMINGS.
Description: The only daughter of the late Judge Asa Packer, from whom she inherited a fortune, made in railroads, specially the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

Name: M. GEARY (of D. O’Day & M. Geary Oil City Boiler Works).
Description: Boiler manufacturing.

Name: MR. VANDERGRIFT (of Vandergrift, Young & Co.).
Description: Oil producing.

Name: WESLEY CHAMBERS.
Description: Oil property and mining speculation.

Name: MRS. J. C. AUDENRIED.
Description: Inherited.

Name: J. B. ALTEMUS (Coffin, Altemus & Co.).
Description: Commission dry goods.

Name: WILLIAM C. ALLISON.
Description: Car building, mainly.

Name: C. W. BERGNER (of the Bergner & Engel Brewing Co.).
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: JOHN BOHLEN.
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: SAMUEL BAUGH.
Description: Tanning and leather and railways. In the firm of Prichett, Baugh & Co.

Name: JOHN F. BETZ.
Description: Brewing and investments. A very rich man.

Name: T. WISTAR BROWN (of John Farnum & Co.).
Description: Manufacturing dry goods. Treasurer of Morris, Tasker & Co., manufacturers of iron pipes, tubes, etc. President of the Provident Life and Trust Company.

Name: ALEXANDER BIDDLE.
Description: Inherited. Made in the Pennsylvania Railroad, banking, and investments.

Name: JOHN T. BAILEY (of John T. Bailey & Co.).
Description: Made in the manufacture of ropes, bags and twine.

Name: CHARLES BAEDER (of Baeder, Adamson & Co.).
Description: Manufacture of glue, curled hair, sand paper, etc.; and investments.

Name: CONYERS BUTTON.
Description: Inherited. Made in the manufacture of knit goods and hosiery.

Name: ALEXANDER BROWN.
Description: Banking and investments. In the firm Brown Bros., having branches in New York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore.

Name: EDWIN N. BENSON (of Benson & Townsend).
Description: Private banking, stocks and investments.

Name: MRS. ALFRED G. BAKER.
Description: From her father, George Fales. Made in dry goods commission business and insurance.

Name: CHARLES F. BERWIND.
Description: Coal mines and railroads.

Name: MRS. JULIA BRADFORD.
Description: From her husband, first president of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad. She is the owner of a large fortune.

Name: MRS. MATTHEW BAIRD.
Description: From her husband, a locomotive builder.

Name: WILLIAM S. BOYD.
Description: Made a fortune in the grocery business.

Name: JOHN H. BROMLEY (of John Bromley & Sons, carpet manufacturers, and the Bromley Manufacturing Company, upholstery goods).
Description: Has made a fortune in manufacturing.

Name: JOSEPH H. BROMLEY.
Description: Manufacturing curtains and carpets in John Bromley & Sons and the Bromley Manufacturing Company.

Name: BARONESS VON BILDT (Sweden).
Description: From her father, J. Bloomfield Moore. Made in manufacturing.

Name: LOUIS BERGDOLL (of the Louis Bergdoll Brewing Company).
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: DANIEL BAUGH.
Description: Originally in tanning and leather; then in the manufacture of animal charcoal for sugar refining and kindred products, chemicals and glue.

Name: HENRY BOTTOMLEY.
Description: Made in the manufacture of woollen goods.

Name: WILLIAM B. BEMENT.
Description: Made a fortune of $1,300,000 in tool manufacturing and foundry business. While he has reduced his fortune largely by gifts to his children, he should probably be mentioned here.

Name: COL. JOSEPH M. BENNETT.
Description: Before and during the war, engaged in the wholesale clothing business. He founded the clothing store known as Tower Hall, now owned by another firm. He is the owner of Chestnut Street Opera House and other valuable real estate.

Name: GEORGE W. BLABON.
Description: Manufacturing oil cloths.

Name: GEORGE BURNHAM (of Burnham, Williams & Co.).
Description: Locomotive building.

Name: MRS. ARTHUR BROCK.
Description: From her father, G. Dawson Coleman. Has a part ownership in the famous Cornwall iron-ore hills. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: MRS. HORACE BROCK.
Description: From her father, G. Dawson Coleman. Has a part ownership in the famous Cornwall iron-ore hills. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: JOHN BAIRD.
Description: Marble business and investments.

Name: JOHN A. BROWN, JR.
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: WILLIAM BUCKNELL.
Description: Originally a wood carver and worked with his apron until worth $50,000. Then built gas works under contract in various parts of the country and took part payment in the stock, which rose rapidly in value. Then in brokerage business in Philadelphia, and dealt in securities and made large purchases of unimproved real estate, which afterward became valuable.

Name: A. J. CASSATT.
Description: Made in railroads and the Westinghouse brake. President of the New-York, Philadelphia and Norfolk R. R.

Name: WILLIAM CRAMP (of William Cramp & Sons).
Description: Partly inherited. Made originally in building wooden vessels. Then in building and repairing iron steamships and war vessels, in which the firm have a very large business and a great reputation. Their plant is worth many millions.

Name: CHARLES H. CRAMP (of William Cramp & Sons).
Description: Partially inherited. Made originally in building wooden vessels, then in building and repairing iron steamships and war vessels, in which the firm have a very large business and a great reputation. Their plant is worth many millions.

Name: JAY COOKE.
Description: Banking, negotiation of Government bonds during the war; railroad enterprises, and various investments, including silver mines.

Name: HARRISON K. CANER.
Description: Inherited.

Name: WILLIAM T. CARTER.
Description: Coal mining; iron furnace at Redington, Penn., and investments.

Name: MRS. G. DAWSON COLEMAN.
Description: From her husband. Has an interest in the famous iron ore hills at Cornwall, Penn. (See Cornwall.)

Name: B. DAWSON COLEMAN.
Description: Inherited from G. Dawson Coleman an interest in the Cornwall iron-ore hills large enough to make him a millionaire. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: EDWARD COLEMAN.
Description: Inherited from G. Dawson Coleman an interest in the Cornwall iron-ore hills large enough to make him a millionaire. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: Miss FANNIE COLEMAN.
Description: Inherited from G. Dawson Coleman an interest in the Cornwall iron-ore hills large enough to make her a millionaire. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: Miss ANNIE COLEMAN.
Description: Inherited from G. Dawson Coleman an interest in the Cornwall iron-ore hills large enough to make her a millionaire. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: ROBERT COLEMAN (now living in Paris).
Description: He has a sixth interest in the Cornwall iron-ore hills. (See Cornwall, Penn.)

Name: SAMUEL F. CORLIES.
Description: Partly inherited and increased by judicious investments.

Name: GEORGE CAMPBELL.
Description: Manufacturing yarns.

Name: THEODORE C. CAREY (of Carey Bros.).
Description: Made in the manufacture of wall paper and stationery.

Name: G. M. COATES (of Coates Bros., merchants, and Porter & Coates, booksellers).
Description: Commission wool and bookselling.

Name: LEMUEL COFFIN.
Description: (of Coffin, Altemus & Co.). Made in commission drygoods.

Name: WILLIAM M. COATES (of Coates Bros.).
Description: Commission wool.

Name: ECKLEY B. COXE.
Description: One of the wealthiest citizens of Philadelphia. Partner in Coxe Bros. & Co., owners of coal lands at Hazleton, mining plant, etc. He is in railroads and many other enterprises.

Name: ALEXANDER B. COXE (of Coxe Bros. & Co.).
Description: Coal mines at Hazleton, Penn.

Name: BRINTON COXE (of Coxe Bros. & Co.).
Description: Coal mines at Hazleton, Penn.

Name: Miss COXE (of Coxe Bros. & Co.).
Description: Coal mines at Hazleton, Penn.

Name: GEORGE W. CHILDS.
Description: Publication of “The Public Ledger,” from which he derives a very large income.

Name: CALEB COPE.
Description: Vessel-owning, freighting and investments.

Name: JAMES C. COOPER.
Description: Show and circus business.

Name: JOHN H. CONVERSE (of Burnham, Williams & Co.).
Description: Locomotive building.

Name: CHARLES I. CRAIG.
Description: Manufacturing soap.

Name: ISAAC H. CLOTHIER (of Strawbridge & Clothier).
Description: Wholly in wholesale and retail drygoods.

Name: COFFIN COLKETT.
Description: Made in local city passenger roads.

Name: HUGH CRAIG.
Description: Made in the wholesale liquor and merchandise brokerage business. His warehouse was the first freight depot of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Philadelphia.

Name: CLARENCE H. CLARKE.
Description: Banking and brokerage business. Formerly in the firm of E. H. Clarke & Co., bankers.

Name: RICHARD J. DOBBINS.
Description: Building and real estate. The owner of nearly 300 houses.

Name: ANTHONY J. DREXEL.
Description: Banking, in the firm of Drexel, Morgan & Co., New-York City, and Drexel & Co., Philadelphia. Has large investments and is a very large owner in the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Name: ANTHONY J. DREXEL, JR.
Description: Largely by inheritance. Made in banking with the Drexels.

Name: MISS KATE DREXEL.
Description: Inherited; made in banking. She is now a nun.

Name: THOMAS DOLAN.
Description: Manufacturing cotton and wool, in the firm of Thomas Dolan & Co. Has many other industrial interests.

Name: JOHN DOBSON (of John & James Dobson).
Description: Manufacturing carpets, blankets and woollen cloth.

Name: JAMES DOBSON (of John & James Dobson).
Description: Manufacturing carpets, blankets and woollen cloth.

Name: HAMILTON DISSTON (of Henry Disston & Sons, two concerns).
Description: Manufacturing saws, files and tools in one, and iron and steel in the other. (Keystone Saw, File and Tool Works.)

Name: HORACE C. DISSTON (of Henry Disston & Sons, two concerns).
Description: Manufacturing saws, files and tools in one, and iron and steel in the other. (Keystone Saw, File and Tool Works.)

Name: JAMES DUFFY.
Description: Dealing in logs, speculating in stocks, army contracting, freighting, etc.

Name: THOMAS DRAKE.
Description: Manufacturing and investments.

Name: WILLIAM L. ELKINS.
Description: Oil refining, real estate, contracting, local gas and street-car franchises, and investments. President of the Pennsylvania Globe Gas Light Company and of the Continental Passenger Railway. Vice-President of the Philadelphia Traction Company. Is largely interested in street railroads in New-York City also.

Name: MICHAEL EHERT.
Description: Distillation of the products of coal tar.

Name: CLAYTON FRENCH (of French, Richards & Co.).
Description: Made a large fortune in the wholesale drug business, supplemented by judicious investments in real estate, etc.

Name: MAJOR CHARLES L. FLANAGAN.
Description: Inherited $1,100,000 from a brother in Liverpool. Made in wharves, stevedoring and local steam vessels.

Name: EDWIN H. FITLER (of E. H. Fitler & Co.).
Description: Manufacturing cordage.

Name: WILLIAM M. FARR.
Description: Inheritance and investments.

Name: W. W. FRAZIER.
Description: Made in the Franklin Sugar Refinery of which he is treasurer.

Name: W. M. FULLER.
Description: Exportation of cattle and beef.

Name: JOHN R. FELL (of Pardee & Co.).
Description: Coal and iron mines.

Name: MRS. JOHN R. FELL (born Drexel).
Description: Inherited; made in banking and investments.

Name: ADAM FOREPAUGH.
Description: Buying and selling horses; real estate in Brooklyn and Philadelphia; show business.

Name: CLEMENT A. GRISCOM (of Peter Wright & Sons).
Description: Made in steamship lines to England, and in railroads. President of the International Navigation Company.

Name: W. E. GARRETT.
Description: Manufacture of tobacco and snuff.

Name: HENRY C. GIBSON.
Description: Distilling, and railroad and other investments.

Name: ROBERT GLENDINNING.
Description: Private banking and stocks.

Name: CHARLES H. GRAHAM.
Description: Made in mines.

Name: JOSEPH E. GILLINGHAM.
Description: Principally in real estate investments, but he has other interests. Senior partner in Gillingham, Garrison & Co., Ld., saw mill and lumber. President of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Company.

Name: JOHN GARDINER.
Description: Brewing and investments. President of the Continental Brewing Company. In the firm of John Gardiner & Co., seedsmen. President of the Southwestern National Bank and of the Dime Saving Fund and Trust Company.

Name: DANIEL HADDOCK.
Description: Made a large fortune in mercantile business.

Name: JAMES HOGG.
Description: Manufacturing carpets.

Name: CHARLES J. HARRAH.
Description: Contracting and railroad building in Brazil.

Name: WILLIAM P. HENSZEY (of Burnham, Williams & Co.).
Description: Locomotive building.

Name: MRS. JOSEPH HARRISON.
Description: Inherited. Made in engineering works and concessions, in Russia, in company with Ross Winans.

Name: HENRY J. HOUSTON.
Description: Made in railroads; oil; real estate; transportation, etc.

Name: ADOLPH HELLER.
Description: Millinery business.

Name: ALFRED C. HARRISON.
Description: Made in the Franklin sugar refinery.

Name: WILLIAM W. HARRISON.
Description: Made in the Franklin sugar refinery.

Name: CHARLES C. HARRISON.
Description: Made in the Franklin sugar refinery of which he is president.

Name: MITCHELL HARRISON.
Description: Made in the Franklin sugar refinery.

Name: MRS. J. CAMPBELL HARRIS.
Description: By inheritance from Thomas H. Powers, of Powers & Weightman. Made in manufacturing chemicals.

Name: PETER HEVENER.
Description: Railroad bridge building and guano, etc., in Peru.

Name: WILLIAM H. HORSTMAN.
Description: Manufacture of trimmings.

Name: EDWARD M. HOPKINS.
Description: Brokerage business and stocks.

Name: ISAAC JEANS.
Description: Wholesale groceries, etc.

Name: MRS. DAVID JAYNE.
Description: From her husband, and made in the manufacture of proprietary medicines.

Name: EDWARD C. KNIGHT.
Description: Importation and refining of sugar; and investments in railroad bonds.

Name: WILLIAM H. KEMBLE.
Description: Street railroads and banking.

Name: JOSIAH KISTERBOCK.
Description: Manufacturer of stoves, ranges, etc. He was President of City National Bank.

Name: JOHN D. LANKENAU.
Description: Made a fortune in banking with the Drexels. He has given half a million to the German Hospital.

Name: CHARLES LENNING.
Description: Manufacturing chemicals.

Name: J. BERTRAM LIPPINCOTT (of J. B. Lippincott & Co.).
Description: Publication of copyrighted books and of their magazine; and job printing.

Name: CRAIGE LIPPINCOTT (of J. B. Lippincott & Co.).
Description: Publication of copyrighted books and of their magazine; and job printing.

Name: HENRY C. LEA.
Description: Publishing medical works, copyrighted.

Name: GEORGE T. LEWIS (of George T. Lewis & Sons).
Description: Commission white and red lead.

Name: J. DUNDAS LIPPINCOTT.
Description: Inherited from Joshua Lippincott, who made a fortune in the iron trade.

Name: MRS. JOSHUA LIPPINCOTT.
Description: From her father, James Dundas. Made in the linen trade.

Name: EDWARD LONGSTRETH (formerly of Baldwin Locomotive Works).
Description: Manufacturing locomotives.

Name: MRS. RICHARD HENRY LEE.
Description: From her father, Charlemagne Tower, who made a great fortune in railroads, railroad building and mineral lands.

Name: CHARLES MACALESTER.
Description: Made in brokerage business and stocks.

Name: THOMAS MACKELLAR
Description: President of Mackellar, Smith's & Jordan Co. Made in the type foundry business.

Name: MRS. EDWARD DE V. MORRELL (born Drexel).
Description: Private banking. Inherited from her father, Francis A. Drexel.

Name: ANDREW M. MOORE (of Moore & Sinnott).
Description: Wholesale liquors and distilling. President of the Teutonia Fire Insurance Company.

Name: JAMES S. MASON.
Description: Made in the manufacture of blacking.

Name: C. J. MILNE.
Description: Manufacturing canned goods.

Name: JAMES McMANES.
Description: Local gas companies.

Name: MRS. BLOOMFIELD H. MOORE.
Description: From her husband, a partner in the Jessup & Moore Paper Company. Made in manufacturing paper.

Name: J. BARLOW MOORHEAD.
Description: Railroads and canals, gas companies and iron manufacturing.

Name: WILLIAM MASSEY.
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: JOSEPH J. MARTIN (of Martin, Fuller & Co.).
Description: Exportation of beef and live cattle. Treasurer of the Quaker City Storage and Warehouse Co.

Name: FRANK M’LAUGHLIN.
Description: Publishing “The Philadelphia Times.”

Name: HENRY PRATT McKEAN.
Description: Inherited. Sugar refining and investments.

Name: THOMAS McKEAN.
Description: Inherited. Sugar refining and investments.

Name: THEODORE H. MORRIS.
Description: Iron foundry business (war prices), in the firm of Morris, Wheeler & Co. Also in railroads.

Name: BYRON P. MOULTON (of Reyburn, Hunter & Co.).
Description: Lightning rod business and various local investments.

Name: HENRY NORRIS.
Description: From his father, Richard Norris. Made in locomotive building by the father; added to in investments by the son.

Name: JACOB NAYLOR.
Description: Iron foundry business and investments. President of the Eighth National Bank.

Name: GENERAL ROBERT PATTERSON.
Description: Cotton manufacturing and investments.

Name: WILLIAM F. POTTS.
Description: Iron and tin merchandising.

Name: J. W. PATTERSON.
Description: Made in the manufacture of morocco.

Name: J. SERGEANT PRICE.
Description: Inherited from Eli K. Price, a lawyer. Himself engaged in law practice, and has made money in real estate. Vice-President of the Land Title and Trust Company.

Name: THOMAS POTTER (of Thomas Potter, Sons & Co.).
Description: Manufacture of oilcloths.

Name: JAMES W. PAUL, JR.
Description: Made in banking with the Drexels.

Name: CHARLES T. PARRY (of the former firm of Burnham, Parry, Williams & Co.).
Description: Made in building locomotives.

Name: CALVIN PARDEE.
Description: From his father, Ario Pardee, of Hazleton, Penn., who left a fortune of more than $10,000,000, made in coal and iron mines and lumber.

Name: JOSEPH D. POTTS.
Description: Made in iron manufacturing. President of the Chester Pipe and Tube Company; also of the Enterprise Transit Company.

Name: GEORGE PEPPER.
Description: Left about $3,000,000, which he had inherited and accumulated.

Name: MRS. THOMAS A. REILLY.
Description: From her father, Charlemagne Tower, who made a great fortune in railroad building, railroads, etc.

Name: JACOB E. RIDGWAY.
Description: Street railways, real estates and shipping. President of the Quaker City National Bank.

Name: GEORGE B. ROBERTS.
Description: President of the Pennsylvania Railroad. Made in railroads and real estate. Partly inherited.

Name: FAIRMAN RODGERS.
Description: Inherited. Made in merchandising and the investment of accumulations.

Name: W. S. REYBURN (of Reyburn, Hunter & Co.).
Description: Made in manufacture of lightning rods; real estate; street railroads; gas companies, etc.

Name: PERCIVAL ROBERTS.
Description: Manufacturing bridge and architectural iron in the Pencoyd Iron Works, owned by A. and P. Roberts & Co.

Name: ROBERT W. REYBURN.
Description: Inherited. Improved by investments in real estate; and loans.

Name: JOHN G. READING.
Description: Made a start in retail merchandising at Flemington, N. J. He then went into the lumber business at Williamsport, Penn., and made a large part of his fortune in the purchase and control of large tracts of coal and timber lands. He had a controlling interest in the log boom and gas works at Williamsport and was also in the Beach Creek Railroad.

Name: CHARLES H. ROGERS.
Description: Banking. He owned the Tradesman’s National Bank.

Name: WILLIAM M. SINGERLY.
Description: Publication of “The Philadelphia Record;” added to, to some extent, by manufacturing newspaper for himself and selling the surplus product of his mill to the Government and other buyers. President of the Chestnut Street National Bank and of the Chestnut Street Trust Company and Saving Fund Company.

Name: HENRY V. SHARPLESS.
Description: Wholesale and retail drygoods.

Name: MRS. THOMAS A. SCOTT.
Description: From her husband, the famous President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, who built up that system and left a fortune of over $10,000,000.

Name: JAMES P. SCOTT.
Description: Largely from Thomas A. Scott, his father. He has added to his fortune by his own enterprise, and has large interests in Florida.

Name: JUSTUS C. STRAWBRIDGE (of Strawbridge & Clothier).
Description: Wholesale and retail drygoods.

Name: SETH B. STITT (of Seth B. Stitt & Co.).
Description: Manufacturing woollen goods.

Name: MRS. JAMES C. SMITH (born Drexel).
Description: Private banking.

Name: WILLIAM SELLERS.
Description: Foundry business and making machinists’ tools.

Name: JAMES SIMPSON (of William Simpson & Sons).
Description: Manufacturing cotton goods. President of the Eddy-stone Manufacturing Company.

Name: WILLIAM L. SCHAFFER.
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: JOHN B. STETSON.
Description: Has made a fortune in manufacturing. President of the John B. Stetson Company, hat manufacturers, and interested in Erben, Search & Co., yarns.

Name: CHARLES SMITH (of Charles Smith & Sons).
Description: Banking and brokerage business.

Name: WILLIAM SIMPSON (of William Simpson & Sons).
Description: Manufacturing cotton goods.

Name: JOSEPH F. SINNOTT (of Moore & Sinnott).
Description: Distilling and wholesale liquors.

Name: EDWARD T. STOTESBURY.
Description: Private banking with Drexel, Morgan & Co.

Name: J. WESLEY SUPPLEE.
Description: Flour milling and banking. President of the Corn Exchange and National Banks.

Name: MRS. CHARLEMAGNE TOWER.
Description: From her husband, Charlemagne Tower, a man of great energy and enterprise, who made a fortune of about $10,000,000 in law, railroads and the purchase of coal and mineral lands.

Name: CHARLEMAGNE TOWER, JR.
Description: From his father Charlemagne Tower. Made as above described.

Name: MISS HENRIETTA PAGE TOWER.
Description: From her father, Charlemagne Tower. See above.

Name: MRS. JOSEPH E. THROPP.
Description: From her father, Thomas A. Scott. Made in the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Name: GEORGE C. THOMAS.
Description: Private banking with the Drexels.

Name: GEORGE F. TYLER.
Description: Mining and selling coal.

Name: FRANK THOMSON.
Description: Made in railroads, real estate investments, etc.

Name: JOSEPH B. TOWNSEND.
Description: Law and investments.

Name: JOHN WANAMAKER (Postmaster General of the United States).
Description: Has made a large fortune in his great dry goods store.

Name: ISAIAH V. WILLIAMSON.
Description: Merchandising dry goods first, followed by investments in railroads, coal and iron lands and factories. He left a fortune of several millions.

Name: PETER A. B. WIDENER.
Description: Oil refining, real estate, gas and street car franchises, etc. President of the Philadelphia Traction Company, and has large investments in street railroads in New-York city.

Name: ISAAC S. WATERMAN.
Description: Wholesale groceries and operations in iron and coal.

Name: JOSEPH WHARTON.
Description: Nickel mining, manufacturing zinc and glass, and investments.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM P. WILSTACK.
Description: From her husband. Made in saddlery and hardware.

Name: WILLIAM WEIGHTMAN (of Powers & Weightman).
Description: Made a great fortune in the manufacture of chemicals. Considered by many the richest man in Philadelphia.

Name: C. B. WRIGHT.
Description: Made in the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad, and Northern Pacific Railroad. President of the Tacoma Land Company.

Name: WILLIAM G. WARDEN.
Description: Has made a fortune in refining petroleum oil. President of the Atlantic Refining Company, which is identical with the Standard Oil Company. President also of the Spring Garden Insurance Company.

Name: JOHN S. WOOD (of John S. Wood & Sons, hides, and Wood Bro’s & Co., wool).
Description: Dealing in hides and wool.

Name: THEODORE WERNWAG.
Description: Made in importing and dry-goods commission business, and investments in real estate.

Name: WILLIAM WOOD.
Description: Manufacturing cotton and woollen goods, and investments. President of the Merchants’ National Bank.

Name: JOHN L’CUBER WELSH.
Description: Inherited from S. & J. Welsh. Banking, trade in sugar, and investments.

Name: ANDREW WHEELER.
Description: Made in the iron foundry business (war prices). President of Morris, Tasker & Co.

Name: MRS. CHARLES WHEELER.
Description: Iron foundry business (war prices).

Name: JOHN WYETH (of John Wyeth & Co.).
Description: Wholesale and retail drug business.

Name: EDWARD H. WILLIAMS (of Burnham, Williams & Co.).
Description: Locomotive building.

Name: JAMES A. WRIGHT (of Peter Wright & Sons).
Description: Deep sea steam shipping and ocean freighting.

Name: RICHARD D. WOOD (of R. D. Wood & Co., and Wood, Brown & Co.).
Description: Iron foundry business in one concern, and wholesale cotton goods in the other. Real estate also.

Name: MRS. EDWARD S. WILLING.
Description: From her father, the late Dr. John Rhea Barton. The fortune of Dr. Barton was founded in the Revolutionary period by merchandising and purchases of real estate, and had been added to since by accumulations and investments.

Name: HENRY B. WELSH.
Description: Made in the Pennsylvania Railroad and various investments.

Name: JOHN WRIGHT (of Wright Bros. & Co.).
Description: Manufacture of umbrellas, parasols and canes, and real estate and other investments. The firm are all good financiers and interested in banks, etc.

Name: CHRISTIAN H. WOLFE.
Description: Hardware business.

Name: CHARLES ARBUTHNOT (of Arbuthnot, Stephenson & Co.).
Description: Acquired in wholesale drygoods.

Name: ALEXANDER BRADLEY.
Description: Manufacturing stoves, and investments. President of the Tradesmen’s National Bank.

Name: MRS. BREERTON.
Description: Inherited from the O’Hara estate. Made in real estate which has come down through four generations.

Name: HARRY BROWN.
Description: River steamboats and mining and shipping coal, etc.

Name: JOSEPH CRAIG.
Description: Made in petroleum.

Name: CHARLES J. CLARKE.
Description: Inherited a small part of his fortune 25 years ago, and has added several millions to it by investments in railroad securities and real estate.

Name: MRS. THOMAS M. CARNEGIE.
Description: From her late husband, who accumulated a fortune in manufacturing iron and steel, and in railroad operations.

Name: WILLIAM CARN.
Description: Manufacturing and real estate.

Name: JAMES CALLERY.
Description: Tanning and leather, and investments in railroads, etc.

Name: CHARLES DONNELLY.
Description: Coke manufacturing, in the McClure Coke Co.

Name: MRS. O’HARA DENNY.
Description: From the O’Hara estate. Made in real estate which has come down through four generations and advanced greatly in value.

Name: H. D. DENNY.
Description: From the O’Hara estate. Made in real estate which has come down through four generations and advanced greatly in value.

Name: MISS MATILDA DENNY.
Description: From the O’Hara estate which has come down through four generations, and advanced greatly in value.

Name: H. C. FRICK (of the H. C. Frick Coke Company).
Description: Coke making, which has brought him a very large fortune. He is a partner of Andrew Carnegie.

Name: WILLIAM FLINN.
Description: Contracting and building.

Name: J. M. GUFFY.
Description: Made a fortune in petroleum.

Name: MRS. J. M. GUSKY.
Description: The sale of clothing.

Name: E. M. HUKILL.
Description: Petroleum oil.

Name: SEWARD HAYS.
Description: Inherited a fortune made in coal mining.

Name: MRS. THOMAS M. HOWE.
Description: From her husband, of Howe, Brown & Co., manufacturers of steel. Was also in copper mining.

Name: DR. C. G. HUSSEY.
Description: The richest copper man in the United States. His fortune was made in the copper mines at Lake Superior.

Name: II. A. LAUGHLIN (Laughlin & Co.).
Description: Iron and steel manufacturing.

Name: GEORGE M. LAUGHLIN (Laughlin & Co.).
Description: Iron and steel manufacturing.

Name: CHARLES LOCKHART (of Lockhart & Frew, oil; and Hubbard & Co., saw manufacturers).
