Description: Petroleum oil and refining; and manufacturing saws, shovels, axes, etc.

Name: CHRIS. L. MAGEE.
Description: Newspaper, and traction roads.

Name: JUDGE THOMAS MELLON.
Description: Real estate, banking, coal lands, and money investments.

Name: THOMAS A. MELLON.
Description: Son of Judge Mellon. By his own efforts he has made more than a million in real estate, railroads, coal, lumber and buildings.

Name: JAMES R. MELLON.
Description: Railroads, coal, lumber, buildings, and dealing in real estate. Also a son of Judge Mellon. Mainly in real estate.

Name: ANDREW W. MELLON.
Description: Another member of this remarkable and able family. Son of Judge Mellon. He has made his own fortune in real estate, banking and lumber.

Name: R. B. MELLON.
Description: Son of Judge Mellon. Like his brothers, he has accumulated wealth by his own efforts in real estate, banking and railroad investments.

Name: W. L. MELLON.
Description: A son of James R. Mellon. Has made a fortune in oil pipe-lines, real estate and loans.

Name: MICHAEL M’CULLOUGH.
Description: Manufacturing steel-melting crucibles, and investments in real estate, etc.

Name: MRS. ROBERT M’KNIGHT.
Description: Inherited from the O’Hara estate. Made in rise in value of real estate.

Name: ROBERT PITCAIRN.
Description: Railroads and investments.

Name: GILBERT T. RAFFERTY.
Description: Coke-making in the McClure Coke Company.

Name: D. P. REIGHARD.
Description: Petroleum and investments. President of the Central Bank.

Name: MRS. MARY E. SCHENLEY.
Description: Inherited from her father, Captain William Croghan, real estate which is now immensely valuable, estimated, in fact, to be worth more than $15,000,000. She lives at present in London, England.

Name: COLONEL J. M. SCHOONMAKER.
Description: Coke-making. He sold his interests to H. C. Frick & Co., in return for the payment of $100,000 a year for fourteen years.

Name: MRS. MARY SPRING.
Description: Inherited from the O’Hara estate. Made in rise in value of real estate, which has come down through four generations.

Name: WILLIAM THAW.
Description: This enterprising man made a great fortune in the Union Transportation line, the Pennsylvania Railroad, and leased lines west of Pittsburg. He left an estate of $8,000,000 to $10,000,000; estimated by some even higher than that. It was divided among the members of a large family, none of whom, except Mrs. Thaw, received a million.

Name: J. J. VANDERGRIFT.
Description: Petroleum and investments. President of the Keystone Bank.

Name: GEORGE W. WESTINGHOUSE, Jr.
Description: Made in the manufacture of the Westinghouse patented airbrakes.

Name: W. DEWEES WOOD.
Description: Manufacturing sheetiron.

Name: CALVIN WELLS.
Description: Iron manufacturing; Westinghouse airbrake; and “The Philadelphia Press,” newspaper.

Name: CHARLES BABER.
Description: Gas and water works, street railroads, and other local enterprises.

Name: THOMAS GOOCH.
Description: Iron furnaces and powder manufacturing.

Name: HENRY S. ECKERT.
Description: Iron making (the Henry Clay furnace) and banking. He is president of the Farmers’ National Bank.

Name: J. K. P. HALL (of Hall, Kaul & Co.).
Description: The largest part of his fortune is from lumber. Also in tanneries, bituminous coal mines and banking.

Name: ANDREW KAUL (of Hall, Kaul & Co.).
Description: Made in the same line of business as his partner.

Name: W. J. RAINEY.
Description: Coke making.

Name: WILLIAM CONNELL.
Description: Coal operations, banking and grocery business. President of the Third National Bank.

Name: JOHN JERMYN.
Description: Coal operations.

Name: JAMES BLAIR.
Description: Railroads, banking, and investments. President of Scranton Savings Bank.

Name: CHRISTIAN LONG.
Description: He left several millions.

Name: ELISHA P. STRONG.
Description: By inheritance from Loring A. Robertson, of New-York City. Made in tanning and leather.

Name: J. L. GRANDIN (of Grandin Brothers, bankers).
Description: In early days in petroleum; then in loans, banking, large wheat farms on the Red River and at Mayville, N. D., and investments; in the Missouri Lumber and Mining Company and stocks and bonds.

Name: E. B. GRANDIN (of Grandin Brothers, bankers).
Description: In the same business as above set forth.

Name: W. J. GRANDIN.
Description: In the same business as above.

Name: CHARLES HYDE.
Description: Banking. In the firm of Charles Hyde & Son, bankers, and president of the Second National Bank.

Name: COLONEL JOHN J. CARTER.
Description: Oil producing in the Bradford field; large real estate investments, including the local opera house; banking and other interests.

Name: E. T. ROBERTS.
Description: Inherited from Dr. W. B. Roberts. Torpedoing oil wells; oil producing, banking, etc.

Name: JOSEPH SEEP.
Description: Oil producing, refining and transportation. Director in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: JOHN FERTIG.
Description: Oil producing and refining, and investments. President of the National Oil Company.

Name: JOHN McKEOWN.
Description: Oil producing and lands, and real estate in Boston, New-York, Baltimore, Washington and Chicago.

Name: HENRY COCHRAN.
Description: Private banking in the firm of Cochran, Payne & McCormack; and lumber producing.

Name: E. R. PAYNE.
Description: In the lumber business.

Name: GEORGE W. LENTZ (of White, Lentz & White).
Description: Lumber business.

Name: JAMES V. BROWN.
Description: Manufacturing lumber at Mehoopany.

Name: L. MYERS.
Description: By inheritance of coal lands and their advance in price.

Name: ABRAM NESBITT.
Description: Inherited. Anthracite coal lands. President of the Second National Bank.

Name: WILLIAM L. CONYNGHAM.
Description: Made as coal sales agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Name: JOHN WELLES HOLLENBACK.
Description: Real estate and inherited coal lands. President People’s Bank.

Name: HON. L. D. SHOEMAKER.
Description: Inherited coal lands.

Name: DANIEL EDWARDS.
Description: Made in mining coal.

Name: GEORGE S. BENNETT.
Description: Coal mines and real estate.

Name: JOHN B. PHELPS.
Description: Coal mining and real estate.

Name: DAVID E. SMALL.
Description: Lumber dealing; car building; and investments in the Pennsylvania, the Denver and Rio Grande and other railroads.

Name: ARTEMUS WILHELM.
Description: Started in building furnaces for the Coleman estate at Cornwall. In time became manager of the estate, and then made investments in rolling mills, nail mills, etc.

Name: GEORGE R. FEARING.
Description: Inherited from Daniel B. Fearing, of New-York City, who made a fortune in mercantile business and large investments in real estate.

Name: MRS. GEORGE R. FEARING.
Description: From her father, William R. Travers, who made a large fortune in Wall Street.

Name: DANIEL B. FEARING.
Description: From his father, Daniel B. Fearing, of New-York City. Made in mercantile business and real estate.

Name: H. F. FEARING.
Description: Made chiefly in real estate in New-York City.

Name: CHRISTOPHER TOWNSEND.
Description: Made in business in New-York City.

Name: HENRY S. FEARING.
Description: Large real estate interests in Newport.

Name: GEORGE H. NORMAN.
Description: Contracting, building water works and investments.

Name: MRS. EDWARD KING.
Description: Inherited. Made in the China trade, in tea and silk especially.

Name: GEORGE PEABODY WETMORE.
Description: Inherited several millions from his father, W. S. Wetmore. Made originally in the China trade and added to by investments.

Name: WILLIAM GAMMELL.
Description: From Brown & Ives. Made in the East India trade in early times, and cotton manufacturing since.

Name: Mrs. WILLIAM GAMMELL.
Description: From her father, Robert Ives, of Brown & Ives. Made in the East India trade in early times, and in real estate and manufacturing investments at a later period. Robert Ives left a fortune of over $20,000,000.

Name: Mrs. JOHN CARTER BROWN.
Description: Inherited from the firm of Brown & Ives. Made in the East India trade, and subsequent investment in real estate and manufactures. John Carter Brown left more than $20,000,000.

Name: ALFRED SMITH.
Description: Made in dealing in real estate, chiefly at Newport.

Name: LORILLARD SPENCER.
Description: Inherited. Made in tobacco manufacturing and real estate. He has numerous investments; and is president of the Illustrated American Publishing Company.

Name: SETH BATEMAN.
Description: Banking.

Name: ALBERT L. SAYLES.
Description: Manufacturing woollen goods. Interested in A. A. L. Sayles & Co. and F. L. Sayles & Co., both cotton manufacturers.

Name: DAVID GOFF (of D. Goff & Sons).
Description: Made first in the manufacture of cotton wadding, the company making a great deal of money during the war. In 1861 they started the manufacture of worsted braid, which would have been a failure except for the tariff of 1867. Ten years ago they added the making of mohair plushes. The tariff had nothing to do with the foundation of this fortune.

Name: WILLIAM F. SAYLES (of W. F. and F. C. Sayles).
Description: Bleaching and dyeing; and banking. President of the Slater National Bank.

Name: F. C. SAYLES.
Description: Bleaching and dyeing, in partnership with William F. Sayles.

Name: ROWLAND G. HAZARD.
Description: Made over two millions in the manufacture of woollen goods and shawls; and investments in real estate, railroads, etc.

Name: LAURISTON HALL.
Description: Partly made in manufacturing in Providence, but largely in lands in Minnesota.

Name: GEORGE H. CORLISS.
Description: Manufacturing the famous Corliss steam engine; patents.

Name: WILLIAM GODDARD.
Description: Fortune founded in the East India trade with Brown & Ives; increased latterly in cotton manufacturing and various investments. President of the Providence National Bank and the Providence Institution for Savings. The Goddard Brothers are agents of the Lonsdale Company.

Name: T. P. I. GODDARD.
Description: Fortune founded by Brown & Ives in the East India trade, and increased by cotton manufacturing and investments. The Goddard Brothers are agents of the Lonsdale Company.

Name: ROBERT GODDARD.
Description: Fortune forwarded by Brown & Ives in the East India trade, and increased by cotton manufacturing and investments. The Goddard Brothers are agents of the Lonsdale Company.

Name: J. B. BARNABY.
Description: Made in the sale of clothing.

Name: J. NICHOLAS BROWN.
Description: Fortune founded by Brown & Ives in the East India trade, and increased latterly by cotton manufacturing.

Name: R. H. GAMMELL.
Description: Fortune founded by Brown & Ives in the East India trade, and increased latterly by cotton manufacturing.

Name: HAROLD BROWN.
Description: Fortune founded by Brown & Ives in the East India trade, and increased latterly by cotton manufacturing.

Name: BENJAMIN B. KNIGHT (of B. B. & R. Knight).
Description: Manufacture and bleaching of cotton goods. President of Butchers and Drovers’ Bank.

Name: ROBERT KNIGHT (of B. B. & R. Knight).
Description: Cotton manufacturing and bleaching, etc. President of National Bank of Commerce and the People’s Savings Bank.

Name: HENRY LIPPITT (of Henry Lippitt & Co.).
Description: Manufacturing cotton and woollen goods. President of Rhode Island National Bank.

Name: HENRY G. RUSSELL.
Description: Made in shipping and manufacturing, etc. President of the Union Bank.

Name: JOHN W. SLATER.
Description: Manufacturing cotton and woollen goods.

Name: JOSEPH BANIGAN.
Description: Manufacturing rubber goods.

Name: AMOS C. BARSTOW.
Description: Stove, furnace and general iron manufacturing. President of the City National Bank.

Name: CYRUS BUTLER.
Description: Real estate and banking.

Name: EDMUND DAVIS.
Description: Manufacturing “Pain Killer” and other proprietary medicines.

Name: CHARLES FLETCHER.
Description: Manufacturing woollen goods.

Name: DR. WILLIAM GROSVENOR.
Description: Manufacturing cotton goods.

Name: EDWARD HAIM.
Description: Woollen manufacturing.

Name: HENRY S. HIDDEN.
Description: Cotton cloth dealings and banking.

Name: JESSE METCALF.
Description: Woollen manufacturing. President of the National Bank of North America.

Name: HENRY J. STEERE.
Description: Manufacturing woollens; banks, horse railroads, etc. Had an interest in the American Screw Company, which conducted an immense business in the manufacture of patented gimlet pointed screws.

Name: MARSHALL WOODS.
Description: Real estate and banking.

Name: EDWARD HARRIS.
Description: Made several millions in the manufacture of woollen cloth for men’s clothing. The Harris cloths were famous; and he had the largest woollen factory in the United States.

Name: JAMES S. CALHOUN.
Description: Largest land owner in the State. He had 190,000 acres in all, having spent his life in accumulating land.

Name: F. J. PELZER (of Pelzer, Rodgers & Co.).
Description: In the cotton factor and commission business and private banking chiefly. Has investments in fertilizer companies and cotton mills.

Name: F. S. RODGERS (of Pelzer, Rodgers & Co.).
Description: In the cotton factor and commission business and private banking chiefly. Has investments in fertilizer companies and cotton mills.

Name: WILLIAM B. SMITH.
Description: The richest man in Charleston, and indeed in the State. He died recently, leaving about $3,000,000. Made as a cotton factor and in banking.

Name: GEORGE W. WILLIAMS.
Description: Banking. President of the Carolina Savings Bank.

Name: DR. ANDREW SIMONDS.
Description: Banking and merchandising. Was president of the First National Bank.

Name: T. W. WAGENER.
Description: In cotton factorage, and wholesale groceries and liquors.

Name: GEORGE M. MILLER.
Description: Drygoods, and banks in New-York City, etc.

Name: COLONEL GEORGE A. WASHINGTON.
Description: One-half by inheritance from his father, and the rest by purchase and sale of gold and stocks after the war.

Name: SAMUEL L. GRAHAM.
Description: Warehousing, flour milling and general merchandising.

Name: EDWARD J. SANFORD.
Description: Merchandising first, then in Southern railroads. He is largely interested in all the enterprises about Knoxville, and is president of the Knoxville and Ohio Railroad.

Name: JOHN T. FARGASON.
Description: Wholesale groceries and cotton factorage business.

Name: J. C. NEELEY (of Brooks, Neeley & Co.).
Description: Wholesale groceries and cotton factorage business.

Name: D. P. PORTER (of Porter, Porter & Macrae).
Description: Wholesale groceries, banking and cotton factorage business.

Name: ANDREW GWYNNE (of Stewart, Gwynne & Co.).
Description: Wholesale groceries and cotton factorage business.

Name: W. D. BETHELL.
Description: Made in inherited real estate and investments.

Name: NAPOLEON HILL (of Hill, Fontaine & Co.).
Description: Wholesale groceries and cotton factorage business.

Name: ENOCH ENSLEY.
Description: Made in iron mines.

Name: JOHN OVERTON.
Description: Inherited real estate which has advanced in value.

Name: THOMAS BARRETT.
Description: Speculation in stocks and cotton futures.

Name: S. M. MURPHY.
Description: Manufacture and sale of whiskey in Cincinnati, Ohio.

Name: COLONEL E. W. COLE.
Description: Deals in railroad shares, having been connected with railroads all his life.

Name: DR. WILLIAM MORROW (of Cherry, Morrow & Co.).
Description: Made in mining and leasing of labor from the Tennessee State prisons.

Name: MAJOR GEORGE W. LITTLEFIELD.
Description: First in law practice; then in merchandising; and finally in cattle raising, in which he made the bulk of his fortune. President of the American National Bank.

Name: COLONEL L. A. ELLIS.
Description: Made in sugar and cotton plantations, and leasing labor from the State penitentiaries.

Name: THOMAS C. BEAN.
Description: Land, and stock raising. He had between 80,000 and 100,000 acres of land.

Name: R. E. STAFFORD.
Description: Private banking; stock raising; and lands.

Name: MRS. S. H. COCKRELL.
Description: Rise in the value of real estate, which was bought when Dallas was a hamlet. She is the largest taxpayer in the city.

Name: JAMES C. O’CONNOR.
Description: Cattle raising; banking; large investments in real estate; and local gas company. President of the City National Bank.

Name: WILLIAM H. GASTON.
Description: Banking and real estate. He was an early settler, and his real estate has increased in value with the growth of the city.

Name: JOHN A. SIMPSON.
Description: Cattle raising and banking.

Name: T. L. MARSALIS.
Description: Real estate and wholesale groceries. He is the founder of Oak Cliff.

Name: C. C. SLAUGHTER.
Description: Cattle raising and banking.

Name: J. B. WILSON.
Description: Cattle raising and banking.

Name: W. E. HUGHES.
Description: He is a lawyer; but has made his fortune in cattle raising, ranches and real estate.

Name: ALEXANDER SANGER (of Sanger Brothers).
Description: Wholesale and retail drygoods.

Name: PHILIP SANGER (of Sanger Brothers).
Description: Wholesale and retail drygoods.

Name: W. B. MUNSON.
Description: Made in the purchase of Texas and other Western lands; and railroad development.

Name: JOHN R. HOXIE.
Description: Made in banking and cattle raising largely. Has investments amounting to several millions in Chicago cable railroads; and in lands, cattle, local electric light and gas companies, and banking. President of the Farmers and Mechanics’ National Bank.

Name: ROBERT E. MADDOX.
Description: Trading in mules first; then real estate, stockfarms, etc.

Name: MRS. SALLIE HUFFMAN.
Description: Inherited from her husband, Walter A. Huffman, and from her brother. Made in real estate, street railroads and stocks. She owns “The Fort Worth Gazette,” and has remarkable business talent, devoting her time ably to her business interests.

Name: JAMES LEE, JR.
Description: Steamboats and real estate (largely inherited).

Name: CHARLESTON
Description: MRS. R. R. SNOWDEN.
column5: Inherited real estate, including a hotel.

Name: R. S. WILLIS.
Description: Made in the cotton factorage business. Also in drygoods, groceries, etc., and banking. President of the Texas Banking and Insurance Company.

Name: LEON BLUM.
Description: Importing and dealing in drygoods; cotton, and real estate.

Name: SYLVAIN BLUM.
Description: Made in mercantile business and investments.

Name: J. H. HUTCHINGS (of Ball, Hutchings & Co.).
Description: Cotton speculation during the war; banking, and real estate.

Name: MRS. GEORGE BALL.
Description: Inherited from Ball, Hutchings & Co. Cotton speculation during the war; real estate, and banking.

Name: H. KEMPNER.
Description: Cotton and commission business, and investments. President of the Island City Savings Bank.

Name: J. HENRY ROSENBERG.
Description: Private banking, drygoods and real estate.

Name: J. M. BURROUGHS.
Description: Law practice, and speculation in wharf stock and United States bonds.

Name: JAMES M. BROWN.
Description: Made in the sale of hardware.

Name: JOHN CHARLES LEAGUE.
Description: Merchandising, etc.

Name: J. L. DARRAGH.
Description: Speculation in wharf stock and real estate.

Name: MRS. J. L. DARRAGH.
Description: Real estate and banking.

Name: WALTER GRESHAM.
Description: Speculation in real estate and railroads.

Name: MRS. JOHN SEALY.
Description: Inherited from Ball, Hutchings & Co. Made in cotton speculation during the war; real estate and banking.

Name: MRS. ISADORE DYER.
Description: Real estate and banking.

Name: MRS. ISABELLA RAPPEL.
Description: Real estate and banking.

Name: W. MOODY (of W. L. Moody & Co.).
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: GEORGE SEALY.
Description: Made in banking in the firm of Ball, Hutchings & Co.

Name: T. W. HOUSE.
Description: Private banking, speculation in cotton, etc.

Name: B. A. SHEPHERD.
Description: Merchandising and banking. President of the First National Bank.

Name: H. B. SANBORN.
Description: Merchandising, cattle-raising and real estate.

Name: GEORGE W. MORTON.
Description: Large ranches and cattle business.

Name: GEORGE W. BRACKENRIDGE.
Description: Richest man in San Antonio. Has made several millions in cotton speculation, real estate and banking. Owns the local waterworks. President of the San Antonio National Bank.

Name: H. D. ADAMS.
Description: Made in army contracts for transportation during the war; and real estate.

Name: E. D. L. WICKES.
Description: Army sutler during the war, and real estate.

Name: RICHARD WOOLLEY, JR.
Description: Merchandising.

Name: MRS. ELEANOR STRIBLING.
Description: Inherited. Made in merchandising and real estate.

Name: HERMAN D. KAMPMANN.
Description: Inherited from his father, who was a contractor and had a sash and blind factory.

Name: SAMUEL MAVERICK.
Description: Banking and real estate. President of Maverick Bank and Safe Deposit Company.

Name: ALBERT MAVERICK.
Description: Real estate.

Name: WILLIAM MAVERICK.
Description: Made in rise in real estate.

Name: JAY E. ADAMS.
Description: Real-estate investments.

Name: MRS. E. H. TERRILL.
Description: Inherited from the Mavericks. Made in real estate.

Name: MRS. KING.
Description: The “cattle queen of Texas.” From her husband, who had one of the largest cattle ranches in Texas.

Name: M. KENNEDY.
Description: Steamboats on the Rio Grande.

Name: DR. F. HERFF, Sr.
Description: Inheritance and local real estate.

Name: N. G. COLLINS.
Description: Made in cattle-raising chiefly.

Name: F. K. RIDDER.
Description: Stock-raising.

Name: WILLIAM CAMERON.
Description: Mostly made in the retail lumber business, and rebates from railroads. Increased by investments.

Name: D. H. PEERY.
Description: Milling, manufacturing and banking. President of the First National Bank and the Ogden Savings Bank.

Name: DAVID ECCLES.
Description: Sawmills and lumber.

Name: J. C. ARMSTRONG.
Description: Cattle raising, real estate, and banking. President of the Commercial National Bank.

Name: JOHN S. LEWIS.
Description: Made in the jewelry business and real estate.

Name: W. G. CHILD.
Description: General contracting and real estate.

Name: BARNARD WHITE.
Description: Sawmills and lumber, and merchandising.

Name: WARREN W. COREY.
Description: Railroad contracting, and investments. President of the Citizens’ Bank.

Name: FREDERICK J. KIESEL.
Description: Wholesale groceries and liquors and real estate.

Name: BRIGHAM YOUNG.
Description: Made by the apostle of the Mormons, largely, in real estate.

Name: R. C. CHAMBERS.
Description: Mines of precious metals.

Name: L. E. HOLDEN.
Description: Mines of precious metals.

Name: JOSEPH R. WALKER.
Description: Merchandising, mining and banking. President of the Union National Bank.

Name: JOHN SHARP.
Description: Railroads and banking. President of the Deseret National Bank, and the Deseret Savings Bank.

Name: W. S. McCORMICK.
Description: Private banking and cattle raising.

Name: MATTHEW H. WALKER.
Description: Merchandising and banking.

Name: JOHN C. PACKARD.
Description: Made in mining.

Name: JULIUS J. ESTEY (Estey Organ Co.).
Description: Manufacturing cabinet organs; real estate, and investments. President of the People’s National Bank. Director in the Estey Piano Company.

Name: LEVI K. FULLER (Estey Organ Co.).
Description: Manufacturing cabinet organs. Director in the Estey Piano Company.

Name: J. R. BOOTH.
Description: Sawmills and lumber.

Name: SUMNER S. THOMPSON.
Description: Railroads in Canada and the West.

Name: JAMES R. LANGDON.
Description: Flour milling first; then railroads, a slate quarry at Fairhaven, and banking. President of the Montpelier National Bank.

Name: HUGH H. BAXTER.
Description: Inherited from his father, General H. H. Baxter, of New-York City. Made in railroad building and stocks.

Name: CHARLES CLEMENT.
Description: Marble quarrying and railroads. President of the Clement National Bank and of the Rutland Trust Company.

Name: P. W. CLEMENT.
Description: Marble quarrying, railroads and banking.

Name: JOHN W. CRAMTON.
Description: Investments of many kinds. Is president of the Baxter National Bank and part owner in a hotel, a grocery store and a stove and tinware store.

Name: JOHN GREGORY SMITH.
Description: Made in railroads. President of the Vermont Central nearly forty years. Also president of the Welden National Bank.

Name: COLONEL FRANKLIN FAIRBANKS (of E. & T. Fairbanks & Co.).
Description: Made in the manufacture of patented scales. President of the First National Bank.

Name: HENRY FAIRBANKS (of concern above named).
Description: Manufacturing scales.

Name: of FREDERICK BILLINGS (estimated at over $5,000,000).
Description: Law practice in California with General Halleck and Trenor W. Park; then in Mariposa Mine, and then in Northern Pacific and other railroads. He was president of the Woodstock National Bank.

Name: HARMON NEWBERRY.
Description: Tobacco growing and speculation.

Name: S. A. HANCOCK.
Description: Manufacturing and real estate.

Name: ROBERT C. SELDEN.
Description: Real estate chiefly.

Name: JOHN D. LANGHORNE.
Description: Tobacco growing and speculation.

Name: RICHARD DICKERSON.
Description: Real estate and other investments.

Name: WILLIAM CAMERON.
Description: Tobacco manufacturing and exporting.

Name: THOMAS M. LOGAN.
Description: Law, and building, and management of railroads. Is an officer in many Southern roads.

Name: JAMES H. DOOLEY.
Description: Law, and building, and management of railroads. Is an officer in many Southern roads.

Name: LEWIS GINTER (of Allen & Ginter).
Description: The richest man in Richmond. Has made several millions in the manufacture of cigarettes.

Name: JOHN C. SHAFER.
Description: Merchant tailor and real estate.

Name: EDWARD T. CANNON.
Description: Real estate and law.

Name: FREDERICK R. SCOTT.
Description: Dealing in grain; banking and stock speculation. He is president of the Richmond and Petersburg Railroad.

Name: JOSEPH R. ANDERSON.
Description: Iron manufacturing. He is president of the Tredegar Iron Works.

Name: JAMES THOMAS.
Description: Manufacturing tobacco.

Name: JOHN STEWART.
Description: Speculations in cotton and leaf tobacco.

Name: DANIEL K. STEWART.
Description: Speculations in cotton and leaf tobacco.

Name: JAMES B. PACE.
Description: Made in the manufacture of plug tobacco mainly, added to by speculation in railroad stocks and by banking. President of the Planters’ National Bank.

Name: CHARLES E. WHITLOCK.
Description: Manufacturing tobacco boxes and dealing in sycamore lumber.

Name: JOHN P. BRANCH.
Description: Dealing in grain, speculation in stocks, and banking. President of the Merchants’ National Bank.

Name: P. H. MAYO (President of P. H. Mayo & Brother).
Description: Made in manufacturing plug tobacco.

Name: WILLIAM GRAY.
Description: Dealing in tobacco.

Name: D. M. LEA.
Description: Manufacturing tobacco boxes.

Name: PEYTON L. TERRY.
Description: Tobacco grower and speculator. President of Roanoke Trust, Loan and Safe Deposit Company.

Name: ARTHUR A. DENNY.
Description: Richest man in the State. One of Seattle’s oldest settlers. His fortune comes from rise in real estate.

Name: D. T. DENNY.
Description: Real estate chiefly. He is an old settler.

Name: WILLIAM REUTON.
Description: Sawmills, fir, timber lands, real estate and vessels.

Name: CYRUS WALKER.
Description: Sawmills and lumber, fir, timber lands and vessels.

Name: H. L. YESLER.
Description: The founder of Seattle. Made in real estate.

Name: BAILEY GATZERT (of Schwabacher & Co.).
Description: Wholesale groceries and hardware. He is the leading merchant of the State. President of the Puget Sound National Bank and the People’s Savings Bank.

Name: W. C. HILL.
Description: Real estate.

Name: WATSON C. SQUIRE.
Description: Made in rise in value of real estate.

Name: MRS. MARY M. MILLER.
Description: The richest woman in the State. Made in rise in value of lands and bank stock.

Name: THOMAS BURKE.
Description: Real estate and railroads.

Name: LEIGH S. J. HUNT.
Description: Real estate, newspaper, street railroads, etc. President of the Guarantee Loan and Trust Company.

Name: JACOB FURTH.
Description: Real estate and bank stock. He is interested in three of the largest banks of the city.

Name: E. J. BRICKELL.
Description: Real estate; local waterworks; Traders’ National Bank; and mines. He left over $650,000 in securities alone.

Name: FRANK R. MOORE.
Description: Silver mining and real estate.

Name: J. J. BROWNE.
Description: Real estate and banking (Browne’s National Bank).

Name: A. M. CANNON.
Description: Real estate, banking and railroads. President of Bank of Spokane Falls, and of Spokane Falls Loan, Trust and Savings Bank.

Name: JAMES N. GLOVER
Description: Real estate and banking. President of the First National Bank.

Name: R.W. FORREST
Description: Made in real estate and banking.

Name: ALLEN C. MASON.
Description: Real estate and kindred investments.

Name: NELSON BENNETT.
Description: Railroads, hotel, real estate, and investments in various enterprises.

Name: WALTER J. THOMPSON.
Description: Real estate and banking. President of the Merchants’ National Bank.

Name: HENRY HEWITT, JR.
Description: Several times a millionaire. His fortune has been made entirely in the wonderful timber lands of that country, of which class of property he is one of the largest owners in the United States.

Name: W. H. FIFE.
Description: Made in the rise in value of real estate in Tacoma. He owns a hotel among other parcels of real estate.

Name: CHESTER THORNE.
Description: Inherited from his father.

Name: CHAUNCEY W. GRIGGS.
Description: Made in real estate, merchandising and banking. President of the St. Paul and Tacoma Lumber Company.

Name: MILES C. MOORE.
Description: Railroads, real estate and banking.

Name: JOHN F. BOYES (of Baker & Boyes).
Description: Banking, railroads, lands, etc.

Name: HON. JOHNSON N. CAMDEN.
Description: Has made a large fortune in oil producing and refining in the Standard Oil Company, but is also extensively interested in West Virginia Railroads, and real estate speculation and banking. President of the First National Bank. He is certainly worth $2,500,000.

Name: HENRY G. DAVIS.
Description: Banking, coal mining, railroads, etc. President of the Bank of Piedmont.

Name: J. NELSON VANCE.
Description: Manufacturing iron and real estate. President of the Exchange Bank.

Name: JOSEPH W. PAXTON.
Description: Wheeling and Chicago real estate.

Name: MICHAEL REILLY.
Description: Wholesale groceries and distilling.

Name: MRS. E. VAUGHN MACKINNON.
Description: Mining and real estate.

Name: THOMAS BARDEN.
Description: Banking and real estate. President of the Ashland National Bank.

Name: CAPTAIN JOHN McKAY.
Description: From the Colby iron mine and sale of ore or royalty.

Name: W. E. McCORD.
Description: Pine lands and sale of logs therefrom.

Name: WILLIAM CARSON (of Carson & Rand, and president of the Valley Lumber Company).
Description: Sawmills and lumber.

Name: HENRY C. PUTNAM.
Description: Pine lands and sale of logs therefrom, and banking. President of the Chippewa Valley Bank.

Name: WILLIAM A. RUST.
Description: Partly by inheritance. The rest in the lumber business, merchandising and banking. President of the Bank of Eau Claire.

Name: ORRIN H. INGRAM.
Description: Sawmills, pine lands and lumber, and banking. President of the Empire Lumber Company and the Eau Claire National Bank.

Name: J. A. SCHONWEILER.
Description: Sawmills, pine lands and lumber. Owner of the Northwestern Lumber Company.

Name: SIGMUND A. QUALE.
Description: Dealing in unimproved lands. He bought a large quantity of the land of the West Wisconsin (now Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha) Railroad, in certain counties, paying for it with his paper, secured by mortgage, and sold the land at an advance to Scandinavian settlers. He then bought the Gaslin farm, near Minneapolis, which soon became immensely valuable. He afterward bought State pine and hardwood lands in north Wisconsin, which rose in value; and had real estate in Chicago and elsewhere.

Name: J. T. BOYLE.
Description: Part owner in the Northwestern Yeast Company and manufacturer of Yeast Foam. His fortune has been partly made, however, in outside investments in real estate and securities.

Name: WOODMAN C. HAMILTON (of Hamilton, Merriman & Co.).
Description: Sawmills at Marinette and lumber.

Name: ANDREW C. MERRIMAN (of Hamilton, Merriman & Co.).
Description: Sawmills and lumber.

Name: JASON C. EASTON.
Description: Made in loans to farmers; stock of the Southern Minnesota Railroad, and other securities.

Name: CHARLES L. COLMAN.
Description: Made in the purchase of low-priced pine lands and sale of timber therefrom.

Name: GIDEON C. HIXON.
Description: Pine lands and sale of logs, and banking. President of the La Crosse National Bank.

Name: JOHN PAUL (of the John Paul Lumber Company).
Description: Made in lumbering, pine lands and merchandising drygoods.

Name: CAPTAIN PEYTON S. DAVIDSON.
Description: Made a fortune in steamboating first, and then went into the lumber business.

Name: ABNER GILE.
Description: Made in sale of timber from pine lands, bought when the price was low.

Name: WILLIAM F. VILAS.
Description: Speculations in pine lands and lumber business. He is United States Senator from Wisconsin.

Name: A. C. BROWN.
Description: Iron mining and lumber business.

Name: ISAAC STEPHENSON.
Description: Made in production of lumber and investments. President of the Stephenson National Bank.

Name: A. TAINTER (of Tainter & Son).
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: CAPTAIN FRED PABST (of the Pabst Brewing Company).
Description: Has made a large fortune in brewing. They have the largest lager beer brewery in the world.

Name: VALENTINE BLATZ (president of the Valentine Blatz Brewing Company).
Description: Brewing and real estate. President of the Second Ward Savings Bank.

Name: AUGUST UHLLEIN.
Description: Made in the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company.

Name: HENRY UHLLEIN.
Description: Made in the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company.

Name: ALFRED UHLLEIN.
Description: Made in the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company.

Name: JOHN H. VAN DYKE.
Description: Law, real estate investments and mines.

Name: GEORGE HILES.
Description: Pine lands, sawmills, lumber and railroads.

Name: CHARLES T. BRADLEY (of Bradley & Metcalf).
Description: Manufacturing boots and shoes. President of the Milwaukee National Bank of Wisconsin.

Name: W. H. METCALF (of Bradley & Metcalf).
Description: Manufacturing boots and shoes.

Name: MRS. W. H. METCALF.
Description: Inherited from Eastern relatives, engaged in the shipping business.

Name: JOHN L. MITCHELL.
Description: Inherited from his father, Alexander Mitchell. Made in banking. President of the Wisconsin Marine and Fire Insurance Company Bank, the oldest bank in the West.

Name: MRS. GUIDO PFISTER.
Description: From her husband, a member of the Pfister & Vogel Leather Co. Made in tanning and leather.

Name: MRS. O. P. PILLSBURY.
Description: From her husband. Made in pine lands and lumber.

Name: JOHN PLANKINTON.
Description: Packing, speculation, hotel property and Plankinton bank.

Name: ANGUS SMITH.
Description: Elevators, real estate and mining.

Name: HARRISON LUDINGTON (of Ludington, Wells & Van Schaick).
Description: Sawmills, pine lands and lumber.

Name: DAVID WELLS, Jr.
Description: Sawmills and lumber.

Name: EPHRAIM MARINER.
Description: Law practice, large investments in real estate, pine lands and railroads.

Name: W. H. BRADLEY (of Bradley Bros.).
Description: Made in lumbering.

Name: EDWARD BRADLEY (of Bradley Bros.).
Description: Made in lumbering.

Name: J. W. BRADLEY (of Bradley Bros.).
Description: Made in lumbering.

Name: MRS. EMIL SCHANDEIN.
Description: Inherited from her husband, who was a partner in the Phillip Best Brewing Co. Made in brewing.

Name: D. M. BENJAMIN.
Description: Pine lands and lumber.

Name: S. S. MERRILL.
Description: Inherited from her husband. Made in railroads and real estate.

Name: E. H. BRODHEAD.
Description: Railroads, banking and real estate.

Name: ALBERT CONRO.
Description: Contracting and investments.

Name: ROBERT ELLIOT.
Description: Grain commission business, real estate, etc.

Name: GEORGE BURNHAM.
Description: Brick making, real estate, etc.

Name: HERMAN G. SCHMIDT.
Description: A newcomer in Milwaukee. Made a large fortune in the nitrate beds of Chili.

Name: HENRY SHERRY.
Description: Pine lands, logs and lumber.

Name: HAVILAH BABCOCK.
Description: Manufacturing paper in the firm of Kimberly, Clark & Co.

Name: J. S. KIMBERLY (of Kimberly, Clark & Co.).
Description: Paper manufacturing.

Name: C. B. CLARK (of Kimberly, Clark & Co.).
Description: Paper manufacturing.

Name: HON. PHILETUS SAWYER.
Description: Pine lands, logs, banking and railroad speculation.

Name: EDGAR P. SAWYER.
Description: Pine lands, logs, banking and railroad speculation.

Name: GILBERT W. ROE.
Description: Pine and land speculations and investments. President of the Commercial Bank.

Name: JEROME I. CASE.
Description: Made in the manufacture of threshing machines, etc., and investments. President of the Manufacturers’ National Bank. Also President of the Granite National Bank, Monrovia, Colo.

Name: M. B. ERSKINE.
Description: Manufacturing threshing machines.

Name: L. S. BLAKE.
Description: Manufacturing fanning mills and real estate.

Name: MRS. R. H. BAKER.
Description: From her husband, Robert Baker. Manufacturing threshing machines and speculation.

Name: O. R. JOHNSON.
Description: Lumber, lake shipping and banking. President of Union National Bank.

Name: ALEXANDER STEWART.
Description: Lumbering and pine lands.

Name: DANIEL L. PLUMMER.
Description: Mining, lumber and president of the First National Bank.

Name: MORRIS D. CUTLER.
Description: The first white settler of Waukesha. Made in rise in value of real estate.

Name: O. P. POSEY.
Description: Money made in silver mining at Silverton, Colo.

Name: A. R. CONVERSE.
Description: Cattle and banking.

Name: WILLIAM WALDORF ASTOR.
Description: Inherited through intermediate generations from John Jacob Astor, the great fur merchant, who invested his accumulations in real estate in New-York City. The family have continued to buy and improve real estate, which has increased enormously in value; and Mr. Astor now owns many hundred houses, several hotels, and a large quantity of business property. He is director in the United States Trust Company, Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, Illinois Central Railway, New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company, Gallatin National Bank, and has other kindred investments.

Name: JOHN JACOB ASTOR.
Description: Inherited, as above, through intermediate generations from John Jacob Astor.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM ASTOR.
Description: From her late husband, William Astor, and made originally as explained above.

Name: HERMAN O. ARMOUR (of H. O. Armour & Co., New-York City, and Armour Bros., Chicago).
Description: Made in packing, provisions and commission business. Director in the American Pig Iron Storage Warrant Company. He has numerous other investments.

Name: WALLACE C. ANDREWS.
Description: Started in mining coal in Ohio with his brother, now of Youngstown, Ohio. They formed and floated several coal and railroad companies, and were interested in a large deal for the sale of coal lands to the Hocking Valley Railroad. Later engaged in large local enterprises in New-York City. President of the New-York Steam Company, and ex-president of Standard Gas Light Company. Director in the New-York Ice Company, Southern Natural Gas and Oil Company, National Bank of the Republic, National Iron Fence Company, Electric Secret Service Company, Hudson River Stone Supply Company, New-York Lumber and Wood Working Company, etc., etc.

Name: FRANKLIN ACKER (of Acker, Merrall & Condit).
Description: Made in the wholesale grocery business. Partly inherited from his father, David D. Acker.

Name: CHARLES L. ACKER (of Acker, Merrall & Condit).
Description: Wholesale grocery business.

Name: BENJAMIN ALTMAN (of B. Altman & Co.).
Description: Made in retail drygoods. Is in Garfield Safe Deposit Company, and has other interests.

Name: GUSTAV AMSINCK (of Gustav Amsinck & Co.)
Description: Private banking and importation of rubber and South American products. Director in the Bank of New-York, Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, etc., etc.

Name: COUNTESS DI AGREDA.
Description: From George L. Lorillard, her first husband, whose fortune was made in tobacco manufacturing.

Name: WILLIAM ARNOLD (of Arnold, Constable & Co.)
Description: Importing and selling drygoods, with investments in real estate.

Name: HICKS ARNOLD (of Arnold, Constable & Co.)
Description: Importing and selling drygoods, with investments in real estate. Director in Bank of the Metropolis, etc.

Name: JUAN APARICIO.
Description: Coffee raising in Venezuela and importing coffee to the United States.

Name: WILLIAM AUSTIN.
Description: Made in merchandising linens.

Name: JOHN D. ARCHBOLD.
Description: Production, refining and transportation of petroleum oil. Has numerous investments. Director in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: OLIVER H. P. ARCHER.
Description: Made in railroads and in express and freighting; and rise in value of real estate, of which he is now a very large owner.

Name: JOHN E. ALEXANDRE.
Description: Inherited from his father, F. Alexandre. Made in sailing ships and steam vessels in the Mexican and West India trade. Director in the Mexican Telegraph Company.

Name: JOSEPH J. ALEXANDRE.
Description: Inherited from his father, F. Alexandre.

Name: J. HENRY ALEXANDRE.
Description: Inherited from F. Alexandre, his father.

Name: MRS. JOSEPHINE S. AYER.
Description: From her husband, James C. Ayer. Made in manufacturing proprietary medicines in Lowell, Mass., and large investments in real estate in Boston, New-York City and Chicago. He left a great fortune.

Name: FREDERICK F. AYER.
Description: Inherited from James C. Ayer.

Name: HENRY S. AYER.
Description: Inherited from James C. Ayer.

Name: MRS. GEORGE P. ANDREWS (a daughter of Commodore Garrison).
Description: Inherited a fortune made in railroads and steam shipping.

Name: MRS. RICHARD K. ANTHONY.
Description: Inherited from her brother, John B. Dash. Made in merchandising and real estate.

Name: MRS. RICHARD T. AUCHMUTY.
Description: From Peter Schermerhorn, who had an old ropewalk in what is now Schermerhorn-st. in Brooklyn, and who had a great deal of real estate in New-York and Brooklyn (including what is now Greenwood Cemetery). Also from Edmund H. Schermerhorn. Made in advance in value of real estate.

Name: SARAH E. APPLEBY.
Description: Made in real estate.

Name: JAMES ALEXANDER.
Description: Tobacco manufacturing and real estate.

Name: JOHN CHARLES ANDERSON.
Description: Inherited from John Anderson, who made a fortune of $8,000,000 in tobacco manufacturing, use of lead foil to wrap tobacco, and large investments in real estate.

Name: Mrs. ELIZABETH W. ALDRICH.
Description: From her husband, Herman D. Aldrich, who made a fortune in the drygoods business, and large investments in now valuable real estate.

Name: MATHIAS H. ARNOT.
Description: Inherited from his father, John Arnot, of Elmira, N. Y. Made in banking and investments.

Name: CONSTANT A. ANDREWS.
Description: Partly inherited from his father, a leather merchant, but added to in private banking in the firm of Constant A. Andrews & Co., and in coking coal land investments. President of the United States Savings Bank and of the Elkhron Valley Coal Land Company. Director in the Second Avenue Street Railroad Company, etc.

Name: HUGH AUCHINCLOSS.
Description: Dry goods and importation of thread.

Name: WILLIAM H. APPLETON (of D. Appleton & Co., publishers).
Description: Partly inherited. All made in the publication of copyrighted books and printing. President of the Manhattan Safe Deposit and Storage Company; Director in the American Book Company; Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad; Central Trust Company; New-York Life Insurance Company; New-York Security and Trust Company, etc., etc.

Name: COLONEL DANIEL S. APPLETON (of D. Appleton & Co.).
Description: Partly inherited. All made in publishing copyrighted books and printing. Director in the American Book Company.

Name: WILLIAM W. APPLETON (of D. Appleton & Co.).
Description: Partly inherited. All made in publishing copyrighted books and printing. Director in the American Book Company.

Name: HENRY ALLEN (of Henry Allen & Co.).
Description: Brokerage business, railroads and stocks.

Name: EDWARD D. ADAMS (of Winslow, Lanier & Co.).
Description: Banking and investments. Director in American Cotton Oil Company; National Cotton Oil Company; Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company; Liberty Insurance Company; West Shore Railroad; Lehigh and Hudson River Railway; Central Railroad of New-Jersey; Central and South American Telegraph Company; New-Jersey Southern Railroad; New-York and Long Branch Railroad, etc., etc.

Name: HENRY M. ALEXANDER.
Description: Law practice, especially in insurance business, and investments. Director in the Equitable Life Assurance Society; Mercantile Trust Company; McDougall Electrical and Manufacturing Company, etc., etc.

Name: MRS. CHARLES B. ALEXANDER.
Description: Inherited a fortune from Charles Crocker, who with C. P. Huntington, Leland Stanford and others built the Central Pacific Railroad. Made in railroads and lands.

Name: LORING ANDREWS.
Description: Tanning and leather business, and investments in real estate, banks, etc.

Name: General LLOYD ASPINWALL.
Description: From his father, William H. Aspinwall. Made in sail and steam shipping and trade with the Pacific coast; then in the Panama and other railroads, and finally banking. Director in the Mexican National Railroad.

Name: ELBERT J. ANDERSON.
Description: Merchandising, insurance, banks, etc.

Name: JACOB W. ANDERSON.
Description: Merchandising and large investments in real estate.

Name: JAMES P. ALLAIRE.
Description: Made a fortune in iron-works and the building of marine steam engines. He had the largest marine engine works in the United States at the time.

Name: GEORGE F. BAKER.
Description: Has made a fortune of several millions during a long life of banking, negotiation of Government and other loans, and investment. President of the famous old First National Bank, and of the New-York and Long Branch Railroad. Director in the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, Citizens’ Insurance Company, New-Jersey Southern Railroad, Mutual Life Insurance Company, Bankers’ Safe Deposit Company, National Water Works Investment Company, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, Lehigh and Hudson River Railway, Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, etc., etc.

Name: FREDERIC BRONSON.
Description: Inherited. Has numerous investments. Director in the New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company, Institution for Savings of Merchants’ Clerks, American Jersey Cattle Club, New-York Cab Company, etc.

Name: JAMES GORDON BENNETT.
Description: Largely inherited from James Gordon Bennett, his father. Made in publishing The New-York Herald and in investments in real estate. The present Mr. Bennett has a large investment in the Commercial Cable Company.

Name: WILLIAM V. BROKAW (of Brokaw Brothers).
Description: Manufacture and sale of clothing.

Name: ISAAC V. BROKAW (of Brokaw Brothers).
Description: Manufacture and sale of clothing.

Name: MRS. JAMES H. BANKER.
Description: From her husband, a banker and broker, interested in the Vanderbilt railroads.

Name: HENRY BISCHOFF.
Description: Made in the banking business and real estate investments.

Name: SARAH BURR.
Description: All by inheritance, and all made in real estate.

Name: HENRY A. BURR.
Description: Made in manufacturing hat bodies, and by investments in banks, insurance companies, etc.

Name: THERON R. BUTLER.
Description: Merchandising drygoods first. Money made chiefly in the Sixth Avenue Railroad, of which he was president for many years. Had other investments in railroads. He was a director in the Erie Railroad.

Name: CHARLES BARLOW.
Description: Made in the Dun, Barlow & Co. Mercantile Agency, investments in real estate, and other operations.

Name: SAMUEL H. BROWN.
Description: First in early days in California, then in coal mining in Pennsylvania.

Name: MRS. MARY A. LA BAU-BERGER (wife of Francis Berger).
Description: From the estate of Commodore Vanderbilt. Made in railroads.

Name: WILLIAM BROOKFIELD, 83 Fulton-st. (proprietor of the Bushwick Glass Works).
Description: Partly in manufacturing glass; partly through his wife Kate Morgan, a daughter of Henry Morgan, of Aurora, N. Y., who made a fortune in manufacturing and in the express business. Director in the Kings County Fire Insurance Company.

Name: DAVID WOLFE BISHOP.
Description: Largely from the estate of John David Wolfe, the great hardware merchant and real estate investor.

Name: DAVID WOLFE BRUCE.
Description: Largely from the estate of John David Wolfe, the great hardware merchant and real estate investor. Mr. Bruce had, however, a comfortable property before receiving this inheritance which he had made in George Bruce’s Son Co., type founders.

Name: CATHERINE W. BRUCE.
Description: Largely from the estate of John David Wolfe, the great hardware merchant and real estate investor.

Name: MATILDA W. BRUCE.
Description: Largely from the estate of John David Wolfe, the great hardware merchant and real estate investor.

Name: GEORGE WOLFE BRUCE.
Description: From the estate of John D. Wolfe. He left an estate of nearly two millions.

Name: ELIAS C. BENEDICT (of E. C. Benedict & Co., bankers).
Description: Banking and investments. He made a great deal of money in Chicago gas stock. Formerly President of the New-York Stock Exchange.

Name: FREDERICK H. BENEDICT (of E. C. Benedict & Co., bankers).
Description: Partly from his wife, a daughter of the late Henry M. Flagler. Partly in the banking business.

Name: FREDERICK BUTTERFIELD.
Description: Made several millions in the dry goods business.

Name: SIMON BORG (of S. Borg & Co., bankers).
Description: Made in banking, investment securities, and railroads. President of the New-York Susquehanna & Western Railroad. Director in many railroads and corporations.

Name: A. BLUM.
Description: Began life as a merchant in St. Paul, Minn., but meeting with no success, went to Galveston, where he engaged in the importation and sale of dry goods on a large scale, and made a large fortune. He removed to New-York, invested his profits judiciously and died a wealthy man.

Name: FRANCIS M. BACON (of Baldwin & Co.).
Description: Made in commission dry goods.

Name: T. BRONNELL BURNHAM.
Description: Inherited from his father, Gordon W. Burnham, who made his fortune in manufacturing brass and copper in Connecticut. Director in Holmes, Booth & Haydens, brass manufacturers, Waterbury, Conn.

Name: DOUGLAS W. BURNHAM.
Description: Inherited from Gordon W. Burnham, and made in manufacturing brass and copper. Director in Holmes, Booth & Haydens.

Name: HENRY MORTIMER BROOKS.
Description: Inherited in part from his father, John Brooks; made in manufacture and sale of clothing. Also a partner, formerly, in E. S. Higgins & Co., manufacturers of carpets.

Name: MRS. JOSEPHINE WHITNEY BROOKS (wife of Henry Mortimer Brooks).
Description: Inherited from the estate of Elias S. Higgins. Made in the manufacture of carpets, rise in value of real estate, and investments.

Name: MATTHEW BYRNES.
Description: Originally in carriage-making, then in merchandising in California; chiefly, however, made in real estate investments and building in New-York City.

Name: PETER T. BARLOW.
Description: Chiefly from his father, S. L. M. Barlow, who made a fortune in law practice, enormous fees from railroads and clients, and investments.

Name: JABEZ A. BOSTWICK.
Description: Made in refining and transporting petroleum oil. Has other interests.

Name: JOHN S. BARNES.
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: BARTOLMI BLANCO.
Description: Plantations in Cuba and large real estate investments in New-York.

Name: WILLIAM BARBOUR (of the Barbour Flax Spinning Company and the Barbour Broilers Company).
Description: Made in the manufacture of thread at Paterson, N. J., and investments in corporations. Director in the National Bank of the Republic, Citizens’ Insurance Company, etc.

Name: ROBERT LENOX BELKNAP.
Description: Inherited. Has made money in real estate and other investments. President of the Union Electric Traction Company.

Name: HIBER R. BISHOP.
Description: Refining and transporting petroleum oil, and railroads and investments. Director in Minnesota Iron Company, Metropolitan Trust Company, Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway, Duluth and Iron Range Railroad and other companies.

Name: CHARLES T. BARNEY, No. 84 Broadway.
Description: Made by his father in railroads and the express business. Is himself a banker. He is a director in the Northern Pacific Railroad, Safe Deposit Company of New-York, New-York Loan and Improvement Company, Mercantile National Bank, Hudson River Bank, Don Enrique Mining Company, Knickerbocker Trust Company, etc.

Name: CALVIN S. BRICE.
Description: Has made a large fortune in railroad development, in which he has been engaged since 1876. Director in East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway, Mobile and Birmingham Railroad, Memphis and Charleston Railroad, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railway, Knoxville and Ohio Railroad, Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and has many other interests of kindred nature.

Name: MATTHEW C. D. BORDEN (of Bliss, Fabyan & Co.).
Description: Manufacturing cotton goods in Fall River, and general commission drygoods business here. Director in Lincoln National Bank, Lincoln Safe Deposit Company, New-York Security and Trust Company and other corporations.

Name: J. BOSKOWITZ (of J. & S. Boskowitz).
Description: Made in the sale of furs, robes, etc. They have a branch also in Chicago.

Name: SEMON BACHE.
Description: Left a large fortune, accumulated in the importation of plate glass and window glass.

Name: WILLIAM V. BRADY.
Description: Formerly Mayor of New-York. Accumulated a fortune in real estate and investments in stocks.

Name: CALVIN BURR.
Description: Made chiefly in advance in values of real estate. He owned a great deal of property in Brooklyn.

Name: BIRDSEYE BLAKEMAN (of Ivison, Blakeman & Co.).
Description: Publishing copyrighted books, especially school books. Is president of the Spencerian Pen Company and the American Book Company.

Name: WILLIAM H. BEADLESTON.
Description: Brewing. Director in the Bowery Savings Bank, Pacific Bank, Pacific Fire Insurance Company, etc.

Name: ALFRED N. BEADLESTON.
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: JULIUS BEER (of Weil & Co.).
Description: Made in the sale of leaf tobacco.

Name: CHARLES A. BAUDOUINE.
Description: His fortune has been made chiefly in the advance in value of real estate, of which he owns about $2,000,000.

Name: SAMUEL D. BABCOCK.
Description: Has made a large fortune in railroads, steamboats, banking and investments. Has a large quantity of real estate at Riverdale. President of the New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad, United States Mortgage Company, and the International Bell Telephone Company. Director in American Exchange National Bank, Bank of New-Amsterdam, Central Trust Company, Continental Insurance Company, Mutual Life Insurance Company, New-York and Harlem Railroad, Central Real Estate Association, Greenwood Cemetery, Manhattan Real Estate Association, New-York Real Estate Association, Manufacturing Investment Company, Providence and Stonington Steamship Company, etc.

Name: CORNELIUS N. BLISS (of Bliss, Fabyan & Co.).
Description: Commission drygoods and investments. Director in the American Surety Company, Central Trust Company, Equitable Life Assurance Society, Manhattan Safe Deposit and Storage Company, Fourth National Bank, Home Insurance Company, etc.

Name: GEORGE BLISS (of Morton, Bliss & Co., bankers).
Description: Originally engaged in merchandising; then went into private banking and real estate. Director in the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, Continental Insurance Company, Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, Great Northern Railway, United States Trust Company, New-York, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Manitoba Railway, Copper Queen Consolidated Mining Company, Mutual Life Insurance Company, etc.

Name: JOSIAH BELDEN.
Description: Made in California, in merchandising and real estate.

Name: DR. JOHN C. BARRON.
Description: Inherited. Has various investments. Interested in cattle-raising in the West. President of the Kentucky Coal, Iron and Development Company. Director in the Electric Secret Service Company, etc.

Name: MISS HELEN C. BUTLER.
Description: A niece of Mrs. A. T. Stewart, from whom she inherited over $3,000,000. Made in merchandising drygoods, and investments in real estate.

Name: PRESCOTT HALL BUTLER.
Description: Inherited from Mrs. A. T. Stewart.

Name: MISS ROSALIE BUTLER.
Description: Inherited from Mrs. A. T. Stewart.

Name: MISS VIRGINIA BUTLER.
Description: Inherited from Mrs. A. T. Stewart.

Name: M. E. BUTLER.
Description: Inherited from Mrs. A. T. Stewart.

Name: PATRICK BUTLER (of A. H. Hart & Co.).
Description: Made in manufacturing twine.

Name: ROBERT C. BILLINGS (of Faulkner, Page & Co.).
Description: Commission drygoods.

Name: MRS. SARAH BOREEL (wife of the Marquis de Boreel, of France).
Description: Inherited from the Astor family. Made entirely in real estate, of which she owns considerably more than a million dollars’ worth.

Name: JOHN U. BROOKMAN (of H. D. & John U. Brookman, shipping merchants).
Description: Made in deep sea ships, and fortunate investments in stocks and real estate.

Name: MRS. REBECCA BABBITT.
Description: Widow of B. T. Babbitt, from whom she inherited. Made in the manufacture of soda, saleratus, potash and soap.

Name: VAN WYCK BRINKERHOFF.
Description: Importation of drugs and shellacs.

Name: MRS. ANDREW G. BENINGER.
Description: Inherited from John B. Dash, her brother. Made in merchandising hardware and investments in real estate.

Name: JAMES L. BARCLAY.
Description: Inherited from his father, Henry Barclay, and made entirely in rise in value of real estate.

Name: HENRY A. BARCLAY.
Description: Inherited from Henry Barclay. Made in real estate.

Name: SACKETT M. BARCLAY.
Description: From Henry Barclay. Real estate.

Name: SOLOMON BEUTHNER.
Description: Called the “King of New-Mexico.” Made in mines and lands in New Mexico.

Name: JAMES BLAKELY.
Description: Wholesale paint business and rise in value of real estate.

Name: MILO M. BELDING (of Belding Brothers & Co.).
Description: Made in the manufacture of sewing silk, with some investments in corporations.

Name: ARTHUR W. BLAKE (of Blake Brothers & Co.).
Description: Private banking and stocks.

Name: ADOLPH BERNHEIMER.
Description: Commission, brown cottons.

Name: SIMON E. BERNHEIMER (of Bernheimer & Schmid).
Description: Originally in drygoods. Now in brewing and real estate. (Lion Brewery.)

Name: SIMON BERNHEIMER.
Description: Formerly engaged in the sale of clothing. Now retired. Worth over a million.

Name: ISAAC BERNHEIMER.
Description: Made in the sale of clothing.

Name: FERDINAND BLUMENTHAL (of F. Blumenthal & Co.).
Description: Importation of leather.

Name: VERNON H. BROWN (of Vernon H. Brown & Co.).
Description: Shipping, ocean transportation and investments in corporations.

Name: GEORGE S. BOWDOIN (of Drexel, Morgan & Co.).
Description: Partly inherited. Made in banking and investments in corporations. Director in the New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company, etc.

Name: AUGUST BELMONT (of August Belmont & Co.).
Description: Inherited from August Belmont. Made in private banking and investments. Director in Bank of the State of New-York; National Park Bank; Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway; Kings County Elevated Railway; Louisville and Nashville Railroad; Manhattan Trust Company, etc.

Name: OLIVER H. P. BELMONT (of August Belmont & Co.).
Description: Inherited from his father, August Belmont. Made in private banking.

Name: JOHN CROSBY BROWN (of Brown Brothers & Co.).
Description: Private banking and foreign exchange. Director in the United States Trust Company, Iron Car Equipment Company, etc.

Name: JAMES M. BROWN (of Brown Brothers & Co.).
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: BENJAMIN BREWSTER.
Description: Refining and transportation of petroleum oil, and investments. Director in the Duluth and Iron Range Railroad; Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway; Keokuk and Des Moines Railway; Minnesota Iron Company, etc. Vice-President of Wm. Cramp & Sons Ship and Engine Building Co., Philadelphia.

Name: HENRY R. BEEKMAN.
Description: Inherited. Made in rise in value of real estate owned by the Beekman family.

Name: JAMES W. BEEKMAN.
Description: Made in advance of the values of real estate in New-York City.

Name: JOSEPH BALLIN.
Description: Made in the wholesale drygoods business.

Name: OSCAR E. BALLIN (of Ballin & Co., bankers and brokers).
Description: Partly inherited from his father, Eugene S. Ballin. All made in banking and brokerage business and investments. Director in the Iron Steamboat Company.

Name: WILLIAM C. BROWNING (of Browning, King & Co.).
Description: Partly inherited. Chiefly made in the manufacture and sale of clothing. The firm had large contracts during the war. Largely added to by investments. Director in the Hamilton Bank, Hamilton Loan and Trust Company, Mercantile National Bank, Northern Railroad of New-Jersey, etc.

Name: WALSTON H. BROWN (of Walston H. Brown & Co., bankers, and Brown, Thomas & Co., contractors).
Description: Made in contracting, railroad building and banking. President of the Cincinnati, Jackson and Mackinaw Railroad. Director in the Buffalo, Rochester & Pittsburgh Railway, etc.

Name: MRS. MARY ANN BALDWIN.
Description: Inherited from her father, Jacob D. Vermilye, who made a fortune in banking, stocks and insurance.

Name: WILLIAM LANMAN BULL (of Edward Sweet & Co.).
Description: Brokerage business and the investment of money for foreign houses. He has been president of the New-York Stock Exchange twice. Director in the Northern Pacific Railroad, East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway, Metropolitan Trust Company, etc.

Name: NELSON M. BECKWITH.
Description: Made in the China trade and importation of spices and coffee. Was at one time in China with Russell & Co.

Name: ISAAC BELL.
Description: Shipping and investments.

Name: JOHN M. BIXBY.
Description: Law practice and rise in value of real estate.

Name: WILLIAM BUCHANAN (of Buchanan & Lyall).
Description: Importation of tobacco.

Name: WILLIAM M. BLISS.
Description: Drygoods; importation and jobbing. Interested in telegraph stocks, and Equitable Life Assurance Society, etc.

Name: CHARLES BANKS.
Description: Has inherited from several sources. Was once in business.

Name: ROBERT BONNER.
Description: Publishing “The New-York Ledger” and investments in real estate.

Name: CLARENCE BROOKS.
Description: Manufacturing varnish at No. 403 West Twelfth-st.

Name: JOHN L. BROWN.
Description: City contracts, building, etc.

Name: HENRY A. BOORAEM.
Description: Merchandising, drygoods.

Name: PELHAM ST. GEORGE BISSELL.
Description: By inheritance, chiefly, of real estate, and rapid increase of values of such property in this city.

Name: ANDREW CARNEGIE (of Carnegie Bros. & Co., and Carnegie, Phipps & Co.).
Description: Made a large fortune in the manufacture of iron and steel, and coke. Director in the Music Hall Company in New-York City.

Name: AUSTIN CORBIN.
Description: Made in railroads, banking and real estate improvement. Principal owner in the Corbin Banking Company. President of the Long Island Railroad; Elmira, Cortland and Northern Railroad; Spokane Falls and Northern Railroad; Manhattan Beach Company; Manhattan Beach Hotel and Land Company; New-York and Rockaway Beach Railway, etc. Formerly President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad. Director in the American Exchange National Bank; Chicago and Ohio River Railroad; Peoria and Pekin Union Railway; Western Union Telegraph Company; Central Railroad of New-Jersey; New-York, Brooklyn and Manhattan Beach Railway; Nassau Fire Insurance Company; Long Beach Hotel and Cottage Company; New-Jersey Southern Railroad; Lehigh and Hudson River Railway; Mercantile Trust Company, etc., etc.

Name: EDWARD B. COBB.
Description: Rise in real estate and law practice.

Name: AMOS COTTING.
Description: Made a fortune in merchandising in St. Louis; and banking in New-York, in the firm of Jameson, Smith & Cotting.

Name: JOHN J. CRANE.
Description: Made a fortune in merchandising, distilling and banking.

Name: ARTHUR B. CLAFLIN.
Description: Inherited in part from Horace B. Claflin, who made a fortune in drygoods. Added to by himself in the brokerage business. The Claflins also own a great deal of real estate above the Harlem and in Brooklyn.

Name: HENRY H. COOK.
Description: Largely by inheritance. Made money himself in Wall Street. Director in Union Pacific Railroad, Sixth Avenue Bank, Bank of New-Amsterdam, Mexican Surety Co., Buffalo, New-York and Erie Railroad, etc.

Name: CHESTER W. CHAPIN.
Description: Inherited largely from his father, of same name, who made a large fortune, beginning modestly with stage mail contracts, and local steamboats and railroads in the Connecticut river valley, and then building up into a great property the Boston and Albany Railroad in which his wealth was chiefly made; he was also interested in the New-York Central and other railroads and steamboats on Long Island Sound. Mr. Chapin is a director in the Boston and Albany Railroad, Spokane Falls and Northern Railway, United States Book Company, National Starch Manufacturing Co., Manhattan Elevated Railway, New-Haven Steamboat Co., Screw Dock Co., etc.

Name: JULIUS CATLIN.
Description: Made in drygoods. Has many investments. Director in the United States Life Insurance Co., Importers and Traders’ National Bank, Greenwich Savings Bank, and other enterprises.

Name: SIR RODERICK W. CAMERON (of R. W. Cameron & Co.).
Description: Importation of merchandise.

Name: GENERAL GEORGE W. CULLUM.
Description: Inherited from his wife, a member of the Hamilton family, who received a fortune from her first husband, General Halleck, of San Francisco. Made in law practice, the Mariposa mine, and real estate.

Name: LE GRAND B. CANNON.
Description: Made in iron mines, steamboats on Lake Champlain and railroads. Director in the American Fire Insurance Co., Delaware and Hudson Canal Co., Chateaugay Ore and Iron Co., etc.

Name: MRS. HARRY LE GRAND CANNON (Elizabeth M. Thompson).
Description: From relatives in Detroit. Made in real estate.

Name: GEORGE N. CURTIS.
Description: Patent medicines and street railroad and other investments.

Name: GEORGE A. CROCKER.
Description: Importing metals and banking. Director in the Bank of North America, Hanover Fire Insurance Co., and other companies.

Name: FREDERIC CROMWELL.
Description: Made in the Cromwell Steamship Line of coasting steamers and investments. Treasurer of the Mutual Life Insurance Co.

Name: MISS LAURA R. CONKLING.
Description: Inherited Catherine Wolfe, and made by John D. Wolfe, in importing hardware, and in real estate.

Name: EDWARD COOPER (of Cooper, Hewitt & Co.).
Description: Largely inherited from his father, Peter Cooper. Made in manufacturing iron, isinglass and glue. Peter Cooper was the only man in the United States, it is believed, who made a million dollars in manufacturing glue alone. Edward Cooper is a director in the United States Trust Co., American Sulphur Co., New-Jersey Steel and Iron Co., New-York and Greenwood Lake Railway, American Electric Elevator Co., Chrysolite Silver Mining Co., Metropolitan Opera House Co., etc.

Name: JAMES M. CONSTABLE (of Arnold, Constable & Co.).
Description: Importing and merchandising, drygoods and outside investments in real estate, etc. Director in the Bank of New-York, the Institution for the Savings of Merchants’ Clerks, etc.

Name: FREDERICK A. CONSTABLE (of Arnold, Constable & Co.).
Description: Merchandising, drygoods and rise in value of real estate.

Name: JOHN W. CONDIT (of Acker, Merrall & Condit).
Description: Wholesale groceries and various investments.

Name: WASHINGTON E. CONNOR.
Description: Made in railroads, telegraph companies and ocean cables.

Name: ADDISON CAMMACK.
Description: Brokerage business, stocks and speculation. Is in the Central Crosstown Railroad, Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Co., etc.

Name: JOHN D. CRIMMINS (of J. D. & T. T. Crimmins).
Description: Principally in contracting and building gas works, cable and elevated railroads, subways, etc.; judicious investments in real estate; street railroads, and work for estates. President of the Houston, West Street and Pavonia Ferry Railroad, and of the Essex and Hudson Land and Improvement Company. Director of the Fifth Avenue Bank, United States Savings Bank; and member of the Chamber of Commerce, Real Estate Exchange, etc., etc., etc.

Name: HENRY B. COXE (of Coxe Bros. & Co.).
Description: Coal lands and railroads.

Name: WILLIAM G. CHRISTIE.
Description: Rise in real estate.

Name: MRS. NELLIE L. CARPENTER (wife of Robert B. Carpenter).
Description: Inherited from her father, Thomas Cornell. Made in Hudson River steamboating.

Name: HENRY CLEWS.
Description: Brokerage business, stocks, and speculation in Wall Street.

Name: E. FRANK COE.
Description: Manufacturing fertilizers.

Name: BENJAMIN G. CLARKE.
Description: Iron manufacturing and investments. President of the Thomas Iron Company. Director in the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad; New-Jersey Zinc and Iron Manufacturing Company; Hudson River Ore and Iron Company, etc., etc.

Name: MRS. SARAH K. COWDIN.
Description: From her husband, Elliott C. Cowdin, importer of silks and ribbons. Some of his fortune was made in real estate.

Name: HENRY A. CRAM.
Description: Law practice and rise in value of inherited real estate.

Name: THOMAS CUSHING (formerly of Boston).
Description: Inherited a fortune, which was made in the China trade originally.

Name: WILLIAM P. CLYDE (of Wm. P. Clyde & Co.).
Description: Made in the Clyde line of coasting steamers, established by his father and ably managed by the present firm.

Name: JOHN M. CORNELL (of J. B. & J. M. Cornell).
Description: Made in architectural iron works, building of elevated railroads in New-York City, etc.

Name: ALFRED A. COWLES.
Description: Made in the Ansonia Brass and Copper Company, etc.

Name: MRS. JOHN R. CARTER.
Description: From her father, David B. Morgan, whose fortune was made in Wall Street.

Name: GENERAL WILLIAM CUTTING.
Description: Inherited from the Cutting family. Made in law, stocks, and real estate. Is himself a lawyer.

Name: COLONEL WALTER L. CUTTING.
Description: Inherited. Made in stocks, and real estate.

Name: R. FULTON CUTTING.
Description: Inherited largely from the Cutting family, and made in law, real estate, and stocks. Director in the Florida Central and Pennsylvania Railroad, Hygeia Sparkling Distilled Water Company, St. Louis, Alton and Terre Haute Railroad, etc.

Name: HENRY M. CUTTING.
Description: Inherited from the Cutting family. Made as above.

Name: ROBERT L. CUTTING.
Description: Inherited from the Cutting family. Made in law, real estate, brokerage and stocks. Is himself a broker. Has many investments. Director in the International Boiler Company, etc.

Name: WILLIAM BAYARD CUTTING.
Description: Partly inherited from Francis B. Cutting, the great lawyer. Made in law, real estate and stocks. Is himself in law, banking, real estate and railroads. Director in American Exchange National Bank; United States Trust Company; St. Louis, Alton and Terre Haute Railroad; New-York and Brooklyn Ferry Company; South Brooklyn Railroad; Florida Central and Peninsula Railroad, etc., etc.

Name: FRANCIS BROCKHOLST CUTTING.
Description: Inherited from the Cutting family. Made in real estate, law and stocks.

Name: MRS. LYDIA M. CUTTING (widow of Heyward Cutting).
Description: Inherited from the Cutting and Mason families. Law, real estate and stocks.

Name: JOHN WINTHROP CHANLER.
Description: Derived from the Astor family and made in real estate improvements.

Name: RICHARD F. CARMAN.
Description: Rise in value of suburban (now city) real estate.

Name: NELSON CHASE.
Description: Inherited the millions of Mme. Jumel. Made in rise in value of real estate at Liberty-st. and Broadway and on Washington Heights.

Name: CHARLES T. COOK (of Tiffany & Co.).
Description: Manufacture and sale of jewelry and silverware.

Name: ALFRED CORNING CLARK.
Description: Inherited from his father, Edward Clark, who made a fortune in the manufacture and sale of Singer sewing machines and investments in real estate. Edward Clark aided Singer to establish his rights to his patents in the courts and took an interest in the business.

Name: LIEUTENANT WILLIAM P. CLASON (U. S. N.).
Description: Entirely by inheritance from different relatives.

Name: JOHN CASTREE.
Description: Forty years ago, one of the leading retail grocers of New-York City. Increased his fortune by purchases of real estate, which afterward became valuable, especially in the Fifth, Eighth and Sixteenth wards. Was president of the Irving National Bank and Irving Savings Trust.

Name: GEORGE COPPELL (of Maitland, Phelps & Co., commission merchants and bankers).
Description: Made in general banking and commission business, and in investments. Chairman of Board of Directors of the Denver and Rio Grande Railway. President of the Railroad Equipment Co., of Minnesota and of the Duplex Street Railway Track Company. Vice-President of the Denver Consolidated Gas Co. Director in the Flint & Pere Marquette Railroad; East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad; the New-York and Northern, etc., etc.

Name: GEORGE W. COMSTOCK.
Description: Made in the wholesale drug business, with branches in Philadelphia, New-Orleans, and other cities.

Name: MRS. CARRINGTON (wife of Captain Carrington, England).
Description: From her father, Francis Warden, who made a fortune in importing drygoods, in partnership with A. T. Stewart.

Name: DUCHESS DE CAMPOSILICE.
Description: From her first husband, Isaac M. Singer. Made in manufacture of his sewing machines.

Name: GEORGE C. COLLINS.
Description: Importing tea, jobbing groceries, and investments in banks, insurance companies, etc. He was one of the largest tea importers in the city.

Name: JOHN CAREY.
Description: Made in real estate chiefly.

Name: HORACE F. CLARK.
Description: Law practice first. Then in the Harlem Railroad, which he built up into a great property. Then with Vanderbilt, in other railroads. President of the Lake Shore, Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana railroads. Director in the New-York Central, the Harlem, the New-Haven, the Chicago and Northwestern, and other railroads; Western Union Telegraph Company; Union Trust Company, and other enterprises. He was also a heavy and successful operator in Wall Street.

Name: RICHARD B. CONNOLLY.
Description: He made more than $3,000,000 in the operations of the Tweed ring in New-York City.

Name: HENRY CLAUSEN, Jr. (of the H. Clausen & Son Brewing Company).
Description: Made in brewing and real estate. Director in the Murray Hill Bank, Consolidated Gas Company, Harvey Peak Tin Mining and Manufacturing Company, and other concerns.

Name: SAMUEL J. COLGATE.
Description: Inherited. Made in the Atlantic White Lead and Linseed Oil Company; merchandising and investments.

Name: ROBERT COLGATE.
Description: Same as the last above.

Name: PATRICK C. COSTELLO.
Description: Tanning and leather business.

Name: ROBERT A. CHESERROUGH.
Description: Made in manufacturing vaseline. President of the Chesebrough Manufacturing Company. Director in the Panama Railroad and other companies.

Name: JOSEPH CLARK.
Description: Speculation in mining shares in San Francisco.

Name: CHARLES L. COLLY.
Description: Has made a large fortune, principally in railroads. Director in the Mexican National Railroad, North American Company and other enterprises.

Name: DON ALONZO CUSHMAN.
Description: Merchandising drygoods, and investments in real estate, banks, insurance, etc. He left a large fortune.

Name: CHARLES H. CONTOT.
Description: Inherited. Made in the restaurant business and investments in Broadway and other real estate.

Name: MRS. CORDELIA CHAUVET.
Description: From her father, Francis W. Lasak, who was engaged in the fur business with John Jacob Astor, and who, like Mr. Astor, invested largely in real estate, which is now valuable, and died worth several millions.

Name: MRS. OPHELIA J. CUTHBERT.
Description: From her father, Francis W. Lasak. Made in the fur business, and early investments in real estate.

Name: JEREMIAH W. DIMMICK.
Description: Carpet manufacturing.

Name: PETER DOELGER.
Description: Made in brewing and real estate.

Name: CHARLES D. DICKEY (of Brown Brothers & Co.).
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: WILLIAM P. DOUGLAS.
Description: Inherited. Has investments in insurance companies and real estate in this city and on Long Island.

Name: WILLIAM DICK.
Description: Sugar refining and investments.

Name: MRS. MARY ANNA P. DRAPER (widow of Henry Draper).
Description: Inherited from Cortlandt Palmer, and from her husband. The fortune was made first in merchandising hardware and then in real estate investments.

Name: JAMES G. K. DUER (of James C. King’s Sons).
Description: Partly inherited from Denning Duer. Made in real estate, private banking, railroads, and investments. President of the King Granite Company. Director in the Long Island Railroad, etc.

Name: WILLIAM ALEXANDER DUER.
Description: Partly inherited from Denning Duer, a descendant of Lord Stirling, who had a large estate on Long Island. Director in the Union Trust Company, National Bank of Commerce, Jerome Villa Site and Improvement Company, and other concerns.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM ALEXANDER DUER.
Description: From her father, William R. Travers, who made a great fortune in Wall Street.

Name: CHARLES A. DANA.
Description: Publishing “The New-York Sun,” with investment of accumulations.

Name: ALFRED B. DARLING (of Hitchcock, Darling & Co.).
Description: Largely made in the Fifth Avenue Hotel and real estate and other investments. Director in the Aztec Land and Cattle Company; Fifth Avenue Safe Deposit Company; Second National Bank, etc.

Name: LAWRENCE DRAKE.
Description: Inherited from Mrs. Ann Drake Seaman (born Morgan), widow of John F. Seaman. The property was in real estate in New-York City and Chicago.

Name: JOHN T. DALY.
Description: Gold mines in California and real estate in New-York City. A little distilling and warehousing.

Name: P. HENRY DUGRO.
Description: Inherited from his father, Anthony Dugro. Made in building and investments in real estate. Owner of the Hotel Savoy.

Name: JOHN B. DICKINSON.
Description: Merchandising in the California trade, and investments in banks, insurance companies, Brooklyn ferry, etc.

Name: FREDERICK DE BARY (of Fred. De Bary & Co.).
Description: Importation of wines and champagnes. Agent for G. H. Mumm & Co.

Name: MARY H. DRAKE.
Description: Made in the famous “S T.—1860—X.,” Drake’s Plantation Bitters and investments in real estate.

Name: WILLIAM B. DINSMORE.
Description: Inherited from his father, William B. Dinsmore, who made a fortune in the Adams Express Company and in investments in banks, and street and other railroads.

Name: CLARENCE G. DINSMORE.
Description: From his father, William B. Dinsmore. Made as above.

Name: JOSEPH W. DREXEL.
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: CHARLES DELMONICO.
Description: Made in the Delmonico restaurants.

Name: FREDERICK W. DEVOE (of F. W. Devoe & Co.).
