Description: Railroads and iron mining. President of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company. Director in the Adirondacks Railway, Chateaugay Ore and Iron Company, Crown Point Iron Company, Hudson River Ore and Iron Company, etc.

Name: JAMES F. O’SHAUGHNESSY.
Description: Real estate and railroads in the South and cotton oil. Director in the Kentucky and Arkansas Land and Industrial Company, Nicaragua Canal Construction Company, etc.

Name: WILLIAM OTTMAN (of Eastman’s Company).
Description: Exportation of cattle and beef. Director in the Citizens’ Savings Bank, Germania Bank, Stuyvesant Insurance Company, Butchers’ Hide and Melting Association, etc.

Name: FREDERIC P. OLCOTT.
Description: Private banking and stocks. Partly inherited from his father in Albany, and increased by him by investment. President of the Central Trust Company. Director in the Rio Grande Western Railway, Bank of America, Sixth Avenue Street Railroad, United States National Bank and other corporations.

Name: OSWALD OTTENDORFER.
Description: Publisher of “The Staats Zeitung.” Has investments in real estate and stocks. Inherited largely from his wife, the widow of Jacob Uhl, who created the paper.

Name: MRS. VIRGINIA R. OSBORN (wife of William H. Osborn).
Description: Inherited from her father, Jonathan Sturges, the great merchant of tea, coffee and groceries.

Name: GEORGE A. OSGOOD.
Description: Made in Wall Street and railroad stocks. Partly by inheritance.

Name: WILLIAM F. OAKEY.
Description: Merchandising.

Name: WILLIAM O’BRIEN (of William & John O’Brien).
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: JOHN O’BRIEN (of William & John O’Brien).
Description: Private banking and real estate.

Name: JOHN V. O’DONOHUE (of John O’Donohue’s Sons).
Description: Wholesale tea and coffee.

Name: CHARLES A. O’DONOHUE.
Description: Wholesale tea and coffee.

Name: HUGH O’NEILL.
Description: Made in his great retail drygoods store.

Name: JOSEPH J. O’DONOHUE.
Description: Importing tea and coffee; and investments. President of the Brooklyn and New-York Ferry Company; director in the Eighth Avenue Railroad, etc.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM B. OGDEN.
Description: From her father, John Arnot, of Elmira, N. Y., who made a large fortune in banking. She inherited also from her late husband a fortune made in real estate and railroads, and now owns property worth several millions. Her husband was formerly president of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad.

Name: GEORGE OPDYKE (of George Opdyke & Co., bankers).
Description: He began as an importer of drygoods. Retiring from that business, he started the private bank named above. They were fiscal agents of the New-York and Oswego Midland Railroad and placed most of its bonds. He left a little over a million.

Name: Mrs. MIRIAM A. OSBORN.
Description: From her husband, C. J. Osborn, one of Jay Gould’s brokers. Made in brokerage and stocks.

Name: HERMAN OELRICHS.
Description: Made a fortune in the North German Line of steamers to Europe. Has an interest in the Madison Square Garden, etc.

Name: MRS. THERESA ALICE OELRICHS (wife of Herman Oelrichs).
Description: From her mother, Mrs. Theresa Fair, and her father, James G. Fair. Made in the Bonanza silver mines.

Name: EDWARD OPPENHEIMER.
Description: Made chiefly in real estate.

Name: MME. FRANCES AMELIA BARTLETT OVIEDO (now the wife of Colonel von Gulmer, of the Mexican Army).
Description: From her first husband, and made in plantations in Cuba. Her “diamond wedding” with her first husband was a social sensation in New-York City at the time.

Name: ELIAS R. POWERS.
Description: Inherited from his brother, Henry Powers. Made in hotels and real estate.

Name: COLONEL WALTER W. PRICE.
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: ROYAL PHELPS.
Description: Merchandising and trade with the Isthmus, and real estate investments.

Name: SAMUEL B. PLATT.
Description: Partly inherited from his father, Isaac L. Platt, one of the founders of the Chemical Bank and the Pennsylvania Coal Company, who made a fortune first in hardware in Adriance, Platt & Co., and then in banking and coal mining.

Name: PERCY R. PYNE.
Description: Banking, railroads and investments. Formerly president of the National City Bank. Director in the Central Trust Company, Western Union Telegraph Company, Chicago and Northwestern Railway, Consolidated Gas Company, Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, Mexican Telegraph Company, New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, New-Jersey Zinc and Iron Company, etc., etc.

Name: MRS. ALBERTINA S. PYNE (wife of Percy R. Pyne).
Description: From her father, Moses Taylor, who made his fortune in importing sugar, but chiefly in railroad investments, and in gas, coal and banks.

Name: GEORGE H. PENNIMAN.
Description: Partly in linseed oil manufacturing, but mainly in real estate, in which at least two-thirds of his fortune has been accumulated.

Name: EDWARD A. PRICE (of Fred. Butterfield & Co.).
Description: Importing drygoods and investments. Director in the Fifth Avenue Bank, Importers and Traders’ National Bank, and has other interests.

Name: JAMES W. PAUL.
Description: Banking.

Name: WILLIAM POST.
Description: Real estate operations.

Name: WILLIAM A. PEMBROOK (Sweetser, Pembrook & Co.).
Description: Drygoods at wholesale.

Name: FELIX GOVIN Y PINTO.
Description: Made largely in plantations and land in Cuba; in part in real estate in New-York City, in which he had large dealings.

Name: JAMES C. PARRISH.
Description: Rise in value of real estate, of which he is a large owner.

Name: DANIEL PARRISH, Jr.
Description: Made in inherited real estate. From his father, who was a cotton merchant, and invested his profits in real estate.

Name: ELAZER PARMLY.
Description: Made almost wholly in rise in value of real estate.

Name: MRS. ELLEN M. PIKE.
Description: From her husband, Samuel N. Pike. Made in distilling in Cincinnati and New-York, and large investments in real estate in New-York City, Cincinnati, etc. Had several thousand acres of the Jersey meadows.

Name: FREDERIC A. POTTS.
Description: Coal mining and railroads.

Name: TRENOR L. PARK.
Description: From his father, Trenor W. Park, who made a fortune in law, real estate, the Mariposa mine, and railroads in California, railroads in Vermont, and the Panama Railroad.

Name: ORLANDO B. POTTER.
Description: Made his first million in the manufacture of the Grover & Baker sewing machines. Has doubled his fortune in real estate and law.

Name: W. A. PULLMAN.
Description: Producing oil, banking and investments. He was president of the Seaboard National Bank.

Name: JAMES H. PARKER.
Description: Made in raw cotton, banking, etc. Director in the National Park Bank, etc.

Name: JAMES V. PARKER.
Description: Made in merchandising and investment of profits.

Name: FREDERIC PRENTICE.
Description: Made in oil, lumber and real estate chiefly, but added to in brownstone from Ashland, Wis., in the sale of which he is now engaged.

Name: PRESTON B. PLUMB.
Description: Law, speculation, banking, cattle and various investments. Was in the Mutual Life Insurance Company; silver mines, etc. His business life was spent chiefly in Kansas, of which State he was a United States Senator at his death.

Name: FRANCIS A. PALMER.
Description: President of the National Broadway Bank. Made in banking and investments.

Name: JAMES R. PLUM.
Description: Made in hides; director in the United States Life Insurance Company; Fifth Avenue Bank; Importers and Traders’ National Bank, etc.

Name: EDWARD H. PERKINS, JR.
Description: Banking, president of the Importers and Traders’ National Bank. Director in the United States Life Insurance Company; Fifth Avenue Bank, etc.

Name: DUNCAN C. PELL.
Description: Made in merchandising and real estate.

Name: JOSEPH PULITZER.
Description: Made in the publication of “The New-York World,” and investments in real estate.

Name: MRS. ANNA PHELPS.
Description: From her husband, Isaac N. Phelps, of Phelps, Dodge & Co. Importation of metals, etc.

Name: JOHN E. PARSONS.
Description: Law practice. Counsel for the Sugar Trust, from which he has earned enormous fees.

Name: PHILLIPS PHOENIX.
Description: From his brother Stephen W. Phoenix, who inherited a part of the Whitney fortunes.

Name: LLOYD PHOENIX.
Description: Inherited from his brother, Stephen W. Phoenix, son-in-law of Stephen Whitney, who made a great fortune in merchandising and real estate.

Name: MRS. LESLIE JOSEPHINE PEARSON (widow of Frederick Pearson, Commander U. S. N.).
Description: From her father, James C. Ayer. Made in manufacturing proprietary medicines, and investments in real estate.

Name: NATIONAL PRIME.
Description: Made in Wall Street, and real estate.

Name: WILLIAM H. PARSONS.
Description: Paper manufacturing, at Brunswick, Me. President of the Bowdoin Paper Manufacturing Company.

Name: FREDERICK W. PAULDING.
Description: Real estate, and insurance and other investments.

Name: GEORGE POMEROY.
Description: Wholesale dealing in drygoods.

Name: COURTLANDT PALMER.
Description: From his father, Courtlandt Palmer. Made in hardware and real estate.

Name: HOWARD POTTER (of Brown Bros., bankers).
Description: Made in banking and foreign exchanges.

Name: GEORGE W. PRATT.
Description: Left a fortune made in wholesale jewelry and gold assaying, during the Civil War.

Name: MRS. GEORGE W. QUINTARD.
Description: From her father, Charles Morgan, the founder of Morgan’s great line of coasting steamers, and Morgan’s Louisiana and Texas railroads.

Name: JOHN W. QUINCY.
Description: Made in the sale of hardware, and investments.

Name: DANIEL S. RIKER (of J. L. & D. S. Riker).
Description: Commission drug business.

Name: JOHN L. RIKER (of J. L. Riker).
Description: Merchandising drugs and investments. Director in the New-York Dyewood Extract and Chemical Company; Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company; Atlantic Trust Company; Fidelity and Casualty Company; Greenwich Insurance Company; Hanover Fire Insurance Company; New-Jersey Zinc and Iron Company; Second National Bank; United States Fire Insurance Company; Bank of New-Amsterdam; Fifth Avenue Safe Deposit Company; New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad; etc., etc.

Name: JAMES A. RAYNOR.
Description: Made in steamships, railroads, and real estate.

Name: THEODORE ROOSEVELT.
Description: Importation of glass; banking; and real estate.

Name: ALFRED ROOSEVELT.
Description: Inherited largely. Made in importing glass; private banking; and rise in real estate. Director in the Gallatin National Bank; Metropolitan Improvement Company; Sixth National Bank; etc.

Name: W. EMLEN ROOSEVELT.
Description: Largely inherited. Made in importing glass; private banking; and rise in real estate. Director in the Union Trust Company; Institution for Savings of Merchants’ Clerks; Mexican Telegraph Company; etc.

Name: JAMES A. ROOSEVELT (of Roosevelt & Son).
Description: Fortune partly inherited from Cornelius S. V. Roosevelt, his father. Made in private banking; importing glass; real estate; and investments. Director in the Chemical National Bank; New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company; New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad; Bank of New-Amsterdam; Metropolitan Opera House; Delaware and Hudson Canal Company; etc., etc.

Name: ROBERT B. ROOSEVELT.
Description: Partly inherited from Cornelius S. V. Roosevelt, his father. Made in importing glass and banking by Cornelius. Robert B. Roosevelt has increased his fortune by banking and investments in real estate, president of the Holland Trust Company; director in the Brigantine Beach Railroad; Brigantine Building and Improvement Association; Brigantine Company; Jefferson Insurance Company; etc., etc.

Name: FREDERICK ROOSEVELT.
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate chiefly. Largely interested in the Scriba patent, central New-York.

Name: JEREMIAH P. ROBINSON.
Description: From his father of the same name. Made in the sale of groceries and salt, and in the storage business, and Brooklyn real estate.

Name: I. R. ROBINSON.
Description: From his father, Jeremiah P. Robinson, sr. Made as above.

Name: EDWARD A. RIDLEY (of Edward Ridley & Sons).
Description: Largely inherited from his father, Edward Ridley. All made in merchandising drygoods and rise in the value of real estate.

Name: ARTHUR J. RIDLEY (of Edward Ridley & Sons).
Description: Largely inherited from Edward Ridley. Made in drygoods and real estate.

Name: MISS MARY M. ROBERTS.
Description: From her father, Marshall O. Roberts. Made in steam vessels in the California trade, and in telegraph lines and railroads.

Name: JAMES A. RICHMOND.
Description: Local street railroads, etc., with Jacob Sharp. Director of the Christopher and Fulton Street road.

Name: MRS. J. HAMPDEN ROBB (Cornelia V. R. Thayer).
Description: Inherited from her father, Nathaniel Thayer, of Boston, who amassed a great fortune in foreign trade and shipping first, and then in banking and in the New-York Central, the Michigan Central, the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore and other railroads.

Name: THOMAS F. RYAN.
Description: Brokerage business; stocks and street railroads.

Name: CHARLES BROADWAY ROUSS.
Description: Jobbing drygoods and fancy goods, and rise in value of real estate.

Name: JACOB RUPPERT.
Description: Brewing and real estate.

Name: CHARLES T. RAYNOLDS.
Description: Manufacturing and selling paints.

Name: THOMAS RUTTER.
Description: Merchandising; railroads; gas-works; and investments. Director in the Consolidated Gas Company; Louisville and Nashville Railroad; Washington Trust Company; American Pig Iron Storage Warrant Company; Bank of State of New-York; New-York and New-Jersey Terminal Railroad Company; Housatonic Railroad; Kentucky Central Railway; etc., etc.

Name: HENRY H. ROGERS.
Description: Producing, refining and transporting petroleum oil. Director in the Atlantic Trust Company; Chesebrough Manufacturing Company; and has other interests.

Name: CAPTAIN BENJAMIN RICHARDSON.
Description: Sale of hardware in New-York and Sacramento; speculation in mines; real estate in California and New-York, and contracting; was with John W. Young, the son of Brigham Young, in land investments, and the Utah Central Railroad.

Name: JOSEPH RICHARDSON (brother of Captain Benjamin Richardson).
Description: Contracting and building. Builder and principal owner of the Bridgeport Water Works. Formerly President of the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad. Largely interested in railroads in Mexico and the Mexican Telegraph Company.

Name: JOSEPH RICKENDORFER.
Description: Made in manufacturing lead pencils, in the Eagle Pencil Company.

Name: MISS SERENA RHINELANDER.
Description: From her father, William C. Rhinelander. Made in real estate.

Name: WILLIAM RHINELANDER.
Description: From his father, William C. Rhinelander. Made in real estate.

Name: JULIA RHINELANDER.
Description: From William C. Rhinelander. Real estate.

Name: WILLIAM R. RHINELANDER.
Description: Inherited from the Rhinelander estate. Made in the advance in value of real estate.

Name: PHILIP RHINELANDER.
Description: Inherited from the Rhinelander estate. Made in the advance in value of real estate.

Name: T. J. OAKLEY RHINELANDER.
Description: Inherited from the Rhinelander estate. Made in the advance in value of real estate.

Name: MRS. N. F. REYNAL (wife of Jules Reynal).
Description: From her father, Nathaniel D. Higgins, partner with E. S. Higgins in manufacturing carpets. By inheritance from her father.

Name: CHRISTOPHER R. ROBERT, JR.
Description: From his father, Christopher R. Robert, sr., a merchant and land owner, and founder of Robert’s College, Constantinople.

Name: FREDERICK ROBERT.
Description: From Christopher R. Robert. Made in mercantile business and real estate.

Name: HOWELL W. ROBERT.
Description: From Christopher R. Robert. Made in mercantile business and real estate.

Name: HENRY E. RUSSELL (of the Russell & Erwin Manufacturing Company, New-Britain, Conn.).
Description: Made in the manufacture of hardware.

Name: WILLIAM G. READ.
Description: First in the drygoods business; but chiefly, in partnership with Jasper V. Van Vleck in the banking business on Wall-st., of which they made a good, solid success.

Name: WILLIAM ROCKEFELLER.
Description: The possessor of one of the great fortunes of the United States. Made in producing, refining and transporting petroleum oil, and investment of profits in real estate and the best paying companies. Director in the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway; Consolidated Gas Company; Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad; Hanover National Bank; Leather Manufacturers’ National Bank; New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad; United States Trust Company; etc., etc.

Name: JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER.
Description: Has made one of the largest fortunes in the United States, in the development of the Standard Oil Company and the Standard Oil Trust. He was President of the Trust, which recently dissolved. His enormous profits have been invested in the best paying securities and developing various important and useful business interests.

Name: DR. ROBERT G. REMSEN.
Description: Largely inherited. Made in real estate and the Third Avenue Street Railroad chiefly. Director in the Knickerbocker Trust Company; Union Trust Company; Third Avenue Street Railroad; Manhattan Savings Institution; etc.

Name: WILLIAM REMSEN.
Description: Largely inherited. Made in real estate and the Third Avenue Street Railroad chiefly. Director in the Greenwich Savings Bank; Harney Peak Tin Mining and Milling Company; Holland Trust Company; Third Avenue Street Railroad; and has other interests.

Name: JOHN ROACH.
Description: Made first in building boilers and engines, and then iron ship building and repairing. Owner of the Morgan Iron Works in this city and the great iron shipyard at Chester, Penn.

Name: JACOB ROTHSCHILD.
Description: Millinery; and rise in value of real estate.

Name: ALBERT S. ROSENBAUM.
Description: Manufacturing tobacco and cigars; and investments in street railroads. Director in the Twenty-third Street Railway and Third Avenue Street Railway.

Name: EDWARD ROSENWALD (of E. Rosenwald & Brother).
Description: Tobacco buying on a large scale.

Name: WILLIAM M. RICE.
Description: Tobacco buying on a large scale.

Name: FREDERICK ROLWAGEN.
Description: Made in the market business and investments in real estate.

Name: SAMUEL RAYNOR.
Description: Manufacturing envelopes, and investments in banks, insurance companies, etc.

Name: COUNTESS FRANCISCA SERAFINA DE RODA (formerly Madame de Barrios).
Description: From her first husband, General de Barrios, President of Guatemala, who made a large fortune in concessions, contracts, plantations, etc., in Guatemala.

Name: J. L. ROBERTSON.
Description: Made mainly in the building of the Chattanooga Southern Railroad, and investments in Southern enterprises, and the brokerage business here.

Name: ANNA LLOYD RENWICK.
Description: From her father, William H. Aspinwall. Made in shipping and trade, the Panama and other railroads, and investments in real estate, etc.

Name: ROBERT RAY.
Description: Made chiefly in banking as a silent partner in Prime, Ward & King, bankers. Had also large investments in real estate.

Name: LEWIS M. RUTHERFURD.
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate mainly. He was passionately fond of astronomy, and had a private observatory at his country-house at Tranquillity, N. J.

Name: RUSSELL SAGE.
Description: This able and daring operator has made a fortune of many millions in railroad and telegraph combinations and development, and in stock speculation in Wall Street. Largely interested in many of the great corporations of the day. President of the Iowa Central Railway. Director and large owner in the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, Importers’ and Traders’ National Bank; International Ocean Telegraph Company; Missouri Pacific Railway, Manhattan Elevated Railway, New-York Bank Note Company, New-York, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, Pacific Mail Steamship Company, Standard Gas Light Company, St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railroad, Texas and Pacific Railroad; Union Pacific Railway, Wabash Railroad, Western Union Telegraph Company, American Telegraph Cable Company, Mercantile Trust Company, New-York Mutual Telegraph Company, American Speaking Telephone Company, etc.

Name: GUSTAV H. SCHWAB.
Description: Largely inherited from Gustav Schwab, who made a fortune in the North German Lloyd steamers. Director in the German Savings Bank, United States Trust Company, Keystone Gold Mining Company, New-York Produce Exchange Safe Deposit and Storage Company, American Champagne Company, Merchants’ National Bank, etc.

Name: WILLIAM L. SKIDMORE (of Jeremiah Skidmore’s Sons).
Description: Merchandising coal. Is director in the American Savings Bank, Columbia Bank, and has other interests.

Name: FRANCIS A. STOUT.
Description: Importing business.

Name: SAMUEL SLOAN.
Description: Has made a large fortune in railroads. President of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad and of the New-York, Lackawanna and Western Railroad. Director in the Consolidated Gas Company; Missouri Pacific Railway; Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway; National City Bank; Texas and Pacific Railroad; United States Trust Company; Western Union Telegraph Company; Manhattan Elevated Railway, etc., etc.

Name: JOHN A. STEWART.
Description: Banking and investments. President of the United States Trust Company; director in the Greenwich Savings Bank; Merchants’ National Bank; National Fire Insurance Company; Equitable Life Assurance Society, etc.

Name: J. EDWARD SIMMONS.
Description: Brokerage business, banking and investments. President of the Fourth National Bank. Director in the Panama Railroad and has other interests.

Name: GENERAL HENRY W. SLOCUM.
Description: Made a start in salt works in Syracuse, and increased his fortune by street railroads in Brooklyn, and law practice in New-York City. Director in the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association; Chatham National Bank; Williamsburgh City Fire Insurance Company, etc., etc.

Name: MRS. LILLIAN SWAN.
Description: Inherited from her aunt, Mrs. A. T. Stewart, over $3,000,000. Made in dry goods and real estate investments.

Name: COLONEL WILLIAM L. STRONG.
Description: Made in commission dry goods and investments. President of the Homer Lee Bank Note Company and Central National Bank. Director in the Adirondacks Railway; Mercantile Trust Company; Swan Incandescent Electric Light Company; Brush-Swan Electric Light Company; Hanover Fire Insurance Company; New-York Security and Trust Company; New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, etc.

Name: Mrs. MARGARET LOUISE SHEPARD (wife of Colonel Elliott F. Shepard).
Description: From her father, William H. Vanderbilt, from whom she inherited $10,000,000. Made in railroads.

Name: CHARLES F. SOUTHMAYD (law partner of ex-Secretary Evarts).
Description: Law practice and investments.

Name: JOHN H. STARIN.
Description: River steamboats and harbor transportation.

Name: Mrs. ALICE E. SCHOENBERGER.
Description: From her husband, John H. Schoenberger, who made a fortune in iron manufacturing at Pittsburg.

Name: SCHUYLER SKAATS.
Description: Merchandising; stock-brokerage business, and real estate investments.

Name: CAROLINE SCHMID (of Bernheimer & Schmid).
Description: Made in brewing and real estate, in the Lion Brewery.

Name: EDWARD C. SCHAEFER (president of the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company).
Description: Brewing and real estate. Director in the Germania Bank, etc.

Name: GEORGE K. SISTARE.
Description: Made in Wall Street, and dealing in investment securities.

Name: JESSE SELIGMAN.
Description: Originally made in the importation of clothing, followed by banking, in which latter the Seligmans have become famous.

Name: JAMES SELIGMAN.
Description: Originally made in the importation of clothing, followed by banking, in which latter the Seligmans have become famous.

Name: WILLIAM SELIGMAN.
Description: Originally made in the importation of clothing, followed by banking, in which latter the Seligmans have become famous.

Name: SAMUEL STILWELL.
Description: City and country real estate, and investments.

Name: HENRY SMITH.
Description: First in groceries and canal stores at Fultonville, N. Y. Then agent of the Albany Merchants’ Line of Canalboats, on the Erie Canal. Then with Abram Van Santvoord in towing on the Hudson River. Then with Alfred Van Santvoord in the same business and steamboating to Albany; and in banks and stocks.

Name: AUGUSTINE SMITH (of Augustine Smith & Co.).
Description: Paper manufacturing and investments. Director in the Nassau Bank, etc.

Name: FRANCIS SMITH.
Description: Has made a large fortune, with his brother, George W. Smith, in railroads, stocks, bonds, Omaha real estate and Western lands.

Name: GEORGE WARREN SMITH.
Description: Railroads, securities, Omaha real estate and Western lands.

Name: CHARLES B. SMITH.
Description: Importing and wholesale drygoods, first; then in banking and financial corporations. Director in the Equitable Life Assurance Society; Fifth Avenue Bank; Fourth National Bank; Greenwich Savings Bank; Merchants’ National Bank; United States Trust Company; Manhattan Safe Deposit and Storage Company, etc., etc. President of the Chamber of Commerce.

Name: FRANCIS S. SMITH.
Description: Publishing “The New-York Weekly,” a story paper.

Name: Mrs. F. LEROY SATTERLEE.
Description: From her father, Henry Suydam, who made a fortune in importing tea, wine and coffee.

Name: LAZARUS STRAUS (of L. Straus & Sons).
Description: Importing china, pottery, glassware, clocks and bronzes.

Name: ISIDOR STRAUS (of L. Straus & Sons, importers of china, etc., and of R. H. Macy & Co., retail drygoods, toys, etc.).
Description: His fortune was founded in importing china, etc. He then became one of the owners of R. H. Macy & Co., and invested in real estate and hotel property at Lakewood, N. J., and in banks, etc. Director in the Hanover National and the New-York County National banks.

Name: NATHAN STRAUS (of L. Straus & Sons, importers of china, etc., and of R. H. Macy & Co., drygoods).
Description: Made in importing china, etc., and the retail drygoods business.

Name: DAVID L. SUYDAM.
Description: Partly inherited from his father, shipping man and flour manufacturer. Increased by himself in importing silks and other goods from France.

Name: JOSEPH SCHWARZSCHILD (of Schwarzschild & Sulzberger).
Description: Made in the sale of meat, tallow and hides.

Name: FRANCIS P. SCHOALS.
Description: Bookbinding first; his wealth came, however, chiefly from banking and stocks. Was president of the Broadway Savings Bank.

Name: THOMAS STURGIS.
Description: Made in the East India trade, real estate and investments. Director in the Western Union Beef Company; Electric Street Service Company; Maryland Ice Company; New-York and New-Jersey Terminal Railroad Company, etc.

Name: FREDERICK STURGES.
Description: Inherited from Jonathan Sturges, the grocery, tea and coffee merchant. Director in the National Bank of Commerce; New-York Warehouse and Security Company, and has other interests.

Name: ROBERT STURGIS (formerly of Boston).
Description: Made in foreign trade. Director in the Nicaragua Canal Construction Company, etc.

Name: FRANK K. STURGIS (of Work, Strong & Co.).
Description: Banking and brokerage business and stocks.

Name: GENERAL DANIEL E. SICKLES.
Description: Inherited from his father, George G. Sickles, and made in real estate and houses.

Name: WILLIAM J. SYMS.
Description: Originally a gunmaker, but made his fortune in the Metropolitan Gas Company, street railroads and telegraph lines.

Name: FREDERICK A. SEAMAN.
Description: Merchandising tea.

Name: JOHN H. SHERWOOD.
Description: Merchandising in part, but chiefly in large real estate operations. Also in banking.

Name: ANSON PHELPS STOKES.
Description: Partly inherited from his father, James Stokes, a partner in Phelps, Dodge & Co., who withdrew finally from that firm to form the bank of Phelps, Stokes & Co. He was in the Ansonia Brass and Copper Company, Pennsylvania Land and Lumber Company, and various other business organizations. The fortune was made in importing metals, banking, Michigan and Pennsylvania timber lands, and investments. Anson Phelps Stokes is a director in the Ansonia Brass and Copper Company, Mutual District Messenger Company, Mutual District Telegraph Company, United States Electric Lighting Company, United States Trust Company, etc., etc.

Name: MRS. ANSON PHELPS STOKES.
Description: From her father, Isaac N. Phelps, the great banker. Made in importing metals, banking and investments.

Name: THOMAS STOKES.
Description: Partly inherited from James Stokes, and made in importation of metals, banking and miscellaneous investments.

Name: JAMES STOKES.
Description: Partly inherited from James Stokes. Made in importing metals, banking, Michigan lands, etc. Is himself a banker. Director in the Liberty Insurance Company, Mercantile Trust Company and other companies.

Name: WILLIAM E. D. STOKES.
Description: Partly inherited from James Stokes. Made in importing metals, banking and miscellaneous enterprises. Director in the Kensico Cemetery Company.

Name: JOSEPH S. STOUT.
Description: Largely inherited from his father, Andrew V. Stout, merchant, banker and investor. Joseph S. Stout is in the brokerage business, stocks, and investments. Director in the American Bank Note Company, Holland Trust Company, New-York Mutual Gas Light Company, National Shoe and Leather Bank, etc., etc.

Name: HENRY SPINGLER.
Description: Began as a market gardener west of Union Square. Owned land which has risen enormously in value.

Name: MR. STRYKER.
Description: Rise in value of the old Stryker bay farm within the limits of the present New-York City, near Fiftieth-st.

Name: URIAH J. SMITH.
Description: Made mainly in real estate.

Name: WILLIAM C. SCHERMERHORN.
Description: Made in inherited real estate. From Peter and Edmund H. Schermerhorn. Peter had an old ropewalk upon what is now Schermerhorn-st. in Brooklyn, and a large quantity of real estate, now exceedingly valuable, in New-York and Brooklyn, including what is now Greenwood Cemetery. Director in the New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company.

Name: F. AUGUSTUS SCHERMERHORN.
Description: Made in inherited real estate. From Peter and Edmund H. Schermerhorn.

Name: GEORGE S. SCHERMERHORN.
Description: Made in real estate inherited from his father, Peter Schermerhorn.

Name: J. EGMONT SCHERMERHORN.
Description: From his father, John Schermerhorn. Made chiefly in rise in value of real estate.

Name: HORATIO SCHERMERHORN.
Description: From his father, John P. Schermerhorn, merchant of ship stores.

Name: MRS. ANTINETTE L. SCHERMERHORN.
Description: From the estate of her father, Francis W. Lasak, who made a fortune of several millions in the fur business with the original John Jacob Astor, and in early investments in real estate.

Name: MRS. MARY ROGERS RHINELANDER STEWART (widow of Lispenard Stewart).
Description: From her father, William C. Rhinelander. Made in rise in value of real estate.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM WATTS SHERMAN.
Description: From the John Carter Brown estate, Rhode Island. Made in foreign trade in part, but chiefly in manufacturing.

Name: EDWARDS S. SANFORD.
Description: Made in the Adams Express Company.

Name: WILLIAM H. STARBUCK.
Description: Shipping and railroads. President of the Housatonic Railroad and Oregon Improvement Company. Has other interests.

Name: JAMES O. SHELDON.
Description: Fine stock farm at Geneva, N. Y., from which he made some wonderful sales; and investments. Director in the Manhattan Trust Company, etc.

Name: JAMES M. SIGAFUS.
Description: Cattle raising in the West and investments. Is interested in F. I. Kaldenberg & Co.

Name: HENRY B. SLAVEN.
Description: He is president of the American Contracting and Dredging Company, and has made a fortune in work on the Panama Canal, etc.

Name: PHILIP SCHUYLER.
Description: Inherited from Schuyler and Hamilton families. Made in real estate.

Name: GEORGE H. SARGENT (of Sargent & Co.).
Description: Manufacturing house furnishing hardware, and investments. Their factory is one of the largest in the United States of its class.

Name: ISAAC STERN (of Stern Bros.).—Made in their great drygoods store.
LOUIS STERN (of Stern Bros.).—Made in their great drygoods store.
BENJAMIN STERN (of Stern Bros.).—Made in their great drygoods store.

ALFRED SULLY.—In railroads. He made a large sum in the Reading Railroad reorganization, and was at one time the largest holder of the securities of the road. Director in the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad, the Ohio Southern, and many other roads.
JOHN D. SLAYBACK.—Brokerage business, and investments. Treasurer of the Carbon Iron Company, etc.
B. B. SHERMAN.—Made a fortune in wholesale groceries first, and added to it in banking and trust stocks. His estate amounted to about $1,200,000.
JAMES STILLMAN (of Woodward & Stillman).—Made in dealing in raw cotton and railroads.
JARVIS SLADE.—Made a large fortune in drygoods and real estate.
JOSEPH STERN (of the old firm of Stern & Metzger).—He was a leading wholesale dealer in meats and manufacturer of oleomargarine.
ABRAHAM STEINHARD.—Investments in and dealing in real estate.
LOUIS STIEFEL.—Made in San Francisco and New-York City in dealing in drygoods.
WILLIAM E. STRONG (of Work, Strong & Co.).—Brokerage and banking business and stocks.
JOHN SLOANE (of W. & J. Sloane).—Head of the firm. Merchandising carpets; real estate; and investments.
THOMAS C. SLOANE.—From her husband, a partner in W. & J. Sloane, the carpet merchants.
HENRY T. SLOANE (of W. & J. Sloane).—Merchandising carpets; real estate; etc.

WILLIAM D. SLOANE (of W. & J. Sloane).—Merchandising carpets; real estate and other investments. Director in the Aspen Mining and Smelting Company; Hanover Fire Insurance Company; United States Trust Company, etc.
MRS. WILLIAM D. SLOANE.—From her father, William H. Vanderbilt, who bequeathed to her $10,000,000. Made in railroads.
WILLIAM SCHOLLE (of Scholle Bros., bankers).—First in mercantile business and real estate in San Francisco; then in real estate investments here, and in banking.
JACOB SCHOLLE (of Scholle Bros., bankers).—Has made a large fortune in the same business as his brother William. The firm are worth several millions.
WILLIAM H. SCHIEFFELIN (of W. H. Schieffelin & Co.).—Wholesale drugs.
SAMUEL B. SCHIEFFELIN (of W. H. Schieffelin & Co.).—Wholesale drugs.
MRS. GEORGE R. SCHIEFFELIN (Julia M. Delaplaine).—Inherited from John W. Delaplaine, a fortune made in shipping and rise in real estate.
HENRY M. SCHIEFFELIN.—Wholesale drugs; and rise in value of real estate, in which he had large investments.
ELIHU SPICER (of C. H. Mallory & Co.).—Made in steam shipping and merchandising.
MRS. SCHLEY.—Inherited from her first husband, Henry Keep. Made in railroads, especially in the Michigan Southern.
FRANCIS S. STREET.—Publishing “The New-York Weekly,” a story paper.
ROBERT R. STUYVESANT.—By advance in the value of the real estate left by his great-grandfather, the last Dutch Captain-General of New-York.
RUTHERFORD STUYVESANT.—Inherited from the Stuyvesant estate. Made in real estate.
GERARD STUYVESANT.—Made in inherited real estate.

MRS. MARIETTA REED STEVENS.—From her husband, Paran Stevens. Made in hotel keeping, and rise in value in real estate. Had over a million of real estate. He had the Fifth Avenue Hotel in New-York, the Continental in Philadelphia, and the Tremont and Revere hotels in Boston.
GEORGE S. SCOTT.—Railroads, Wall Street, insurance, etc.
MRS. SCOVILLE.—From her father, Judge James J. Roosevelt.
MRS. FLORENCE SUTTON (wife of James P. Sutton).—From her father, Rowland H. Macy, the dry-goods merchant.
JOSEPH STICKNEY.—Made in dealing in coal.
HENRY F. SPAULDING.—Drygoods commission business; and investments. Director in the Central Trust Company; Continental Insurance Company; Mechanics’ National Bank; and has other interests.

JAMES SWANN (of Inman, Swann & Co.).—Cotton commission business and railroads. Director in the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad; Knoxville and Ohio Railroad; and many other Southern railroads.
MRS. CHARLES D. STICKNEY (Helen Reade Hamersley).—Inherited real estate and advance in value thereof.

ROBERT SCHELL.—Partly inherited from his brother, Augustus Schell. Made in railroads, banking, and other investments. Robert Schell is president of the National Bank of the Metropolis. Director in the German Savings Bank; New-York and Harlem Railroad; etc.

EDWARD SCHELL.—Inherited from Augustus Schell, his brother. Made in railroads, banking, etc. President of the Manhattan Savings Institution, etc., etc. Director in the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, Union Trust Company, Citizen’s Bank, Butchers’ and Drovers’ Bank and Third National Bank. Treasurer of St. Luke’s Hospital, St. John’s Guild and the American Institute.
JACOB H. SCHIFF (of Kuhn, Loeb & Co.).—Private banking and investments. Director in the Louisville and Nashville Railroad; and has other interests.

MRS. MARY MACRAE STUART.—From her husband, Robert L. Stuart, who made a large fortune in the manufacturing of candy, first, then in refining sugar, and in investments in real estate. He left about $5,000,000, of which $1,250,000 was in real estate.
ALEXANDER STUART.—Made in the manufacture of candy, refining sugar, and investments in real estate. He left it all to his brother Robert.
CHARLES F. SCHMIDT (of Charles F. Schmidt & Peters).—Importing wines and liquors.
WILLIAM SCHLESINGER (of Schlesinger Brothers).—Merchandising iron ores.
WILLIAM STEINWAY (of Steinway & Sons).—Manufacturing pianos, investments in banks, etc. Director in the German Savings Bank, and has various other interests.
CONRAD STEIN.—Made in brewing and real estate. Director in the Germania Bank.
JOHN H. SWEETSER (of Sweetser, Pembrook & Co.)
Description: Drygoods at wholesale.

Name: EFFINGHAM B. SUTTON (of Sutton & Co.)
Description: First in drygoods, but chiefly in Sutton’s line of sailing clippers in the ocean freighting of the world.

Name: JACKSON S. SCHULTZ
Description: Tanning and leather.

Name: BARONESS DE SEILLIERE (formerly Mrs. Charles F. Livermore)
Description: From her first husband, a banker and real estate owner.

Name: THOMAS SUNDERLAND
Description: Law practice in California, first, and investments.

Name: EDWIN H. SHELDON
Description: Made in railroads and large investments in real estate.

Name: LOUISIANA ST. JOHN
Description: This extremely rich woman’s wealth may be said to have come largely by gift and rise in value of real estate.

Name: PRINCESS SCHEY-MONTBELIARD (Winnaretta Singer)
Description: From her father, Isaac M. Singer, and made in the manufacture of the Singer sewing machine. She lives in France.

Name: THOMAS U. SMITH
Description: Made a start in merchandising, and added to his fortune as president of the Mercantile Trust Company and by investments in real estate.

Name: JONAS STRAUSS
Description: Made a large fortune, first in drygoods and clothing in Rochester N. Y., then in general drygoods in New-York City.

Name: JOHN B. SIMPSON
Description: Inherited from his father, William Simpson, and his uncle, John B. Simpson. They came to this country, from England in 1822 and founded the pawn brokerage business, which they pursued for upward of half a century, investing their profits principally in real estate on the Bowery and in what was formerly Westchester County. This real estate is now exceedingly valuable.

Name: WILLIAM SIMPSON
Description: Inherited from William and John B. Simpson, and made as above explained.

Name: MRS. CATHERINE WILSON TAYLOR
Description: From her husband, Moses Taylor, who left an estate of $40,000,000. He began life in importing sugar from Cuba, and bought vessels to employ in the trade. His great wealth was made, however, in the development of the railroads leading from the coal regions of Northern Pennsylvania. He bought a large quantity of stock of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, when it was down to about $5 share during the panic of 1857, and its subsequent increase in value made him enormously wealthy. He also gained control of the Manhattan Gas Light Company in about the same way, and owned largely in the Lackawanna Iron and Coal Company. Had investments in banks and many other companies. He was one of the five men who formed the company to lay the first Atlantic cable.

Name: HENRY A. C. TAYLOR
Description: Inherited from Moses Taylor, whose fortune was made as above explained. He is a director in the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, National City Bank, etc., etc.

Name: GEORGE C. TAYLOR
Description: Inherited from Moses Taylor.

Name: CHARLES L. TIFFANY (of Tiffany & Co.)
Description: Manufacture and sale of high-class jewelry and silverware, with investment of savings. Director in the American Surety Company, State Trust Company, and has real estate and other interests.

Name: COLONEL WILLIAM P. THOMPSON (formerly of Parkersburg, W. Va.)
Description: Refining, production and transportation of petroleum oil. Director in the United States National Bank, American Pig Iron Storage Warrant Company, National Lead and Oil Company, and has other interests.

Name: CHARLES H. TENNY (of Charles H. Tenny & Co., hats, and Tenny & Dupee, hats.)
Description: Commission hats and straw goods. Director of the National Citizens’ Bank, etc.

Name: DR. CHARLES A. TINKER
Description: Money made originally in clipper sailing ships. Director in the American District Telegraph Company, American Speaking Telephone Company, Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, Holmes Electric Protective Company, etc., etc.

Name: LAWRENCE TURNURE (of Lawrence Turnure & Co.)
Description: Commission shipping, insurance, banking, sugars, and corporations. Director in the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, Continental Insurance Company, National City Bank, etc., etc.

Name: DANIEL F. TIEMANN (of D. F. Tiemann & Co.)
Description: Merchandising and manufacturing paints.

Name: MRS. FLORENCE ADELE TWOMBLY (wife of Hamilton McK. Twombly)
Description: From her father, William H. Vanderbilt, from whom she inherited $10,000,000. Made in railroads.

Name: HORACE K. THURBER
Description: Has made a large fortune in the great wholesale grocery and canned goods business established by himself and his brother, Francis B. Thurber, followed by investment of savings in many large enterprises. President of the United States and Brazil Mail Steamship Company and the United States Book Company. Director in the Spokane Falls and Northern Railway, United States Life Insurance Company, Importers and Traders’ National Bank, National Starch Manufacturing Company, Trow City Directory Company, “American Grocer” Publishing Association, Safety Insulated Wire and Cable Company, etc., etc.

Name: FRANCIS B. THURBER
Description: Has become very rich in the wholesale grocery and canned goods business with his brother. President of Thurber, Whyland & Co., wholesale grocers. Director in the Condensed Coffee Company, Jackson Cold Drawn Steel Company, etc., etc.

Name: FRANK TILFORD (of Park & Tilford)
Description: Made in the wholesale and retail grocery business and investments. They are the principal retail grocery merchants of New-York City.

Name: CHARLES E. TILFORD (of Park & Tilford)
Description: Made in the wholesale and retail grocery business.

Name: HENRY TALMAGE
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: J. MONROE TAYLOR
Description: Made in the manufacture of saleratus and baking soda and real estate.

Name: JAMES TALCOTT
Description: Domestic silks and drygoods, commission business, and investments. Director in the National Broadway Bank.

Name: WILLIAM TILDEN
Description: Varnish manufacturing.

Name: WILLIAM TOEL (of Watjen, Toel & Co.)
Description: Foreign exchange and banking.

Name: GENERAL SAMUEL THOMAS (of Brown, Thomas & Co., contractors, and the Thomas Iron Company)
Description: First in manufacturing and coal mining in Central Ohio. Then after 1873 in railroads and coal and iron development in the South. Director in the Texas and Pacific Railway, Western Union Beef Company, Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railway, East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway, Hudson River Ore and Iron Company, Knoxville and Ohio Railroad, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, Memphis and Charleston Railroad, Cincinnati, Jackson and Mackinaw Railroad, Pacific Mail Steamship Company, Texas and Pacific Railway, the Thomas Iron Company, etc., etc.

Name: JAMES A. TROWBRIDGE (of Vermilye & Co.)
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: WILLIAM H. TAYLOR
Description: Made in San Francisco in the sale of petroleum, paints, whiskey, etc.

Name: FREDERICK B. TAYLOR
Description: Made in San Francisco in the sale of petroleum, paints, whiskey, etc.

Name: REVERDY J. TRAVERS
Description: From his father, William R. Travers. Made in Wall Street.

Name: WILLIAM R. TRAVERS, JR.
Description: From his father, William R. Travers. Made in Wall Street.

Name: WILLIAM TURNBULL
Description: Railroads.

Name: GIDEON TUCKER
Description: Rise in value of a large quantity of real estate in the vicinity of Tenth and Twelfth sts., Fifth-ave. and the Bowery.

Name: MRS. DANIEL TORRANCE
Description: Inherited from Commodore Vanderbilt, her father, and from her husband. Made in railroads and importation of tea.

Name: MRS. KATE L. TERRY
Description: Inherited from Juan Pedro Terry, her husband. Made in coffee and sugar-raising in Cuba and investments in real estate and stocks here.

Name: ANTONIO TERRY
Description: Inherited from Juan Pedro Terry. Made as above.

Name: HENRY G. TREVOR
Description: From his father, John R. Trevor. Made in banking, railroads and stocks.

Name: ERASTUS D. TEFFT
Description: Made in wholesale drygoods and real estate investments.

Name: MRS. EMILY THORN (widow of William K. Thorn)
Description: From the Vanderbilt estate. Made in railroads.

Name: JONATHAN THORNE (of J. & W. Thorne)
Description: Largely inherited from his father, Jonathan Thorne. Made in merchandising, in tanning and leather and investments in banks, gas companies, railroads, etc.

Name: WILLIAM THORNE (of J. & W. Thorne)
Description: Largely inherited from his father, Jonathan Thorne. Made in merchandising, in tanning and leather, and investments in banks, gas companies, railroads, etc.

Name: L. MORTIMER THORN
Description: Made a million by the discovery of a fast dye for calico.

Name: EDWIN THORNE
Description: Largely inherited. Merchandising drygoods first, then tanning leather, and investments in gas, street railroads, etc.

Name: SAMUEL THORNE
Description: Largely inherited. Made in the tanning and leather business, real estate, gas, street railroads and other investments. Director in the Sixth Avenue Railroad, Hanover Fire Insurance Company, Pennsylvania Coal Company, Bank of America, New-York Mutual Gaslight Company, etc.

Name: EDWARD N. TAILER
Description: Importing and merchandising drygoods.

Name: MRS. AGNES TAILER (wife of Edward N. Tailer)
Description: From her father, Thomas Suffern, importing merchant and investor in real estate.

Name: ROBERT W. TAILER
Description: Importing merchant. Part of his large fortune came from inheritance and investments in street railroads, real estate, etc. Director in the Third Avenue Railroad.

Name: LUCIUS TUCKERMAN
Description: Made in the iron trade and in investments in real estate, of which he is a large owner.

Name: MRS. SINCLAIR TOUSEY
Description: Made in the American News Company. Inherited from her late husband. Wholesale handling of books and papers.

Name: WESLEY H. TILFORD
Description: Producing, refining and transporting petroleum oil in the Standard Oil Company.

Name: J. KENNEDY TOD (of J. Kennedy Tod & Co.)
Description: Private banking, railroads and real estate. Director in the Cincinnati, Jackson and Mackinaw Railroad, Great Northern Railway, Rio Grande Western Railway, Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railway, etc.

Name: GEORGE F. TALLMAN
Description: Rise in value of real estate and improvement thereof.

Name: LOUIS L. TODD
Description: Made in part in Wall Street in the brokerage business and partly in real estate investments. He is a large owner of real estate. Builder and owner of the Hotel Marlborough and the Hotel Vendome.

Name: ERNEST W. TABOR
Description: Exportation of cattle and beef.

Name: EDMUND URQUHART
Description: Made in shipping and investments. Director in the American Cotton Oil Company.

Name: BENJAMIN F. ULLMAN
Description: Made in the liquor trade and in pawnbroking establishments.

Name: JOSEPH ULLMAN
Description: Furs and hides.

Name: SIMON ULLMAN (of S. & F. Ullman)
Description: His regular business is that of dealer in hops, but a large amount of money has been made in Brooklyn elevated railroads and in other investments.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM H. VANDERBILT
Description: From her husband, William H. Vanderbilt. Made in the development of the railroads of the Vanderbilt system.

Name: CORNELIUS VANDERBILT
Description: One of the richest men in America. Inherited from William H. Vanderbilt, his father, and made in the development of the New-York Central and Hudson River, the Harlem, the Lake Erie and Michigan Southern, and other railroads of the Vanderbilt system. President of the Canada Southern and Michigan Central railroad. Director and large owner in the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad; New-York and Harlem Railroad; West Shore Railroad; Dunkirk, Alleghany Valley and Pittsburg Railroad; Lake Shore and Michigan Southern R. R.; Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha R. R.; N. Y., Chicago and St. Louis R. R.; Union Trust Co.; Pine Creek Railroad; New-York Mutual Gas Light Company, etc., etc.

Name: WILLIAM K. VANDERBILT
Description: Inherited an enormous fortune from William H. Vanderbilt, his father, Made in the railroads of the Vanderbilt system. Director in nearly all the same railroads as Cornelius Vanderbilt, but also in the Chicago and Northwestern Railway; the Metropolitan Opera House Company; Merchants’ Dispatch Transportation Company, etc., etc.

Name: FREDERICK W. VANDERBILT
Description: Inherited a fortune from his father, William H. Vanderbilt. Director in all the roads of the Vanderbilt system, and has various investments of his own.

Name: GEORGE W. VANDERBILT
Description: Inherited a fortune from his father, William H. Vanderbilt.

Name: JOHN D. VERMUELE
Description: Chiefly in manufacturing. President of the Goodyear’s Rubber Manufacturing Company and of Goodyear’s India Rubber Glove Manufacturing Company. Director in Anglo-American Saving and Loan Association; Bank of New-Amsterdam; etc., etc.

Name: MRS. MARY J. VAN DOREN
Description: Inherited from her father, Jordan L. Mott, sr. Made in manufacturing stoves and ironwork. Increased by real estate investments. Owner of the Holland House.

Name: PHILLIP VAN VOLKENBURG
Description: Commission drygoods and investments in banks, insurance companies, real estate, etc.

Name: GEORGE F. VIETOR (of Frederick Vietor & Achelis)
Description: Importation of drygoods.

Name: ALEX. T. VAN NEST (of A. R. Van Nest & Co.)
Description: Wholesale hardware and investments. Is in the Dolphin Manufacturing Company (jute goods) also; and Sixth-ave. railroad, etc.

Name: of A. R. VAN NEST (of A. R. Van Nest & Co.)
Description: Made several millions in the wholesale hardware business and investments in street railroads, insurance, etc.

Name: WARNER VAN NORDEN
Description: Banking and investments. President of the National Bank of North America. Director in the Home Insurance Company, Mobile and Ohio Railroad, Duluth and Superior Loan Company, Holland Trust Company, Pueblo Smelting and Refining Company, American Savings Bank, Plymouth Consolidated Gold Mining Company, etc. President of the South Yuba Water Company.

Name: JAMES J. VAN ALEN
Description: Inherited a fortune through his wife from the Astor estate. Made in real estate.

Name: CORTLANDT S. VAN RENSSELAER
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate.

Name: MRS. SUSAN L. VIVIAN (wife of Colonel Ralph Vivian)
Description: From her first husband, Marshall O. Roberts. Made in steam shipping in the California trade, telegraph lines, and railroads.

Name: ASHLEY A. VANTINE
Description: Importing Japanese and Chinese goods.

Name: A. E. VANDERPOEL
Description: Largely inherited, and made in the rise in value of real estate.

Name: LOUIS A. VAN HOFFMAN
Description: Private banking, and investments of various kinds. Had an interest at one time in cattle-raising in the West. Director in the International Bell Telephone Company.

Name: E. H. VAN INGEN
Description: Made in the importation of woollen goods.

Name: HENRY VILLARD
Description: Made a large fortune in railroads, especially in the Northern Pacific and connecting lines, a large part of which he lost, but a portion of which he retains. Director now in the Edison Electric Light Company; Edison Electric Illuminating Company; Edison General Electric Company; and has other interests.

Name: ALFRED VANSANTVOORD
Description: Has made several millions, originally in towing, but later in the “Hudson River Line” of steamboats on the Hudson River, with careful investment of his profits. Director in the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company; Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway; N. Y. and Harlem R. R.; Lincoln National Bank, etc., etc.

Name: CHAUNCEY VIBBARD
Description: Dealing in railroad supplies; Hudson River steamboats to Albany; elevated railroads in New-York City; and in the Southern Pacific Railroad, and Southern and Central American enterprises.

Name: THEODORE N. VAIL
Description: Made in introducing the telephone and in telegraphing. Director in the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company; Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company; American Telephone and Telegraph Company; Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company; National Heating Company; Dives Pelican Mining Company, etc. President of the Accumulator Company.

Name: DR. WILLIAM SEWARD WEBB
Description: President of the Wagner Palace Car Company and owner or director in several railroads. He inherited through his mother from the Cram estate (made in real estate), and added to his means, first, in the brokerage business in Wall Street, and then in the Palace Car Company and in railroads. Director in the Lincoln Safe Deposit Company.

Name: MRS. ELIZA O. WEBB (wife of Dr. William Seward Webb)
Description: From her father, William H. Vanderbilt, from whom she inherited $10,000,000, made in the development of the New-York Central and other railroads.

Name: CLARENCE WARDEN
Description: From his father, Francis Warden, who was next to Stewart in the partnership of A. T. Stewart & Co., and who for many years selected in Paris the silks, laces, shawls and carpets the firm imported to New-York, and died worth more than $8,000,000.

Name: WILLIAM WARDEN
Description: From his father, Francis Warden, partner of A. T. Stewart. See last above.

Name: MRS. FANNIE S. WHITEHOUSE
Description: From William B. Ogden. Made in Chicago and New-York City real estate and in railroads. He was formerly the president of the Illinois Central Railroad.

Name: JOHN G. WENDELL
Description: Inherited from his father, John D. Wendell, who was related to the Astors, and who made a fortune in the rise in value and improvement of real estate.

Name: MRS. DR. FANEUIL D. WEISSE
Description: From her father, Henry Suydam, importer of tea, coffee and wine.

Name: WILLIAM WATSON
Description: He left over $5,000,000, made in drygoods and investment of his accumulations.

Name: JACOB WENDELL
Description: Made a fortune in commission drygoods, banking, etc. Director in the Continental Insurance Company, Manhattan Real Estate Association, New-York Real Estate Association, etc.

Name: THOMAS H. WHEELER
Description: Made in the sale of dressed beef. President of the New-York Beef Company.

Name: JAMES E. WARD (of James E. Ward & Co.)
Description: Made a fortune in coasting lines of steamers. Director in the New-York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company.

Name: LUCIEN C. WARNER (of Warner Brothers)
Description: Manufacturing corsets, and investments in banks, etc. President of the Hamilton Bank. Director in the Twelfth Ward Savings Bank, International Phosphate Company, etc.

Name: GEORGE HENRY WARREN
Description: Through his wife, who inherited a fortune from the estate of Stephen Whitney, an old-time merchant.

Name: MRS. CATHERINE WINTHROP (wife of Robert Winthrop, the banker)
Description: Inherited a fortune from her father, Moses Taylor. Made in part in importing sugar and in shipping, but chiefly in the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads, gas, banks, and coal companies.

Name: BENJAMIN R. WINTHROP
Description: Inherited from his father and his mother (a Stuyvesant); made in the rise in value of real estate; increased by himself by investments.

Name: DAVID D. WITHERS
Description: Partly inherited. Increased by him in Louisiana in gas works, railroads, etc.

Name: HERBERT D. WARD (of Ward & Oliphant)
Description: Made in coal mining.

Name: MRS. SARAH WILLIAMS
Description: Inherited from George Law, and made in contracting and building, railroads, etc.

Name: MRS. ANNA F. WRIGHT
Description: From George Law. Made as above.

Name: MRS. MIRIAM F. WILDE (wife of William Wilde)
Description: From her first husband, Frank Leslie. Made in Frank Leslie’s newspaper and other publications.

Name: WILLIAM H. WEBB
Description: One of New-York City’s greatest ship builders, who before the War conducted an extensive business, and brought more millions of dollars to America by building great war vessels for European powers than any other American ever engaged in that industry. His accumulations have been increased by investment in street railroads, real estate, apartment houses, etc. Director in the Central Trust Company, Pennsylvania Coal Company, Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, New-York Balance Dock Company, and has other interests.

Name: J. HOOD WRIGHT (of Drexel, Morgan & Co.)
Description: Banking and investments. Director in the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway, Edison Electric Light Company, Edison Electric Illuminating Company, West Shore Railroad, etc.

Name: RICHARD T. WILSON (of R. L. Wilson & Co.)
Description: Commission cotton business, cotton oil, private banking, and railroad development in the South. Director in the Cincinnati, Jackson and Mackinaw Railroad, Union Trust Company, Western Union Beef Company, American Cotton Oil Company, Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, Fourth National Bank, Manhattan Trust Company, etc., etc.

Name: JEROME B. WHEELER
Description: Silver mines, banks and investments. President of the Grand River Coal and Coke Company, and the Aspen Mining and Smelting Company. Director in the Equitable Gas Light Company, and has other interests.

Name: ISIDOR WORMSER
Description: Banking, brokerage and stocks.

Name: SIMON WORMSER
Description: Banking, brokerage business and stocks. Director in the Manhattan Elevated Railway.

Name: MRS. CHARLES A. WHITNEY
Description: From her father, Charles Morgan, who made a fortune in coasting vessels, sail and steam, and Louisiana and Texas railroads, and from her husband, who was the manager of those interests.

Name: BENJAMIN WOOD
Description: Originally in lotteries. Then in publishing “The New-York Daily News.”

Name: JAMES WOOD
Description: Real estate in Harlem.

Name: MRS. CAROLINE S. WILSON (wife of Marshall Orme Wilson)
Description: A daughter of William Astor, from whom she received a fortune. Made in real estate.

Name: FR. FREDERICK S. WINSTON
Description: Began in drygoods. Then embarked in the Mutual Life Insurance Co., of which he was president, about thirty years. Director in the Michigan Central Railroad, etc.

Name: FRANK WORK (of Work, Strong & Co.)
Description: Private banking and brokerage business.

Name: WILLIAM ALFRED WIECHERS
Description: Sugar refining.

Name: MRS. ANNIE WOERISHOFER (widow of C. F. Woerishoffer)
Description: Made in brokerage business and stocks.

Name: WILLIAM A. WHEELOCK
Description: Drygoods importing; afterward in banking and various investments; director in the Equitable Life Assurance Society; New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad; American Surety Co.; Central National Bank; Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, etc., etc.

Name: WILLIAM L. WALLACE
Description: Manufacturing candy.

Name: MRS. SARAH A. WILLETS
Description: Daughter-in-law of Samuel Willets, from whom she inherited. Made in merchandising, whaling and investments.

Name: FREDERICK WILLETS
Description: Inherited from his grandfather, Samuel Willets, hardware merchant, whaling ship owner, and investor in real estate and securities.

Name: EDWARD WILLETS
Description: From Samuel Willets. Made as above.

Name: WALTER R. WILLETS
Description: Inherited a fortune from his grandfather, Samuel Willets, the hardware merchant, whaling-ship owner and investor in real estate and securities. Is himself engaged in dealing in grain.

Name: BUCHANAN WINTHROP
Description: Inherited a fortune.

Name: EGERTON L. WINTHROP
Description: Has inherited a fortune.

Name: JOHN WOLFE
Description: Inherited. Made in merchandising and real estate.

Name: MRS. JOHN WOLFE
Description: From her brother John B. Dash, made in part in merchandising, but chiefly in real estate.

Name: WILLIAM C. WHITNEY
Description: Law practice, railroads and investments.

Name: MRS. FLORA PAINE WHITNEY (wife of William C. Whitney)
Description: By gift from her brother and father. Made in producing, refining and transporting petroleum oil.

Name: WILLIAM WALDRON
Description: Rise in value of real estate.

Name: WALTER B. WALDRON
Description: Building and real estate.

Name: EDWARD WINSLOW (of Winslow, Lanier & Co.)
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: WILLIAM WHITEWRIGHT
Description: Made a fortune in merchandising. Has an interest in the Union Trust Company; New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railway, etc., etc.

Name: E. B. WESLEY
Description: Brokerage business and interest in “The New-York Times,” director in the Union Trust Company.

Name: ALBERT E. WHYLAND (of Thurber, Whyland & Co.)
Description: Wholesale groceries and the Trow City Directory Company; has other interests.

Name: ANTHONY WALLACH
Description: Made in jewelry; director in the United States Life Insurance Company; Importers and Traders’ National Bank; New-York Life Insurance Company; American Grocers’ Publishing Association, etc., etc.

Name: CHARLES C. WORTHINGTON
Description: Manufacturing steam pumps.

Name: JOHN T. WILLETS
Description: Made in merchandising, banking and real estate; president of the Leather Manufacturers’ National Bank.

Name: JAMES M. WATERBURY
Description: Manufacturing ropes and cordage, and investments; president of the Nassau Ferry Company; is in the New-York Bagging Company, etc.

Name: LORENZO G. WOODHOUSE (formerly of Field, Leiter & Co., Chicago)
Description: Has made a large fortune in drygoods.

Name: GEORGE C. WILLIAMS
Description: Has made a large fortune in banking and investments; president of the Chemical National Bank; director in the United States Life Insurance Company; New-York Life Insurance Company; Union Trust Company; Fidelity and Casualty Company; Eagle Fire Insurance Company; Peck, Stow & Wilcox Company; Title Guarantee and Trust Company; Institution for Savings of Merchants’ Clerks; Pennsylvania Coal Company; United States and Brazil Mail Steamship Company, etc., etc.

Name: ERASTUS WIMAN (of R. G. Dun & Co.)
Description: Made by very successful railroad and real estate enterprises on Staten Island; fortunate telegraph deals, and a liberal income from the R. G. Dun & Co. Mercantile Agency, of which he has been for years the mainspring; director in the Western Union Telegraph Company; the United States Book Company; Staten Island Rapid Transit Company, etc., etc.

Name: MRS. MARIA L. WADSWORTH (wife of James S. Wadsworth)
Description: Inherited a fortune from William R. Travers, her father. Made in Wall Street.

Name: MRS. WILLIAM WHITNEY
Description: From Stephen Whitney, the great merchant. Made in merchandising and investments in what was formerly suburban real estate, but now is part of the city.

Name: EDWARD J. WOOLSEY
Description: Rise in real estate.

Name: SAMUEL WYMAN
Description: Merchandising drygoods and investments in real estate.

Name: FRANK T. WHITE (of Hewson & White)
Description: Private banking and investments.

Name: WILLIAM WHITE
Description: Made in street railroads chiefly.

Name: WILLIAM STORRS WELLES
Description: Inherited a fortune made in real estate.

Name: MRS. RHINELANDER WALDO
Description: Inherited a fortune made in real estate.

Name: JACOB WEEKS
Description: Coal merchandising.

Name: CHARLES WATROUS
Description: Dealing in lumber and builders’ supplies in San Francisco and New-York.

Name: JOHN BRISSEN WALKER
Description: Made principally in the cultivation of a Colorado alfalfa farm, and in the rescue of considerable tract of worthless river-bed in Denver by certain engineering operations. Added to in publishing The Cosmopolitan Magazine in New-York City; and increase in value of farm and city land, incident to the growth of Denver, Colo.

Name: WILLIAM WATSON
Description: Made in drygoods and investments in real estate.

Name: JAMES WINSLOW (Winslow, Lanier & Co.)
Description: Made in banking and investments.

Name: ABRAHAM WOLFF (of Kuhn, Loeb & Co.)
Description: Banking and investments.

Name: HENRY WELSH
Description: Formerly in the wholesale grocery business, in which he made a fortune; which he has since increased by investment.

Name: JOHN S. YOUNG
Description: Merchandising and real estate investments.

Name: MRS. MARGARET ZIMMERMAN (widow of John E. Zimmerman)
Description: Inherited from her father, William P. Furniss, who made a fortune in shipbuilding and real estate.

Name: ELLIOTT ZBOROWSKI
Description: Inherited. Made in real estate. Has more than $1,000,000 of that class of property.

Name: ANDREW C. ZABRISKIE
Description: Inherited from the Aycrigg estate. Jane Aycrigg was the daughter of Thomas B. Gardner, who owned much real estate in New-York City, which has since grown enormously in value.
